div2.p: a)/rxetai—not historic, but primary and connected with ge/graptai below. Thuc. means to say ‘what preceded (i.e. book I.) was an introduction: now begins (my account of) the war itself.’ Cf. a)rca/menos, I. 1, 1: Diod. XII. 37 th\n i(stori/an e)nteu=qen a)rca/menos. Ullrich first rightly explained this passage.
o( po/lemos—i.e. the Archidamian War, 431-421; not the whole war to 404.

e)nqe/nde h)/dh—cf. Aristoph. Ach. 539 ka)nteu=qen h)/dh pa/tagos h)=n tw=n a)spi/dwn, referring to the outbreak of the war. e)nqe/nde refers back to I. 146, i.e. the account of the ai)ti/ai kai\ diaforai\ is now concluded. (The other explanation, referring e)nqe/nde to the attack on Plataea, is less satisfactory, as e)nqe/nde is so far from the account of the attempt.)

tw=n e(kate/rois c.—when cu/mmaxos is in the gen. plu., it is generally constructed as an adj., following that of cummaxei=n. Thus cacophony is avoided. Contrast I. 18 toi=s e(autw=n cumma/xois, IV. 81 toi=s *)aqhnai/wn c. e)n w(=|—neut. Cf. c. 11, 6, 35, 2, = quo tempore. It expresses not merely time, but includes circumstances. e)n w(=|=‘during which period.’
ou)/te...te —cf. c. 5, 5.

e)pemei/gnunto par' a)llh/lous—the e)pi-expresses reciprocity, as in e)pixrh=sqai. During the period of suspicion which preceded war, e)pemei/gnunto kai\ par' a)llh/lous e)foi/twn a)khru/ktws me/n, a)nupo/ptws d' ou)/, 1.146.
katasta/ntes—sc. e)s po/lemon, when once they had definitely started. Cf. c. 9, 1 and I. 49, 3. This refers to the interval between the attempt at Plataea and the invasion of Attica.

cunexw=s—down to the truce that preceded the Peace of Nicias. Cf. v. 24 tau=ta ta\ de/ka e)/th o( prw=tos po/lemos cunexw=s geno/menos, VI. 26 a)/rti d' a)neilh/fei h( po/lis e(auth\n a)po\ tou= cunexou=s pole/mou.

ge/graptai —sc. moi.—This resumes a)/rxetai, but ge/graptai is probably impersonal, Thuc. meaning ge/grafa. Attic prose shows a marked preference for perf. pass. over perf. act. forms in 3rd sing. Thus a(\ pe/praktai/ moi is far commoner than a(\ pe/praxa, which is quite rare. ge/grafa occurs once in Thuc., ge/graptai e)ge/grapto or partic. nine times.

e(ch=s—explained by kata\ q. kai\ xeimw=na. Distinguish between ta/cis, the arrangement of the subject matter as a whole, diai/resis, the divisions in which the separate events are grouped, e)cergasi/a, the treatment of
the separate events. It is to the diai/resis that Thuc. refers.
w(s e(/kasta e)gi/gneto—neut. plu. is used of the several events, just as Thuc. uses au)ta\ constantly of the details of the subject he is dealing with.

kata\ q. kai\ xeimw=na—as Thuc. begins his account of each summer with the first event of the new campaign, the summer in his history does not always begin exactly at the same time. Thus in 429, the account of summer begins with the Peloponnesian expedition against Plataea, which took place a)kma/zontos tou= si/tou, i.e. 80 days after the opening of spring (II. 71, 1; 79, 1; cf. c. 19, 1 and 2, 1). In 428 the account of the summer only begins a(/ma tw=| h)=ri a)kma/zonti (III. 1, 1). Phormio's arrival at Piraeus did not occur till spring had opened; but, for the sake of convenience, that event is tacked on to the preceding winter (II. 103). But usually the opening of spring is reckoned with summer. Autumn also is counted with summer. Though Steup maintains that summer and winter are of equal length in Thuc., Poppo's view, that the summer consists of eight months (Elaphebolion to Pyanepsion) is probably correct. Thus the winter is from Maemacterion to Anthesterion.

div3.p: ga\r—takes up a)/rxetai and introduces the narrative. So c. 49, to\ me\n gar e)/tos takes up dhlw/sw. e)ne/meinan—the aor. of a single historical fact. M. T. 56, 57 (sometimes called ‘complexive).’

*eu)boi/as a(/lwsin—Euboea revolted at the same time as Megara, 445 B.C. See I. 114, 115. The place of the article is taken by the gen., as often. Cf. I. 1 dia\ xro/nou plh=qos. Comparing this phrase with c. 49, 4 meta\ tau=ta lwfh/santa, VI. 3, 3 meta\ *surakou/sas oi)kisqei/sas, II 68 a)po\ tw=n *)amprakiwtw=n cunoikhsa/ntwn, VI. 80, 2, and similar predicative uses of the partic. collected by Stahl, Quaest. Gram. p. 28, we might suppose that Thuc. could have written meta\ *eu)/boian a(lou=san, just as below we have e)pi\ *xrusi/dos i(erwme/nhs, but, with the solitary exception of a(/ma with expressions of time, as a)/ma tw=| si/tw| a)kma/zonti, it is improbable that this convenient use of the partic. was ever employed unless the expression made sense without the partic., which would not be the case here. This convenient use is of course much commoner in Latin than in Greek.

e)pi\ *xrusi/dos —Argos, though humbled by Sparta, 495 B.C., was still the third state in Greece. The Argives reckoned by the number of years during which the priestess of Hera had held office. Hellanicus had written a work on the Priestesses of Argos, using them as marks for the dates.

*ai)nhsi/ou—sc. e)pi/: so with *puqodw/rou. e)fo/rou—i.e. the Ephor e)pw/numos. The omission of o)/ntos, for which cf. v. 25, 1, is rare except in dates. e)fo/rou o)/ntos = e)foreu/ontos. te/ssaras mh=nas—the archons entered on office on the 1st of Hecatombaeon, which in 431 B.C. fell on August 1st. To
express a period of time, the pres. (or imperf.) or perf. (or pluperf.) participle is used: to supply the reference to the completion of the period, (a) h)/dh is added, in primary sequence, which becomes to/te in secondary sequence: both refer to a period past at the time of speaking: (b) e)/ti referring to the completion of a period in the future. Thus v. 112, 2 ou)/t' e)n o)li/gw| xro/nw| po/lews e(ptako/sia e)/th h)/dh oi)koume/nhs th\n e)leuqeri/an a)fairhso/meqa, and observe to/te i(erwme/nhs and e)/ti a)/rxontos here. The four months are Elaphebolion, Munychion, Thargelion, Scirophorion.
*)aqhnai/ois—cf. 1. 93 a)rxh\n a)/rxein *)aqhnai/ois, but in v. 25 a)/rxontos *)aqh/nhsi. The dative is probably local. Cf. c. 86 and 92 a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn for a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnw=n. [

meta\ th\n mhni\ e(/ktw|]. Reasons for regarding these words as a later addition to the text are 1. Nearly a year (I. 125) intervened between the day on which the allies of Sparta decided to go to war and the first invasion of Attica (c. 19). Between the battle of Potidaea and the decision came the events recorded in I.63-88, 118-125. The invasion was 80 days after the attempt on Plataea (c. 19). So for the period between the battle at Potidaea and the attempt on Plataea we get nearly a year minus 80 days and the time occupied by the events of I. 63-88, 118-125. The result must clearly be more than six months But Lipsius' e(/ktw| kai\ deka/tw| probably gives too much time: thus, from battle at Potidaea to attempt on Plataea = 15 months; from attempt on Plataea to invasion of Attica = 80 days. Total about 17 1/2 months. Deducting nearly a year for the time between the decision of the allies and the invasion, we get about 6 1/2 months, at least, for the events of I.63-88, 118-125. These events were as follows: the Athenians built a wall on the north side of Potidaea and garrisoned it. After a considerable interval (xro/nw| u(/steron) Phormio was sent from Athens with 1600 hoplites. He spent some time on the road (kata\ braxu\ proiw/n). On arriving, he built a wall south of Potidaea. The Corinthians called a meeting of allies at Sparta. The Spartans sent to Delphi. Then a general meeting of allies was held at Sparta. at which the decision was come to. It is not clear whether the Corinthians proposed the first meeting after the north wall was built, or only after the south wall was finished. It is however highly improbable that they waited to take action till Potidaea was completely shut in; for they were most anxious about Potidaea, and were anxious to force on war. The Athenians would occupy about a month in building the north wall. Thus the Corinthians probably suggested the meeting about 40 days after the battle. Thus, the whole time would only be about 40 days + the time taken in the mission to Delphi and the calling of the second meeting. 2. The
bracketed words give no additional indication of the date of the attempt on Plataea. Thuc. wishes to be precise here, but he has given no definite indication of the date of the battle at Potidaea, nor was it necessary to do so. He says (1) the decision of the allies was some 11 months before the invasion, (2) the invasion was 80 days after the attempt. All that could be found from mhni\ e(/ktw| would be the date of the battle of Potidaea. If any event were here referred to it would rather be the decision of the allies.
a(/ma h)=ri a)rxome/nw|—the last day of Anthesterion, in 431 April 4th. See c. 4, 2
boiwtarxou=ntes—the 11 chiefs of the Boeotian confederacy, of whom Thebes elected two, the other cities one each.

peri\ prw=ton u(/pnon—cf. VII. 43 a)po\ prw/tou u(/pnou. When the article is omitted with expressions of time, a preposition is usually present, except with h(me/ras and nukto/s. See Rutherford, Syntax, p. 4. There were three watches, the first beginning about 10 o'clock.

cu
 o(/plois—in later Attic, except Xenophon, su
 has only two uses; (1) the old phrase su
 (toi=s) qeoi=s, (2) in enumerating things which are thrown together in a sum total; so that su
 is very rare with persons, and it never implies a willing connection. Andoc. II. 7 to
 pate/ra su
 e)mautw=| a)poktei=nai. Of (1) Thuc. has 1 example, II. 86; of (2) 11 examples, e.g. (a) with things—c. 13, 77,; v. 26 cu
 tw=| prw/tw| pole/mw| tosau=ta e)/th. Cf. VII. 42; VIII. 90, 95: (b) with persons, comparatively common in Thuc., I. 12; II. 6, 13; IV. 124; v. 74. Besides these, Thuc. has the old military phrase, cu
 (toi=s) o(/plois, 8 times. Cf. Eur. Hec. 112. Aristoph. Nub, 560. In the same class fall cu
 e(ni\ i(mati/w|, II. 70, yiloi\ cu
 cifidi/w| and cu
 dorati/ois III. 22. Cf. the Homeric su
 teu/xesi. Further, 6 cases of verbal nouns which modify the meaning of a verb, viz.: cu
 e)pai/nw| e)cotru/nein I. 84, cu
 kathgori/a| parocu/nein ib., cu
 xalepo/thti paideu/esqai ib., cu
 fo/bw| e)/xein ti I. 141, cu
 a)na/gkh| ti paqei=n III. 40, cu
 profa/sei kakw=s poiei=n ib. The absence of this archaic idiom from the later books is remarkable. Lastly, 3 cases of a connection willingly formed, viz.: II. 58; III. 90; VII. 57. This is common in Tragedy and Xenophon. In inscriptions of the classical period only the Attic use marked (2) above is found, and that never with persons.
e)phga/gonto—the ta/cis (see on c. 1) of this c. is dramatic, the causes which led to the attempt being given parenthetically in 2 and 3, while the narrative is continued at 4.

*plataiw=n a)/ndres—the Thebans call them, III. 65, a)/ndres oi( prw=toi kai\ xrh/masi kai\ ge/nei. These leaders of the aristocratic party represent the great land-owners as distinct from the merchants.
a)/ndras tou\s u(penanti/ous—the order, noun, art, adj., puts emphasis on the adj. Cf. c. 34, 4.
e)/pracan—of manipulation or diplomacy, as often. Cf. c. 5, 7. An abuse of the meaning ‘to succeed.’
e)/soito —was certain. Cf. c. 13, 1.

e)/ti e)n ei)rh/nh|—cf. III. 13 e)/ti e)n th=| ei)rh/nh|, and c. 5, 4. Here te kai\ joins a positive to a negative expression which merely repeats it from another point of view. Cf. v. 9, 2 tw=| te kat' o)li/gon kai\ mh\ a)/pantas kinduneu/ein.
mh/pw—the sentence expresses a wish.
h(=| kai\ ra=|on—cf. h(=| kai\ ma=llon I. 11, 25; III. 13; IV. 1, 103. h(=| kai\ before a comparative adverb emphasizes an inference.
e)/laqon e)selqo/ntes—see M. T. 144, 146, 887.
prokaqesthkui/as —Pp. compares anteponere vigilias, Tac. An. I. 50.
qe/menoi ta\ o(/pla—cum in foro constitissent, lit. ‘having grounded their arms.’
toi=s e)pagome/nois—the temporal force is lost, and the partic. becomes a substantive, as in oi( prodido/ntes c. 5.
e)pei/qonto w(/ste—cf. c. 101, 5.
w(/ste is often inserted with verbs which take simple infin., the main emphasis is transferred from the finite to the infin. M. T. 588.
e)/rgou e)/xesqai —rem aggredi. Cf. 1.49, 7, 78, 3.

i)e/nai e)s—for the hostile sense of i)e/nai cf. v. 69 e)s th\n gh=n e)lqei=n, ‘to attack.’ e)pi\ is commoner than e)s, as I. 58 h)\n e)pi\ *potei/daian i)/wsin. Cf. c. 3, 4. e)/rxomai, ei)=mi, h(/kw, h)=lqon and synonyms are far more supple in sense than our ‘to come.’ Note that the moods of ei)=mi are usually present in meaning, except in Oratio Obliqua.
gnw/mhn e)poiou=nto—i.e. e)gi/gnwskon, ‘came to a decision.’
e)pithdei/ois—so c. 18, 3.
kai\ a)nei=pen—‘and in fact,’ kai\ introducing the parenthesis and emphasizing the word following. Cf. c. 49, 5, 51, 5.

ei)/ tis bou/letai—in a protasis to a condition in Oratio Obliqua, probably only the future indicative is ever changed into optative, so that the optative in protasis in Or. Obl., except in the future, represents either h)\n and subjunctive or ei) and optative of the Recta.
kata\ ta\ pa/tria—in Iliad II. 504 Plataea is enumerated among the Boeotian confederate cities.

cummaxei=n—this may be a gloss on ti/qesqai k.t.l. Cf. IV. 30 prokalou/menoi, ei) bou/lointo, ta\ o(/pla keleu/ein paradou=nai, and so 37; v. 115 e)kh/rucan, ei)/ tis bou/letai, lh/|zesqai, VII. 82 kh/rugma poiou=ntai, ei)/ tis bou/letai, w(s sfa=s a)pie/nai. With bou/lomai an infinitive has often to be supplied from the context.

w(s h)/|sqonto—cf. c. 5, 4, 31, 1, 94, 3. The aorist is usual with w(s, but, whatever tense is used, it is always independent of that of the main verb. In this respect w(s differs from other temporal particles. Thus if imperf. is used, as in c. 77, 1, or pluperf. as in c. 59, 1, it is because that tense is required to describe a continuous or completed act, apart from the main verb. If the act in a temporal sentence is represented as simultaneous with or preceding the action of the main
sentence, o(/te or e)peidh\ is used.
h)/|sqonto—‘became aware,’ ingressive aor., a use almost confined to 1st aor. forms.

e)capinai/ws—this and e)capi/nhs, in place of e)cai/fnhs or ai)fnidi/ws, are Ionic, and only found in Thuc. and Xenophon of Attic prose writers. [Dem.] c. Neaeram § 99 is copied from this passage. Cf. c. 48, 2, 93, 3.
katadei/santes kai\ n.— ingressive, ‘having become alarmed,’ etc.
pollw=| plei/ous— sc. h)\ e)sh=lqon. An ellipse with comparative is very common.
e)n th=| nukti\—per noctis caliginem. Cf. e)n nukti\ below, and c. 4 e)n sko/tw| kai\ ph/lw|.
pro\s c. e)xw/rhsan—se converterunt Cf. III. 66 proei/pomen to\n boulo/menon kata\ ta\ pa/ntwn *boiw=twn pa/tria politeu/ein i)e/nai pro\s h(ma=s, IV. 120, VIII. 40, 2.
e)newte/rizon—the subject is changed, as in 4 below. Thuc. assumes that his readers will follow the narrative attentively.
pra/ssonte/s pws—the particle implies that unnecessary details are omitted. Cf. a)/llws pws in brief narrative, I. 99,, VI.2.
krath/sein—Cl. defends krath=sai, on the ground that the aor. expresses confidence in the result of the action in e)piqe/menoi. But the aor. inf. is very doubtful used thus for the future.
tw=| ga\r plh/qei—ga\r gives the writer's explanation, and shows that oi( *plataih=s above was loosely used for to\ plh=qos tw=n *p.
boulome/nw| h)=n—so VII. 35; VIII. 92, 6. M. T. 900. The editors compare Sallust, Jug. 84 plebei volenti putabatur, ib., 100 militibus labor volentibus esset. Livy XXI. 50.
e)pixeirhte/a ei)=nai—cf. I. 118 e)pixeirhte/a e)do/kei ei)=nai pa/sh| proqumi/a|. Plur. neut. forms for sing. are very common in Thuc., especially with verbals.
cunele/gonto—with par' a)llh/lous, dioru/ssontes tou\s t.—cf. toixwru/xos.
a(ma/cas te—the conjunction adds a third and important fact, as often.
h)=|—sc. au)to/, what has just been described, the barrier of waggons.
e(toi=ma—the plur. marks the details of a complex act. See c. 10, 2
fula/cantes e)/ti nu/kta—cf. VII. 83 th=s nukto\s fula/cantes to\ h(suxa/zon. ‘Waited for the time when it was still night.’
e)/ti nu/kta is equivalent to th\n e)/ti nu/kta.
fula/cantes e)/ti nu/kta—cf c. 2, 1.
kai\—adds the more exact time.

peri/orqron —the beginning of that time of night denoted by o)/rqros. Cf. IV. 110 nukto\s e)/ti kai\ peri\ o)/rqron, VI. 101 peri\ o)/rqron, According to Phrynichus (Bekker An. Gr. 54, 8) o)/rqros e)stin h( w(/ra th=s nukto\s kaq' h(\n a)lektru/ones a(/|dousin. a)/rxetai de\ e)na/ths w(/ras kai\ teleuta=| ei)s diagelw=san h(me/ran. So in III. 112, Demosthenes attacked the Ambraciots a(/ma o)/rqrw|, at which time they could not distinguish friend from foe, nukto\s e)/ti ou)/shs. Thus the Plataean rally was at about 2 o'clock.
gi/gnwntai—sc. oi( *qhbai=oi. Cf. I. 143 ou)ke/ti e)k tou= o(moi/ou e)/stai, III. 12, 3.

foberw/teroi—for the passive meaning, ‘timid,’ cf. IV. 128, 4.
Conversely a)deh\s which is usually active is occasionally passive =not formidable. See I. 36, 1. Cf. prostro/paios, a)lith/rios, and in Latin formidolosus and others. See Cook on Sallust, Cat. 39, 2. Shil. quotes Soph. O. T. 153 fobera\n fre/na dei/mati pa/llwn.

h(/ssous w)=si th=s—i.e. h(ssw=ntai equivalent to nikw=ntai u(po\ th=s k.t.l. sfete/ras—indirect reflexive, i.e. refers to subject of the main verb, not to that of its own clause. Cf. c. 83, 3, 89, 4; IV. 37, 1; V. 47; VII. 48; VIII. 74, 3. This is the regular use of sfe/teros, whereas sfe/teros au)tw=n is the same as e(autw=n. But Thuc. also uses sfe/teros alone as direct reflexive, as IV. 33 ou)k e)dunh/qhsan th=| sfete/ra| e)mpeiri/a| xrh/sasqai: and in dependent clauses, as c. 71 and IV. 11 tas sfete/ras nau=s katagnu/nai e)ke/leue. ta\ sfe/tera is direct in c. 20, 4; IV. 99, 1, indirect in III. 68, 3.
prose/balo/n te—inferential te, ‘and so.’
e)/gnwsan—‘became aware,’ ingressive.
cunestre/fonto—‘proceeded to rally,’ imperf. expressing difficulty.
sfi/sin au)toi=s—in c. 65, 12, 76, 2 Thuc. has the Ionic use of sfa=s alone as a direct reflexive. See Rutherford, Syntax, p. 11.

di\s me
 ... e)/peita—cf IV. 115 kai\ mi/an me
 h(me/ran a)pekrou/santo, th=| d' u(sterai/a|. As regards e)/peita without de/, the ordinary use is prw=ton (prw=ta) me
. e)/peita, which Thuc. uses 28 times; see c. 19, 2, 49, 2, 75, 1, 89, 2, 96, 1, 98, 1. He has prw=ton (prw=ta) me
 ... e)/peita de\ 8 times; see c. 55, 84. If kai\ follows e)/peita, de\ is always inserted, e.g. c. 84; IV. 43; VII. 23; VIII. 48; also ma/lista me
 is always followed by e)/peita de/, as c. 54; I. 75; VI. 11, 4, 16, 5, 67, 2. If the more emphatic e)/peita me/ntoi is used, it is preceded by to\ prw=ton or to\ me
 p., as III. 93, 1, 111, 3; VIII. 75, 1, 86, 2. to\ me
 prw=ton .. e)/peita occurs I. 131; V. 41, 3, 84, 2; the same, but e)/peita de\ c. 48; v. 41, 2. prw=ton alone is always answered by e)/peita alone, unless kai\ follows e)/peita, as in VII. 23 to\ me/giston prw=ton, e)/peita de\ kai\ k.t.l. After other phrases, e)/peita is without de\ in 10 cases, has de\ in 2, viz. c. 92, 1; I. 18, 3.

kraugh=|—Moeris says kekragmo\s *)attikoi/, kraugh\ *(/ellhnes, but kekragmo/s, ke/kragma and kraugh/ are all Attic words. Perhaps Moeris really wrote kraugasmo\s *(/ellhnes, which would agree with Phrynichus.
kai\—there is chiasmus here and in li/qois kai\ kera/mw|.

o)lolugh=|—‘cheering,’ this word is used regularly of women. Pollux I. 28 o)lolu=cai kai\ o)lolugh=| xrh/sasqai e)pi\ gunaikw=n. Hence kraugh=| goes with oi)ketw=n, o)lolugh=| with gunaikw=n. Eur. I. T. 1337 a)nwlo/luce kai\ kath=|de of Iphigenia; cf. Aesch. Ag. 587 of Clytaemnestra. Verg. Aen. IV. 667, IX. 477 femineo ululatu.
te ... te—these join xrwme/nwn to ballo/ntwn and represent the two actions as going on simultaneously. Cf. c. 22 e)kklhsi/an te ou)k e)poi/ei ... th/n te po/lin e)fu/lasse.

li/qois kai\ kera/mw|—no doubt the slaves had gathered the stones, while the women removed the tiles. For ke/ramos collective, cf. III. 74, 1; IV. 48, 2. So e)/palcis c. 13, ka/lamos c. 76. Xen. Mem. III. 1, 7 li/qoi kai\ pli/nqoi kai\ cu/la kai\ ke/ramos.
dia\ nukto\s—cf. dia\ panto\s c. 16, 2.
pollou=—predicate with e)pigenome/nou Cf. VII. 87 ai( nu/ktes e)pigigno/menai metopwrinai\ kai\ yuxrai/.
e)pigenome/nou—expresses any sudden or unexpected phenomenon. Cf. c. 64, 1, 70, 1, 77, 5. The other meaning occurs in 4 below.
oi( plei/ous—the subject is here limited by apposition from all to the majority, Cf. I. 2, 6 oi( e)kpi/ptontes ... oi( dunatw/tatoi. So in Latin, Livy XXI.24, 2 Galli ... aliquot populi.

phlw=|—so that progress was impeded. Cf. c. 5, 2. This shows that the streets of Plataea were bad, like Greek streets generally. On the outskirts of the town the soil was certainly soft, and the Thebans fled in the direction of the valley of the Asopus, so that the further they went, the worse the road became. Probably in wet weather the streets of the town resembled water-courses carrying down the water from Cithaeron to the Asopus.
tw=n dio/dwn—belongs like h(=| xrh\ s. to a)/peiroi o)/ntes.
h(=| xrh\— takes the place of a deliberative subj. (why?). Cf. I. 91, 1 ou)k ei)=xon o(/pws xrh\ a)pisth=sai.

kai\ ga\r—explains only e)n sko/tw|, phlw=| being already explained in u(etou= a(/ma. teleutw=ntos tou= mhno\s—there was a new moon on the early morning of the 7th April 431, and, as the Attic months were lunar, assuming the calendar to have been in perfect order (it must have been in fair order), the month Elaphebolion began at sunset on the 6th April. The attempt was made at the end of Anthesterion, on the night of April 4th or 5th. When the calendar month did not correspond with the true lunar month, the true day of the new moon was called noumhni/a kata\ selh/nhn (c. 28).
e)mpei/rous de\ e)/xontes tou\s d.—for e)mpei/rwn de\ o)/ntwn tw=n d. Cf. I. 144 au)tono/mous a)fh/somen ei) kai\ au)tono/mous e)/xontes e)speisa/meqa.

[tou= mh\ e)kfeu/gein—this is taken as ne effugereni. (There is another tradition, due to Kr., that it expresses a consequence, which is not in good Attic.) It must depend on diw/kontas,—which gives the platitude that the enemy pursued them that they might not escape. To avoid this, Cl. explains it as equivalent to tou= mh\ e)a=n e)kfeu/gein and constructs it with e)mpei/rous. But (1) there is no other case of gen, of inf. with adjectives in Thuc., (2) e)mpei/rous tou= e)kfeu/gein ought to mean ‘experienced in escaping.’ Supply tw=n dio/dwn with e)mpei/rous. w(/ste diefqei/ronto oi( p.]—the article, found in BCEFGM and in A corrected, contradicts to\ plei=ston in 5 below, and o)gdoh/konta kai\ e(kato\n c. 5, 7, the number captured out of a force of few over 300 (c. 2, 1), when many others had been killed or had escaped (4 below). Bekker omits oi(, followed by
most edd., and the imitation of Aen. Pol. 2, 6 is quoted oi( me\n ga\r e)/fugon a)/peiroi o)/ntes h(=| xrh\ swqh=nai, oi( de\ e)mpei/rws diw/kontes pa/nu pollou\s e)/fqeiran. But on reading the whole chap. to 4, it becomes clear that no results of the flight are given till 4, where the fate of the whole number is told: so that these words break the continuity of the narrative.

sturaki/w| a)konti/ou—stura/kion labw/n tis e)n tw=| moxlw=| th=s qu/ras e)ne/balen, Schol. The stura/kion is the spike at the top of a small javelin for fixing it in the ground; = Homeric saurwth/r. This was used instead of the ba/lanos or iron pin which was driven through the mo/xlos (bar) and the door, and could not be removed without a key (balana/gra, klei/s), which fitted into it. Arnold remarks that the action is the same as spiking a gun. Cf. Aristoph. Av. 1159 a(/pant' e)kei=na pepu/lwtai pu/lais kai\ bebala/nwtai kai\ fula/ttetai ku/klw|. xrhsa/menos e)s —cf. c. 49 e)/drasan e)s ta\ fre/ata.

diwko/menoi .. a)naba/ntes e)/rriyan—the 1st partic. gives the cause of a)na/bantes, while the latter is temporal to e)/rriyan. Cf. c. 59, 3, 76, 1, 90, 3. The 2nd partic. tends to become a mere adverb to the verb, as c. 90, 1 boulo/menoi proagagei=n au)tou/s, a)nagago/menoi e)/pleon. oi( me/n tines ... oi( de\ ... a)/lloi de\ ... to\ de\ plei=ston—the partic. diwko/menoi is subdivided. Also oi( me/n tines is restricted by oi( plei/ous.

[laqo/ntes kai\]—it is evident that gunaiko\s dou/shs pe/lekun must be joined with diako/yantes, but kai\ is in the way of this. But, though Stahl's reading is given, perhaps Thuc. wrote gunaiko\s dou/shs pe/lekun kai\ diako/yantes to\n moxlo\n laqo/ntes e)ch=lqon. There would then be no objection to kai/. For the want of symmetry in dou/shs kai\ diako/yantes, see c. 25, 1. For the two participles diako/yantes, laqo/ntes, the first temporal, the second defining the verb, see c. 33, 3. The objection to bracketing kai\ only is that Thuc. would have written la/qra| diako/yantes, as IV. 110; VIII. 84.
a)/lloi de\ a)/llh| th=s—cf. c. 76 a)/llas de\ a)/llh| tou= tei/xous.
to\ plei=ston ... e)spi/ptousin—plur. verb after a collective, as often. Rutherford, Syntax, p. 21.

o(\ h)=n tou= tei/xous—cf. I. 134 oi)/khma o(\ h)=n tou= i(erou=. It was not usual in early times to have buildings adjacent to the walls. Cf. c. 17, 1 note. Hence the Thebans thought the building was part of the gate-way, supposing it to be double like the Dipylon at Athens. Thebes prided herself on her seven great gates, and it is highly improbable that the pomoerium was thus violated in that city. There cannot have been many such buildings at Plataea, for in c. 76 we see there was room for a curved wall between the tei=xos and the mass of the buildings.

a)new|gme/nai e)/tuxon—in order to represent the action as complete, the perf. partic., not aor., has to be used
with tugxa/nw, lanqa/nw, fqa/nw, unless the verb is in imperf, or pres. See M. T. 144, 146, 147, 887. Cf. I. 103 *nau/pakton e)/tuxon h(|rhko/tes. au)tou=—in the second member of a relative sentence the relative is not repeated, but a demonstrative or personal pron. takes its place. Cf. c. 34, 5, 72, 1, 74, 3. Exceptions are c. 43, 3, 44, 1, where the relative is repeated. Cf. ‘Whose fan is in His hand, and He shall throughly purge His floor.’

pu/las—pu/lai tou= tei/xous, qu/rai tou= oi)/kou Schol. Cf. tei=xos and toi=xos. a)/ntikrus—‘right through.’ In VI. 49 it means direct. In all other places in Thuc. downright, complete, as VIII. 64 e)pi\ th\n a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/an. It is said that a)/ntikrus = fanerw=s, a)/ntikru (not found in Thuc.) = e)c e)nanti/as.
katakau/swsin—cf. c. 52 ou)k e)/xontes o(/ ti ge/nwntai. w(/sper e)/xousin—sc. oi( *qhbai=oi, on the spot. Often in Thuc., but later Atties use ou(/tws in much the same sense.
ta\ o(/pla kai\ sfa=s au)tou\s—the phrase is common, and the order is always the same. Cf. IV. 21, 3, 30, 4, 37, 2, 38, 3. Livy XXII. 60, 24 and 26 arma et vos ipsos traditis.

xrh/sasqai o(/ ti a)\n b.—with xrh/sasqai supply sfi/si only. Cf. c. 24, 2. xrh/sasqai expresses purpose, the act. or mid. being regular in this construction even when the pass. might seem more suitable. M. T. 770. The phrase is regular in the terms of a complete surrender. Cf. IV. 69, 3; VII. 85, 1. Andoc. I. 11, 26.
me\n dh\—dismisses the subject.
e)pepra/gesan—the pluperf shows that Thuc. has anticipated: in c. 5 he goes back.
e)/dei paragene/sqai—‘ought to have reached Plataea.’ M. T. 415. Cf. c. 92, 7, 95, 3.

ei)/ ti a)/ra—cf. c. 12, 1. The following are noteworthy: (1) ei)/ mh\ a)/ra = nisi forte, e.g. Xen. Mem. I. 2, 8 pw=s a)
 ou)=n o( toiou=tos a)nh diafqei/roi tou\s ne/ous; ei) mh\ a)/ra h( th=s a)reth=s e)pime/leia diafqora/ e)stin. (2) ei/ a)/ra in indirect questions, e.g. Plat. Phaedo, 95 B peirw/meqa ei/ a)/ra ti le/geis. (3) ei) a)/ra or h)
 a)/ra in protasis, as I. 140 h)
 a)/ra ti kai\ sfallw/meqa. a)/ra implies a quite unlikely contingency.
proxwroi/h—the apodosis is only implied in e)/dei paragene)sqai. M. T. 696. h)\n proxwrh=| might have been kept. proxwrei=n is a favourite word with Thuc.
a(/ma—belongs to r(hqei/shs, as c. 4 u(etou= a(/ma e)pigenome/nou. r(hqei/shs—more usually e)lqou/shs, but the former is better suited to a hurried announcement to an army on the march.

tw=n gegenhme/nwn —the Theban reinforcements were ignorant of the destruction of their friends when they arrived, see 4 below. Hence these ta\ gegenhme/na told them were not complete. The message was doubtless brought by those who escaped kata\ pu/las e)rh/mous, who did not know all.
e)peboh/qoun—‘increased their speed.’ Cf. III. 110, 1.
e(bdomh/konta—probably rather over the direct route, but approximately correct measured by the road.
geno/menon —of natural phenomena, as often. Cf. c. 77 e)ge/neto flo/c, u(/dwr kai\ bronta\s genome/nas. e)rru/h me/gas—cf. c. 75 h)/|reto me/ga.
te—‘and so.’
u(/steron—‘late,’ cf. c. 80 u(/steron h)=lqon.
tw=n a)ndrw=n—apposition with tw=n me\n ... tw=n de\, as in 4, 4.
zw/ntwn—predicative.
kataskeuh/—‘property,’ viz. household effects and farming implements. kataskeuh\ means anything that makes a place habitable and worth living in. See L. and S.
oi(=a —Ionic for a(/te.

e)bou/lonto ei)/ tina la/boien k.t.l.—M. T. 695. The second protasis is not co-ordinate with the first. In a more certain form the sentence would run o(/ntina la/boiein u(pa/rxein e)bou/lonto a)nti\ tw=n e)/ndon e)zwgrhme/nwn.

diabouleuome/nwn—reciprocal mid., like diale/gomai, diapra/ttomai. When a compound of dia\ is not available, the same sense is given by e)n e(autoi=s or sfi/sin au)toi=s, as IV. 25, 9 parakeleuo/menoi e)n e(autoi=s, VIII. 76 paraine/seis e)poiou=nto e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s, sometimes by e)n a)llh/lois, for which see c. 65, 11.
u(potoph/santes—rare and poetical, used by Thuc. 8 times, only in aor. inf. or partic.
peri\ toi=s e)/cw—the dat. with peri\ gradually disappeared in Attic and occurs but once in the orators, Isocr. Ep. 9, 10. It is regular in Thuc. with verbs of fearing.

o(si/ws—when used of states, o(/sios means in accordance with those principles of right dealing universally recognised (jus gentium). Cf. III. 56 e)timwrhsa/meqa kata\ to\n pa=si no/mon kaqestw=ta, to\n e)pio/nta pole/mion o(/sion ei)=nai a)mu/ne/sqai. ib. c. 58, 3. See on c. 52, 3. Eur. Hec. 788.
sfw=n —with po/lin. The position is for the sake of emphasis.
peiraqe/ntes—the Attic aor. of peirw=mai is e)peira/qhn, cf. c. 33, 2. But Thuc. uses also the lonic e)peirasa/mhn in c. 44 and 85.
e)/legon—interrupts the structure of ou)/te ... te, but the irregularity is very slight. le/gw in sense of keleu/w regularly takes infin., mh\ being the neg.

ei) de\ mh/—cf. I. 28 ei) de\ mh/, kai\ au)toi\ a)nagkasqh/sesqai e)/fasan. The addition of e)/fasan, suspected also by Kr. in both places, certainly adds clearness, yet Thuc. proceeds in a quite different way in c. 13. But the difference in the nature of the matter of these chapters (the one narrative, the other reflective) may account for the difference of style.

a)naxwrhsa/ntwn ... au)toi=s—the use of the gen. abs. in spite of the dat. following, makes the act in the partic. more prominent, and prevents it from being a mere appendage of a)podw/sein. A common sacrifice of form to sense in Herod. and Thuc. au)toi=s is wrongly bracketed in the text.
e)pomo/sai—jusjurandum addere. Does not occur elsewhere in Thuc.

eu)qu\s—with a)podw/sein. as the following
words show.
h)/n ti cumbai/nwsi—closely with genome/nwn, ‘with a view to an arrangement.’ h)\n cumbw=si would be ‘if they come to an arrangement.’
d' ou)=n—doubtful statements are dismissed and the narrative of facts resumed.
ou)de\n a)dikh/santes—contrast ou)de\n a)dikou=ntes=‘guiltless.’
ta\ e)k th=s xw/ras e)sekomi/santo —the preposition attracted to the verb, for e)n. Cf. c. 13, 2, 14, 1.
a)pe/kteinan—assuredly justified as an act of reprisal, but most impolitic, as calculated to provoke Thebes and Sparta.
ei(=s au)tw=n h)=n—the so-called partitive gen. is often used thus without ei(=s, which is wanting in C. Cf. I. 85 ei(=s tw=n e)fo/rwn to/te w)/n, v. 59, 5; VIII. 39, 2.

pro\s o(/n e)/pracan —so I. 131, I; IV. 114, 3. This is only a variant for pra/ssein with dat., as IV. 110, 2; v. 76, 3. But when many persons are dealt with, pra/ssein e)s is also used, as I. 132, 4. The same three constructions follow le/gein: pro/s, Andoc. I. 48; dat., ib. I. 69; e)s, ib., l.c. Eur. Hec. 303 ei(=pon ei)s a(/pantas, ‘proposed in the general assembly.’
oi( prodido/ntes —see on c. 2, 4.

e)/pempon—the imperf. with verbs of ‘going’ and ‘sending,’ presenting the details of an elaborate negociation involving a journey, is common. Cf. c. 85, 2; I. 10, 5, 26, 1, and 3 below. But the aor. is also used. M. T. 57.

kai\ —has nothing to do with the te preceding, which is answered by the te following. Thus the sentence consists of two members joined by te .. te. Cf. I. 69, 1 to/ te prw=ton e)a/santes . . kai\ u)/steron ta\ makra\ sth=sai tei/xh, e)s to/de te ai)ei\ a)posterou=ntes. So in 4 below.
h)gge/lqh eu)qu\s—does not refer to e)/pempon a)/ggelon, but to two previous messages mentioned in 3 below. Plataea is something over 30 miles from Athens.

kai\ .. cune/labon— parataxis, presenting the two facts as almost concurrent. The second was prompt and hurried. Cf. I. 61 h)=lqe kai\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois eu)qu\s h) a)ggeli/a ... kai\ pempousin. e)/pemyan ... keleu/ontes—the activity of the sender is continued in the person sent. Cf. c. 85, 1.

new/teron poiei=n—i.e. newteri/zein. Cf. I. 132, 5; IV. 55 mh\ new/tero/n ti ge/nhtai. pri
 a)
—after historic tenses, pri
 a)
 and subj. is used only in Oratio Obliqua. Cf. c. 84, 1, 102, 5.
a(/ma th=| e)so/dw| gignome/nh|—see c. 2, 1.
ou(/tw dh\— gives the result of facts just stated, contrast c. 19, 1.
ou)k ei)do/tes—sc. o(/ti teqnh/kasin. e)pe/stellon—see 1 above.
e)gkate/lipon—so e)gkaqe/zomai III. 1; e)gkaqi/sthmi I. 4; e)gkaqormi/zomai IV. 1; e)gkatoikodomei=n III. 18; e)gkataskh/ptein c. 47.

tou\s a)xreiota/tous—sunt a)xrei=oi omnes inhabiles militiae,’ Pp. Cf. c. 44. Juv. 15, 126 imbelle et inutile
vulgus. For the deeper application of a)xrei=os, see c. 40, 2.
e)ceko/misan—c. 78, 3.
lelume/nwn—before the attempt on Plataea, each side had interpreted the other's action as spondw=n cu/gxusis (I. 146), but there had been no open violation of the letter of the truce.
lamprw=s—cf. I. 49, 7; VIII. 66, 3, 75, 2.

pareskeua/zonto de\—the anaphora would have been more perfect with pareskeua/zonto me
 preceding, but Thuc. often omits me/n in cases where it is not required, though a writer more careful about symmetry would msert it: perhaps he purposely avoids a rhetorical formula in narrative. The common cases in Thuc. are very simple, as polloi\ me
 ... polloi\ de/, ei) me
 .. ei) de/, a(/ma me
 ... a(/ma de/. Cf. I. 28 with pe/mpete; VI. 20, 4; also c. 41, 3 mo/nh ga kai\ mo/nh. me/llontes—belongs to both subjects, as poiou/menoi below. Probably both intended sending to Persia, though the Athenians did not carry out their intention. See c. 67.
pe/mpein—M. T. 73, 96.
a)llo/se—see c. 29.
e(autw=n—for sfete/ras. Cf. c. 92, 4, and see c. 3, 4.

*lakedaimoni/ois ... e)peta/xqh—i.e. *lakedaimo/nioi e)pe/tacan. This dat. of the agent is very rare with other parts of the pass. than perf. It occurs in I. 51 toi=s *kerkurai/ois ou)x e(wrw=nto, IV. 64 ti/nes a)\n dikaio/teron pa=si ... misoi=nto, ib. 109 po/leis oi)kou=ntai cummi/ktois e)/qnesi. There are only two instances in the Orators.
au)tou=—in the harbours of Peloponnese.

e)c *)i. kai\ *s.—with toi=s e(lome/nois, but placed first for the sake of the antithesis with au)tou=. Cf. c. 18, 3 kata\ th\n a)/llhn porei/an h( sxolaio/ths. nau=s e)peta/xqh—Stahl supports his reading with great ability. It will be noticed that these Dorian cities, reckoned by Sparta among her allies, are not mentioned in c. 9 with the cu/mmaxoi, because there only those who actually contributed to the armament are given, and these cities contributed nothing. III. 86, 2.
poiei=sqai—middle, nau=s being the object. Cf. I. 14, 2.
e)s to\n pa/nta a)—‘in all.’ When the article precedes pa=s, the whole is regarded as the sum of its component parts.
pentakosi/wn—by no means realised. The Spartan navy in the Archidamian War was contemptible. See c. 66 and 85. Thuc. speaks with some irony.
ta/ t' a)/lla—perhaps ta)=lla should be read here, the t' being due to dittography.

h(suxa/zontas—the change from the dat. e(lome/nois is due to the infin. This change from gen. or dat. is always possible except when a word is the predicate to a gen. or dat., as I. 71 boulome/nwn u(mw=n ei)=nai proqu/mwn. See c 24, 1.

mia=| nhi\—si singulis navibus venissent; nam pluribus venientes timendum esse ne hostiliter agerent, Pp. This gives an example to show how they
were to refrain from hostile acts (h(suxa/zontas).
e(/ws a)\n— whereas with pri/n, me/xri and me/xri ou(= Thuc. occasionally omits a)\n when subjunctive is used, according to the older Attic idiom, this is never the case with e(/ws. Cf. c. 72, 3.
ta\ peri\ *p.—‘in the neighbourhood of P.’ like circa. Cf. c. 99, 3.

ma=llon—‘more than elsewhere,’ so ‘especially.’ Cf. c. 15 e(te/rwn ma=llon. *ke/rkuran— the places are given in inverse order, the final point reached coming first. Cf. c. 93, 1. Eur. Bach. 13 fol. At present only an e)pimaxi/a existed between Athens and Corcyra. See Intr. p. LXVI.

*kefallhni/an—it took no part in the war at first, but joined Athens towards the end of the summer. See c. 30. *)akarna=nas—except the Oeniadae, c. 102, 2, the Acarnanians were reckoned as allies from the first, though no treaty was concluded till the autumn of 430. See c. 68. *za/kunqon—its interests and policy coincided with those of Corcyra. Cf. c. 9, 4; I. 47, 2.
ei) ... ei)/h— Recta, e)a\n ... h)=|. See 2, 4.
bebai/ws—cf. IV. 20, 3 fi/lous gene/sqai bebai/ws. pe/ric katapolemh/sontes—se undique impugnaturos.
o)li/gon ou)de\n—cf. VII. 59, 3, 87, 6; VIII. 15, 2. o)li/gon is predicate.
te—‘in fact,’ summing up the preceding remarks. Cf. 3 below.
e)/rrwnto—totis viribus incumbebant. Thuc. uses the literal sense only once, VII. 15.
ou)k a)peiko/tws—so ei)ko/tws in the Orators is often followed by ga/r. Cf. I. 77, 5. So ou)k a)kousi/ws below.
a)rxo/menoi—i.e. there is greater enthusiasm at the beginning of an undertaking than after the first excitement has worn off.
a)ntilamba/nontai— sc. tw=n pragma/twn, rem capessunt.
to/te de\—contrasted with pa/ntes. kai\—an additional reason existed then.

neo/ths —juventus. Cf. c. 20, 2, 21, 2. The abstract term, like h(liki/a, represents the young men as a power in the State. Cf. Pericles' remark, quoted by Aristot. Rhet. A. 7, 34 th\n neo/thta e)k th=s po/lews a)nh|rh=sqai w(/sper to\ e)/ar e)k tou= e)niautou= ei) e)caireqei/h. u(p' a)peiri/as—so u(po\ is used with any noun denoting any state of mind which is the immediate cause of action. See c. 47, 4. paroimi/a: gluku\s a)pei/rw| po/lemos [Pindar, frag. 87 Bergk] Schol.
h( a)/llh *(ella\s—all States in or outside Greece. Cf. I. 1, 1, 6, 1.
cuniousw=n—pres. not fut. Cf. v. 59, 5, 71, 1.
lo/gia—a general term for all words, whether prose or verse, supposed to be ominous. Probably old stories of strange things in the past are here meant Pind Pyth. 1, 92.

e)le/geto—in other places the plur. verb appears after a neut. sing. (see not. crit.), viz.: I. 126, 5 e)ph=lqon *)olu/mpia (where CEG read e)ph=lqen); v. 75, 2 *karnei=a e)tu/gxanon
o)/nta: though elsewhere names of festivals have the sing.; v. 26, 2 a(marth/mata e)ge/nonto; VI. 62, 4 e)ge/nonto e(kato\n ta/lanta. Ita rarus est hic plur, numeri usus apud veteres scriptores Atticos, ut fere suspiceris librariorum errores esse e Byzantinorum sermone illatos, Herw.
polla\ de\—i.e. xrhsmoi/, which are collected and interpreted by xrhsmolo/goi. h)=don—contrasted with e)/le/geto, since the xrhsmoi\ were in verse; ‘recited.’ Cf. c. 54, 2. So cano often.
*dh=los e)kinh/qh—the centre of the Ionian race, which by its unique ki/nhsis foreshadowed an equally unique ki/nhsis of all Greece. Cf. I. 1, 2.
ou)/pw—either Thuc. did not know of Herod. VI. 98, or he ignores it.
e)pi\—‘in view of.’ c. 36, 4.
shmh=nai—intrans., shmei=on ei)=nai. Cf. c. 43, 3, 49, 7.
a)nezhtei=to—cf. VIII. 33, 4. Bloomf. quotes Aristoph. Lys. 28 pra=gm' a)nezhthme/non, pollai=sin a)grupni/aisin e)rriptasme/non.
e)poi/ei e)s—a)nti\ tou= eu)noikw=s ei)=xon Schol. Mira locutio, says Herw. The phrase is only found here in Attic, but is imitated by late writers.

proeipo/ntwn—cf. c. 5, 5; M.T. 850; and for Latin, Riemann, S.L. § 263; a convenient use of the gen. abs., in spite of the proximity of another case, to make a fresh predication without a new sentence. Cf. c. 83, 3; I. 114, 1; III. 13, 6, 22, 1.

e)leuqerou=sin—the claim continually put forward by S., that she was a Liberator. She traded on the insane craving for au)tonomi/a, the evil spirit by which the Greeks were possessed. A wanton abuse of terms must lead to disaster, and after misusing the word Freedom for a century, Greece ‘buried her Liberty’ on the field of Chaeronea.

kai\ lo/gw| kai\ e)/rgw|—sive ... sive. There are some 50 cases of this antithesis between l. and e)/. in Thuc., which is not surprising considering that (1) great importance was attached to words at Athens, apart from their truth or falsity; (2) Thuc. had but too good reason to contrast the professions of men with their deeds during the war. The antithesis underlies all diplomacy. The opening of the Funeral Oration, c. 35, is a contrast of lo/gos and e)/rgon. Cf. c. 40, 1, 41, 2, 4, 42, 2, 4, 43, 1, 2, 46, 1, 65, 9, 72, 1, 81, 2.

e)n tou/tw| ... w(=|—‘in any enterprise in which he did not take part.’ w(=| depends on pare/stai, as in I. 22 oi(=s au)to\s parh=n. kekwlu=sqai—i.e. kekw/lutai ei) mh\ au)to\s pare/somai, the perfect being used of something bound to happen in the future if the condition is fulfilled. Livy XXI. 43, 2 vicimus for vicerimus. Cf. IV. 46, 3 w(/st' e)a/n tis a(lw=| a)podidra/skwn, a(/pasi lelu/sqai ta\s sponda/s. The description of the friends of Sparta is not without a touch of sarcasm.
<e)n> o)rgh=| ei)=xon—c. 59, 2.
a)rxqw=si—ingressive, ‘become subjects.’

fobou/menoi—the government of Sparta kept all its proceedings too secret for them to know the true
nature of the Spartan oligarchy, which was to conduct them in many cases from democracy to decarchy.
paraskeuh=| ... kai\ gnw/mh|—c. 7 and 8 are resumed by a chiasmus (see analysis of 7, 8).
w(/rmhnto—‘made ready for war.’ Cf. I. 32, 5.

*lak, me
 ... *pe/l. me
 ... e)/cw de\ *)aq. de/—the extremes and the means are contrasted, as usually with this double use of me
 ... de/. *peloponnh/sioi—in the geographical sense, the dwellers in Peloponnese of whatever stock.

[oi( e)nto\s *)isqmou=]—usually in Thucydides *peloponnh/sioi means ‘the allies of Sparta.’ In c. 11 indeed, Archidamus is made to address the officers as *pel. kai\ cu/mmaxoi, i.e. as politically connected and as comrades in arms, but, after that it is generally taken for granted that all the allies are included in the term *pel. But before the war, *peloponnh/sioi means ‘the inhabitants of Peloponnese,’ and only in this sense can the Argives and Achaeans be included in the term. If oi( e)nto\s is in the text, the P. of Peloponnese are contrasted with those P. outside it (*peloponnh/sioi e)/cw *peloponnh/sou), i.e. *pel. must mean ‘the allies of Sparta,’ which is impossible.
*pellhnh=s—near Zougra. Pellene seems to have been connected politically with Sicyon (10 miles) and Phlius (14 miles) rather than with Achaea.
e)/peita de\ u(/steron—cf. III. 94, 1; IV. 102, 2; v. 61, 4. In 417 the Lacedaemonians became more closely connected with Achaea. See v. 82, 1.

e)/cw de\ *p.—on the land side, Athens was wedged in between enemies. This both exposed her to invasion and hampered her own undertakings. It was with a view to breaking up this hostile combination that Demosthenes undertook the expedition into Aetolia in 427.
*lokroi/—the Opuntian Locrians, with the Epicnemidian, whereas the Ozolian Locrians were allies of Athens.
nautiko\n—scarcely anything was done by S. with the fleet in the 1st year. Intr. p. LXXII.
*kori/nqioi—for their naval operations, see c. 33, 80, 3, 83. *megarh=s—c. 92. *sikuw/nioi—c. 80, 3.
*)amprakiw=tai—c. 80. [parei=xon]— Intr. p. XXXIX.

au(/th—the omission of me\n here and in I. 125, 1. in both of which C inserts me/n, raises a difficulty. Elsewhere it is left out only when a participle prevents its use, as in the opening of c. 65, 72, 75. It is possible that au(/th *lak. cummaxi/a is inserted wrongly from 6 below. (This omission is not similar to that noticed above, c. 7, 1.)
*xi=oi, *le/sbioi— the only islands on the Aegean then retaining the position of independent allies of Athens.

e)n *naupa/ktw|—placed there by Athens at the close of the third Messenian War. See
c. 27, 2.
oi( plei/ous—Astacus (c. 30) and Oeniadae (c. 102) did not join Athens.
a)/llai—‘and other cities (besides the au)to/nomoi cu/mmaxoi just mentioned), namely.’

*kari/a—the e)/qnh are added in the nom., in spite of the dat. preceding, because these are the four financial divisions of the po/leis u(potelei=s, so that the nominatives are as much in apposition with po/leis as with e)/qnesi. *kari/a ... pro/soikoi—called in the tribute lists o( *kariko\s fo/ros, and so *)iwni/a = o( *)iwniko/s, *(ellh/spontos = o( *(ellhspo/ntios, ta\ e)pi\ *q. = o( e)pi\ *q. f., nh=soi ... *qh/ras = o( nhsiwtiko\s f. From 436 B.C. Ionia and Caria were grouped together.
*karsi\ pro/soikoi—for the omission of oi( cf. c. 85, 5. It is explained by the fact that this is an official title, Kr. Gr. Gr. 50, 2, 11.
nh=soi...pa=sai ai( a)/llai —for o(/sos Iimited by plh/n, cf. IV. 32, 2, and for oi\ a)/lloi V. 27, 2.
*mh/lou kai\ *qh/ras—both colonized by the Dorians about the time of their settlement in Crete, circ. 1100 B.C.
nautiko\n—this was a privilege belonging only to the independent allies. Cf. Intr. p. LXXIV. They were au)totelei=s.
cummaxi/a—abstract for concrete.
kai\ paraskeuh\ —the chapter is summarised in inverse order, as in c. 7, 8.
perih/ggellon—often takes the construction of keleu/w but with the dat., which keleu/w never has.
ta/ te e)pith/deia —sc. paraskeua/zesqai. oi(=a ei)ko\s—quae deceret.

w(s e)sbalou=ntes—because Athens was exposed to attack from the Isthmus. The corresponding Athenian incursion was merely into the Megarid; but Athens was unable to strike at Sparta herself directly. For the system adopted in consequence, see Intr. p. LXIX.
e(toi=ma—not with e)pith/deia, but as in c. 3, 4, 98, 1.
gi/gnoito—iterative; hence cunh=|san imperf.

ta\ du/o me/rh— the denominator exceeding the numerator by 1 is invariably omitted. Contrast tw=n pe/nte ta\s du/o moi/ras I. 10. ta\ d. me/rh is in limiting apposition to the subject of cunh=|san. Cf. c. 47, 2.
tou\s . . a)ciologwta/tous—an indefinite expression, suited to the different circumstances and arrangements of the various contingents.
a)ciologwta/tous—forming one group with tou\s e)n te)lei, but not identical with them. Cf. I. 10 ta\s megi/stas kai\ e)laxi/stas.

a)/ndres—Thuc. shows exquisite judgment in selecting the places in which to insert speeches. They are the occasions on which it is necessary for the reader to understand the exact situation of affairs and to realise what were the infiuences at work. They stand in place of explanation
and abstract reasoning. The occasions selected for this purpose in this book are (a) the first invasion of Attica (this speech shows the feelings of the Spartans); (b) the close of the first campaign (the Funeral Oration is an exposition of the form and theory of the Athenian polity by the ablest citizen); (c) the close of Pericles' administration and life, the speech containing a vindication of his policy; (d) the victories of Phormio, the one event of great importance outside Athens in 429, and the most splendid example of Athenian prowess in the whole war. Dion. Hal. totally misunderstood the significance of the speeches. Far juster is Lucian's estimate (pw=s dei= i(stori/an suggra/fein c. 44): he knew that Thuc.'s object was safw=s dhlw=sai kai\ fanw/tata e)mfani/sai ta\ pra/gmata.
[oi(] —inserted through confusion with oi( pate/res. Thuc. never puts in the article in such addresses.
cu/mmaxoi—there are two elements in the force, but Archidamus groups them together, and carefully draws no distinctions. a)/ndres goes with cu/mmaxoi also.
kai\ oi( p. . kai\ au)tw=n—paratactic, the 2nd member being the more prominent.
oi( pate/res—an opportune reference to the wars which were the glory of the Dorian race. Thuc. however avoids any commonplaces about the Persian wars such as become frequent in later writers.

stratei/as e)poih/santo— = e)stra/teusan. h(mw=n oi( presbu/teroi ei)si/n—with the ‘partitive’ genitive 1st or 2nd person, the verb is generally in 3rd person, but the writer always passes quickly to the 1st or 2nd. Cf. III. 62 ske/yasqe e)n oi(/w| ei)/dei e(ka/teroi h(mw=n tou=to e)/pracan. VII. 64 e)nqumei=sqe o(/ti oi( e)n tai=s nausi\n u(mw=n nu=n e)so/menoi kai\ pezoi\ toi=s *)aqhnai/ois ei)si\ kai\ nh=es. So I. 87. When for the subject a relative clause is substituted, the 3rd person is rare: e.g. Andoc. I. 46 o(po/soi u)mw=n parh=san (= oi( paro/ntes) a)namimnh/skesqe. Lys. 12, 97, Aeschin. 3, 60. The same phenomenon may be seen in Latin poets, as Ov. Trist.III. 4, 75 et qua quisque potest aliqua mala nostra levate.
mei/zona—litotes, as plei=stoi shows.

nu=n e)rxo/meqa—sc. h(mei=s, whereas oi( pate/res kai\ oi( presbu/teroi was subject to e)ch/lqomen. strateu/ontes—sc. e)rxo/meqa, the antithesis being between po/lin and au)toi/, dunatwta/thn and plei=stoi kai\ a)/ristoi strateu/ontes.
di/kaion ou)=n—the topic is to\ kalo/n, as in 9 below. Index s. v. to/poi. It is a common subject in Thuc., especially in military harangues.
h(mw=n au)tw=n—put first for the sake of the antithesis. See c. 7, 2.

e)ph=rtai—cf. Dem. 4, 49 toi=s pepragme/nois e)ph|rme/non. eu)/noian e)/xousa—with infin. = e)piqumou=sa, as c. 86, 5 gnw/mhn ei)=xon mh\ e)kplei=n. A periphrasis for a simple verb is very common in Tragedy.
ou)/koun xrh\—the topic of the pi/stis is to\ cumfe/ron, as the Schol. says. It is the commonest of all forms of argument in Thuc.
plh/qei—of superior numbers, as c. 89, 1.
a)sfa/leia pollh\—opposite of ki/ndunos me/gas, but, being an abstract idea, and not, like ki/ndunos, a single entity, it requires pollh/. Cf. VI. 24. So with proqumi/a, a)qumi/a and such words.

ei)=nai —sc. dokei=. mh\ a)/n e)lqei=n—after the predicative noun a)sfa/leia, like ki/ndunos, cuggnwmh/. dia\ ma/xhs i)e/nai—cf. 6 below; IV. 92, 1. So dia\ di/khs i)e/nai VI. 60, 3; di' o)/xlou ei)=nai I. 73, 2; dia\ fo/bou ei)=nai VI. 59, 2; di' hsuxi/as e)/xein c. 22, 1.
a)mele/stero/n ti—cf. 9 below ple/on ti. By the addition of ti the range of the adjective is indefinitely extended.
to\ kaq' au(to\n—suam quemque vicem. Cf. c. 87, 8. The subject of h(/cein is h(gemo/na kai\ s.

a)/dhla ga\r—Thuc. is extremely fond of gnw=mai or general truths as arguments, whereas he does not use paradei/gmata or examples at all. The gnw=mai have been collected by several critics, and, as might be supposed, they show a profound insight into the fundamental principles that actually guide human conduct.
e)c o)li/gou—‘suddenly.’
di' o)rgh=s— ‘on impulse.’
ai( e)pixeirh/seis gi/gnontai—the passive of ta\s e)pi. poiei=sqai I. 70, 7.
te—adds a third and important fact. [

dedio\s a)/meinon]—
1. dedio\s obscures the point, which is that a large force, caught off its guard, has often been defeated by a small force. There is no room here for any reference to the apprehension or precautions of the smaller force.
2. No passage supports the idea that Archidamus is pointing out the advantage of de/os in action, e)n tw=| a)mu/nesqai. It is then too late for de/os, which is valuable only e)n tw=| paraskeua/zesqai.
3. The assumption that dedio\s is answered by dia\ to\ katafronou=ntas ... gene/sqai is not borne out by the form of the sentence.
4. Archidamus merely says ‘do not be careless, lest you be caught unprepared.’ 5. Of a)/meinon there are two explanations
(a) = a)/meinon h)\ oi( plei/ones to\ e)/lasson plh=qos. But h)mu/nanto is used only of the side on the defensive; nor is there any reference to superiority in courage such as a)gaqo/s suggests.
(b) a)/meinon dedio\s h)\ mh\ dedio/s, Cl., a curious paradox worthy only of a rhetorician.Append. II.
h)mu/nato—gnomic. Cf. c. 89 polla\ strato/peda h)/dh e)/pesen u(po\ e)lasso/nwn.
xrh\ de\—a gnw/mh in the form of an antithesis. For ‘figures’ in gnw=mai, cf. c. 40 throughout.

th=| me\n gnw/mh| ... tw=| de\ e)/rgw|—an imperfect antithesis. gnw/mh means ‘feelings,’ e)/rgon ‘actions’ (not gnw/mh ‘plans,’ e)/rgon ‘battle’). Cf. c. 43, 3, 64. 6, and 89 th= duna/mei to\ ple/on pi/sunoi h)\ th=? gnwmh?. Herod. VII. 49 a)nh\r ou(/tw a)/n ei)/h a)/ristos ei) bouleuo/menos me\n a)rrwde/oi e)n de\ tw=| e)/rgw| qrasu\s ei)/h—which is however somewhat different.

paraskeua/zesqai—the reading is now commonly pareskeua/sqai. Cr. says ‘le parfait est nécessaire,’ but gives the present. The perfect is due to a mistaken interpretation of gnw/mh| and e)/rgw|,
the latter of which refers to the period before battle. The antithesis between strateu/ein and paraskeua/zesqai must not be too closely pressed. (A quite different view of this passage will be found in Steup, Quaest. Thuc. p. 30.)

pro\s to\ e)pie/nai eu)yuxo/tatoi—cf. III. 44, 3 cumfe/ron pro\s to\ h(=sson a)fi/stasqai; VIII. 76, 6. The use of the infinitive with article in all constructions is far commoner in the speeches and the passages in the rhetorical manner than in ordinary narrative.

e)pixeirei=sqai—‘to be attacked.’ This sentence puts in the proper light the two points referred to in 3 above: so plh/qei e)pie/nai has become eu)yuxo/tatoi e)pie/nai, a)sfa/leia mh\ a)\n e)pixeirei=sqai has become a)sfa/leia pro\s to\ e)pixeirei=sqai. eu)yuxo/tatoi e)pie/nai results from to\ qarsale/ous strateu/ein, a)sfa/leia pro\s to\ e)pixeirei=sqai from to\ dedio/tas paraskeua/zesqai.
ou(/tw—with a)du/naton. toi=s pa=si—cf. c. 36, 3.

ei) mh\ kai\ nu=n—‘if not already ... at least.’ I see no need to alter the text with Francken, or to assume a misplacement of kai/. For a)lla/, a)lla\ ... ge/, a)ll' ou)=n ... ge, see Kr. Gr. Gr. 69, 4, 5.
o(/tan o(rw=si—usually in Thuc. o(/tan denotes a single act, o(po/tan repeated action. I. 142, 9 is an exception.
ta)kei/nwn—for ta\ e(autw=n, as e)kei=nos can apply to anyone other than the speaker and the person addressed.
fqei/rontas— cf. Livy XXII. 3 Flaminius postquam res sociorum ante oculos prope suos agi ferrique vidit.

pa=si ga\r—the only possible way of taking these words as they stand is the traditional way of Arn., Shil., and Bh., which is supported by A. Grossman, N. Jahrb. 121, p. 523. e)n toi=s o)/mmasi kai\ e)n tw=| parauti/ka are taken after o(ra=n, the infinitive is made to depend on the phrase o)rgh\ prospi/ptei, as though it were lupei=, and o(ra=n pa/sxontas = ‘to see that they are suffering.’ There are grave objections: o(ra=n pa/sxontas would more naturally mean ‘to see others suffering,’ and it is very doubtful whether o)rgh\ prospi/ptei can be considered a periphrasis which could legitimately take an infinitive in prose. Usener proposes pa=si ga\r e)n tw=| parauti/ka o(ra=n pa/sxonta/s ti a)hqe/s, taking e)n tw=| with o(ra=n pa/sxontas. Cf. Steup's proposal in not. crit.

ga\r—this introduces the gnw/mh by which the statement that ‘the Athenians will come out to battle’ is supported. We have here an example of the form of proof called Enthymeme, i.e. a ‘syllogism drawn, not from the premisses proper to any particular science—such, for instance, as medicine—but from propositions relating to contingent things in the sphere of human action, which are the common property of all discussion.’ Jebb, Attic Orators II. p. 289. Cf. c. 60. kai\ logismw=|—i.e. ‘and then men do not pause to think.’ Possibly oi( bracketed represents a lost oi( toiou=toi, = oi( o)rgisqe/ntes. qumw=|—also, like logismw=|, with xrw/menoi.

*)aqhnai/ous—this view of Athenian character is that of Thuc. himself. He began the description of it in the first speech of the Corinthian envoy at Sparta (I. 70) and completes it in the Funeral Oration (c. 35 fol.).
ple/on ti—cf. III. 45, 6, 69, 2; IV. 78, 5; V. 29, 2; VI. 90, 1; VII. 21, 4, 49, 4. For ti with comparative, see 3 above. ma=llo/n ti is commoner in this sense.
tw=n a)/llwn—often e(te/rwn in this idiom.

ei)ko\s—decet, with aorist infinitive, as regularly (sometimes present, c. 10, 1). Rutherford, Syntax, p. 128. The argument is now drawn from to\ ei)ko/s. An orator naturally employs this topic to prove something in the past, but Thuc. to forecast the future. Index s.v. to/poi. tou=to dra=sai—the regular phrase for referring to an action just deseribed. Cf. c. 49, 5; I. 5, 2, 6, 5. Of course Thuc. refers to the actual indignation of the Athenians at seeing their land ravaged. See c. 21, 2. It was a source of great pride that the beautiful country of Attica had never been plundered plh\n ta\ *mhdika/. Cf. Eur. Med. 826—the play was produced this very year— where the Athenians are addressed as i(era=s xw/ras a)porqh/tou t' a)poferbo/menoi. o(ra=n—sc. dh|oume/nhn.
do/can e)p' a)mfo/tera—kai\ eu)klei/as kai\ dusklei/as Schol.

oi)so/menoi—cf. c. 60 ai)ti/an fe/resqai. toi=s progo/nois—we should refer to posterity, but the ancients thought far more of the worship due to their ancestors, the qeoi\ xqo/nioi. On the excessive reverence of the Greeks for the past (from which Thuc. was remarkably free), Girard, Essai sur Thuc., p. 13, says ‘Les Grecs ne songeaient qu'aà chercher dans cet âge merveilleux leurs titres de noblesse et à y rettacher étroitement le présent.’

u(mi=n au)toi=s—corrected from h(mi=n au)toi=s with Hude, Comment. Crit., p. 109. e(/pesqe strongly supports him. ‘Nulla in re magis quam in pronominibus h(mei=s et u(mei=s permutandis librarios peccavisse satis constat.’
a)pobaino/ntwn—see c. 50, 2.
o)/cews dexo/menoi—cf. c. 89, 9.

ka/lliston kai\ a)sfale/staton—the identity of to\ kalo\n and to\ a)sfale\s has been the prevailing idea throughout the speech. It is an idea characteristic of Sparta that eu)nomi/a is ka/llos. Thus Spartan tradition did not object to Athens claiming the poet Tyrtaeus for her own, though the claim was probably unfounded; but took care that the lame Athenian singer should only develop into the warrior Tyrtaeus after settling in Sparta.
o)/ntas—the participle adds emphasis to pollou\s and heightens the contrast to e(ni/.
tosau=ta—haec tantum, the regular word after a short speech instead of toiau=ta. ei)/ ti a)/ra—c. 5, 1.
ti ma=llon—not for ma=llo/n ti, but ti belongs to e)ndoi=en, as below, ou)de\n e)ndwsei/ousi.
ou)d'—ou)de/, mhde/, sometimes as here = nedum ‘much less.’

to\ koino\n—the boulh\ and e)kklhsi/a. h)=n ... nenikhkui=a —except with this periphrasis in the perfect passive and middle forms, the tense of ei)mi\ must precede the participle, and is emphatic, representing a state of things existing at the time referred to, Cf. c. 67 h)=n ... poliorkou=n, 80 h)=san ... cumproqumou/menoi, 93 h)=n profula/sson. Then the participle often resembles an adjective.
kh/ruka ... prosde/xesqai—a formal expression for breaking off all political relations. Cf. V, 80..
e)kto\s o(/rwn—without article, as a local expression, akin to e)n a)/stei. Rutherford, Syntax, p. 4.
to\ loipo\n— with presbeu/esqai. a)naxwrh/santas—i.e. retire before thinking of sending any more. The participle is emphatic.
dialu/sesqai—‘part from his escort.’
toso/nde— ‘merely this.’
o(/ti—this convenient form of quasi-oblique speech, where the speaker's actual words follow o(/ti, is colloquial and limited to prose.
h(/de h( h(me/ra—Aristoph. Pax 435 eu)xo/mesqa th\n nu=n h(me/ran *(/ellhsin a)/rcai pa=si pollw=n ka)gaqw=n. Verg. Aen. IV. 169 ille dies primus leti, primusque malorum causa fuit.
e)/gnw—ingressive, ‘learnt.’
e)ndwsei/ousi—though Cobet and Sta. reject this, it is more probable than e)ndw/sousi, since pw is not used with future, and Archidamus' object was to find out what the Athenians were now intending.
ou(/tw dh\—like to/te dh/, gives the decisive moment. Cf. c. 19.
me/ros—of infantry. So the Boeotians did not supply cavalry only. See c. 9, 3.
leipome/nois—for the present, see c. 2, 4.

e)n o(dw=| o)/ntwn—cf. c. 12, 1 and 2, but referring here to the march not of the various contingents to the Isthmus, but of the whole force from the Isthmus. Several meetings of the Ecclesia were held.

*periklh=s—O. Drefke, de orat. quae in priore parte Historiae Thuc. insunt, suggests that Thuc. probably intended to insert a speech here, but changed his mind on finding the subject unsuitable for readers. He thinks that we have here the notes Thuc. had made at the time, which assumption would explain the loose structure of the Oratio Obliqua throughout. Cf. c. 72. de/katos au)to\s—the view of Gilbert, that this phrase means that Pericles was strathgo\s au)tokra/twr, i.e. was irresponsible and had full powers to do anything he deemed necessary, is now generally accepted. Pericles held the same position in the war with Samos 440 B.C.

mh\ polla/kis—as though u(potoph/sas were fobhqei/s. Cf. III. 53, 2 u(popteu/omen mh\ ou) koinoi\ a)pobh=te. polla/kis—forte, a sense which it bears only after ei), e)a/n, mh/. mh\ dhw/sh|—should be ou) dhw/sh|. This very rare irregularity is
only possible when the second negative is far removed from the first. M. T. 306.
e)pi\ diabolh|=—the same thing was done by Hannibal to cast odium on Fabius, Livy, xxii. 23, 4. For the order, see c 2, 2.
tou=to ge/nhtai—c. 11, 8.
prohgo/reue—above proei=pon. The rule about compounds of le/gw and a)goreu/w will be found in Rutherford's New Phryn. p. 326.
oi(—the only form of the indirect reflexive singular found in Thuc. and the orators, and rare in them.
e)pi\ kakw=|—the same phrase in V. 44, 3, 77, 6; VIII. 58, 3, 4.
ge/noito—sc. tou=to, as ge/nhtai tou=to above.
tou\s a)grou\s kai\ oi)ki/as—the article not repeated, the two nouns forming one idea between them (viz. the idea th\n fanera\n ou)si/an). Cf. c. 10, 3.
a)fi/hsin—does not depend on prohgo/reue, but is used for a/fie/nai fhsi/n (which is possibly what Thuc. wrote), just as we might say ‘he gives the land’ for ‘he undertakes to give it.’
ei)=nai—like the use of ei)=nai in Homer and Herod., expressing purpose, but redundant. M. T. 774.

gi/gnesqai —this is like the use of the infinitive in the terms of a treaty or any compact. It is in origin probably identical with the so-called infinitive for imperative. But this may be oblique for mhdemi/a moi u(poyi/a gigne/sqw. In any case, Pp.'s explanation, supplying bou/letai, is without doubt wrong. The sentence is probably a note Thuc. wrote in these very words at the time.
parh/|nei de\—cf. V. 38, 2 parh/|noun gene/sqai o(/rkous. kai\ pro/teron—I. 143. ta\ e)k tw=n a). e)skomi/zesqai—cf. c. 5, 7.

e)/s te ma/xhn—the ancient critics noticed that polysyndeton is common in Thuc. There are three main members here, each introduced by te, paraskeua/zesqai/ te ... e)/s te ... ta/ te, and the first two are complicated by an additional member, which however does not affect the main structure, viz. kai\ ... e)skomi/zesqai, a)lla\ e)cartu/esqai. mh\ e)pecie/nai—Intr. p. lxix.

th
 po/lin e)selqo/ntas fula/ssein— cf IV. 70 th
 po/lin e)selqw
 bebaiw/sasqai. When a participle and verb which have different constructions take a common object, the object regularly follows the construction required by the participle, as in I. 114, 2 e)s *)eleusi=na kai\ *qriw=ze e)sbalo/ntes e)dh/|wsan, IV 18 dou=nai e)f' a)\ a/figme/noi u(ma=s ai)tou/meqa, VII. 3, 4 me/ros ti pe/myas pro\s to\ frou/rion ai(rei=, ib. 53, 2 prospeso/ntes toi=s prw/tois tre/pousi. But there is here no need to take th
 po/lin with e)selqo/ntas at all.
dia\ xeiro\s e)/xein— the opposite of a)nie/nai, I 76 a)rxh\n a)nie/nai. So Livy XXI. 35, 9 in manu habere. xei\r means ‘control.’ Eur. Hec. 986. Cf. the legal sense of manus. See also c. 76, 4.

le/gwn ... ei)=nai—a rare construction—c. 57, 1. a)po\ tou/twn ei)=nai tw=n xr. th=s proso/dou—i.e. th\n i)sxu\n th=s proso/dou tw=n xrhma/twn a)po\ tou/twn ( = tw=n cumma/xwn) ei)=nai. Cf. III. 13, 6 e)/sti tw=n xrhma/twn a/po\ tw=n cumma/xwn h( pro/sodos. This sentence must
not be pruned, for th=s proso/dou defines the nature of i)sxu/n, and tw=n xrhma/twn is caught up presently by xrhma/twn again: the insertion of tw=n xrhma/twn is stylistic.
ta\ polla\ .. kratei=sqai—‘most successes are won.’

gnw/mh| —‘insight,’ not put in at hap-hazard, but summing up in a word paraskeua/zesqai to e)cartu/esqai. It is on the policy here sketched that Pericles rested his claims to be possessed of gnw/mh, or, as Thuc. says in c. 65 pro/noia. To supply gnw/mh was the statesman's part, to supply xrh/mata the subjects'.

e(cakosi/wn—in I. 96 we see that under Aristides' administration the fo/ros amounted to 460 talents. In the lists of the quota paid to Athene for 450 and 446 B.C., the tribute of some States is seen to be reduced, and the total was probably made up by payments from new subjects. But the tribute was in some cases subsequently raised, so that 600 talents may represent the average (w(s e) ti\ to\ polu\) in 431.
fo/rou—for this genitive of material, cf. a)rguri/ou below. See Rutherford, Syntax, p. 35.
a)po\ tw=n cum—the origin (a)po\) from which money is obtained. Cf. Aristoph. Vesp. 670 dwrodokou=sin a)po\ tw=n po/lewn (rightly defended by Sobolewski, de praepos. usu Aristoph.).

a)/neu—this is the ordinary meaning of xwri\s as a preposition in Attic, but Thuc. only uses xwri\s as an adverb. The opposite of su\n (toi=s) qeoi=s (see c. 2, 1) is a)/neu (tw=n) qew=n. The opposite of su\n in its other Attic sense in totals, is usually xwri/s. The opposite of meta/ is a)/neu, and more rarely xwri/s (thus Isocrates has two cases, but in both xwri/s, not a)/neu, is used to avoid hiatus).

th=s a)/llhs proso/dou—as rents from public lands, especially the silver mines, the tax paid by resident aliens and by owners of slaves, duties on imports exports and sales, and court fees and fines, amounting in all to at least 400 talents.
e)n th=| a)kropo/lei— in the Opisthodomus of the Parthenon.
e)ge/neto—‘amounted to.’ Cf. c. 20, 4.
ta\ propu/laia—begun 437, completed 432.
ta)=lla—the Odeum, Parthenon and the sculpture on the buildings was paid for out of this fund.

e)s *potei/daian —from first to last the siege cost 2000 talents. It began in the autumn of 433, ended in the winter of 430. Probably Thuc. omits in that sum the expense of Hagnon's expedition (c. 58), which cost 400 talents more.
*xwri\s—‘besides.’ Cf. c. 24, 31, 97. xrusi/ou— depends on tala/ntwn below.
o(/sa—sc. e)sti/. So c. 9, 4, 97 peri/—‘used in.’
sku=la *mhdika\—sc. o(/sa e)sti/, but this might have been e)n sku/lois *mhdikoi=s. The throne of Xerxes and the sabre of Mardonius (Medus acinaces) were among them.

ou)k e)/lasson h)\ p. tala/ntwn—cf. IV. 72 paro/ntos tou= strateu/matos, o(plitw=n ou)k e)/lasson e(cakisxili/wn. The genitive
of comparison does not follow e)/lasson here, because tala/ntwn is already in the genitive absolute, sc. u(parxo/ntwn from above.
*ta\ e)k tw=n a)/llwn i(erw=n—i.e. in temples other than the Parthenon. The temple treasures were of great value.

xrh/mata—no doubt Pericles explained the details, whieh he must have known thoroughly after his long tenure of the Generalship, in which he had distinguished himself in Finauce. In this respect he was imitated by many popular leaders who followed him, and, as the war went on, Finance became the most pressing difficulty.

oi(=s xrh/sesqai—cf. c. 102 le/getai ... o(/te dh\ a)la=sqai. This attraction of short relative clauses in Oratio Obliqua into infinitive is less rare in Greek than in Latin (of course qui = et is etc. is different). Thuc. has nine instances.
th=s qeou=—i.e. the statue of Athene. Both in Greek and Latin the name of the person represented is used for the statue itself, as Victoria aurea.
staqmo\n —predicate.
xrusi/ou a).—with ta/lanta. a)pe/fqou—i.e. without alloy.

periaireto\n ei)=nai—sc. e)/fh. mh\ e)la/ssw— often during the war money was borrowed from the i(era\ xrh/mata. The loans were repaid with interest at a low rate, which Pericles probably proposed at this time.
*trisxili/ous kai\ m.—cf. c. 31, 2. 10,000 were on the spot, 3000 at Potidaea.

tw=n e)n toi=s frouri/ois—the garrisons of Attica were supplied mainly from the peri/poloi, young Athenians between 18 and 20 years old. At 18 their age was entered in the lhciarxiko\n grammatei=on, list of the members of the deme capable of arms kept by the demarch. Not till 20 was a man entitled to attend the Ecclesia. The peri/poloi regularly served in Attica.

e)/palcin—eollective. See c. 4, 2. Again the article dropped with a word approximating to a proper name, in prepositional phrases. The line of fortified walls of Athens and Piraeus, including the long walls, is meant. The citizens who manned these were drawn from the presbu/tatoi, those excused by age from serving outside Attica. Legally this age was 60, but in practice it could be, and probably was, reduced.
newta/twn—the peri/poloi.

*tou= *falhrikou=—begun under Themistocles with to\ e)/cwqen (tei=xos), which ran to Piraeus. Under Pericles, about 445, a third wall, to\ dia\ me/sou was built between these two, running to Munychia.
h)=san—were, according to Pericles' narrative.
to\n ku/klon tou= a)/stews—the walls of Athens.
a)fu/lakton h)=n—about 6 stadia: so that the city walls, as rebuilt after Salamis, were about 50 stadia in circumference.
tou= te makrou= = tou= e)/cwqen. ta\ makra\ tei/xh—namely to\ e)/cwqen, the earlier wall, and to\ dia\ me/sou tei=xos, called ta\ ske/lh.
stadi/wn—genitive of description, almost confined to expressions of magnitude. Cf. c. 23, 3.
*cu\n i(ppotoco/tais—including (cu\n) the 200 mounted archers, state slaves who served as police, as did the 1200 *sku/qai who are included in the 1600 toco/tai below.
trih/reis ta\s p.—see c. 2, 2.

triakosi/ous—in III. 17 we read that 250 ships were employed on active service at the beginning of the war. (As the details there given do not correspond with those given in this book with regard to the fleet in 431, the text is probably wrong in III. 17.)
*)es a)po/deicin tou= perie/sesqai—cf. c. 56 e)s e)lpi/da h)=lqon tou= e(lei=n, and for the rare future infinitive with article, I. 144, 1.
tw=| pole/mw|—the dative is temporal. Cf. c. 20 e)kei/nh| th=| e)sbolh=?. It is however rarely that e)n is omitted with a noun used temporally which is not properly temporal.

*)anepei/qonto—both the compound and the tense denote the difficulty of convincing them. Cf. c. 65, 1. Even now they did not feel quite certain, and were liable to change their minds again. (It was do/ca resulting from peiqw/, not e)pisth/mh resulting from ma/qhsis.)
th\n a)/llhn—perhaps the exclusive a/llos, but kataskeuh/, stock, may here include children and wives. See c. 5, 4.
kat' oi)=kon—see on c. 60, 4.
cu/lwsin—materia; several verbal nouns in -is are peculiar to Thuc. Cf. o)lo/fursis c. 51. Pollux and the Schol. regard this one as coined by Thuc.
kaqairou=ntes—this and e)sekomi/zonto both govern cu/lwsin. e)pikeime/nas—‘off the coast.’
*xalepw=s ... e)gi/gneto—passive for xalepw=s th\n a). e)poiou=nto. a)na/stasis—an unwilling (metana/stasis, a willing) removal from one's country.

*)epi\ ga\r—now follows one of the few episodes in Thuc., who never leaves his subject except to comment on some epoch of Athenian history either throwing light on the circumstances he is relating, or imperfectly understood in his day.

kata\ po/leis—cf. the condition of Sparta, referred to I. 10, 2. According to tradition, there were 12 po/leis in Attica; these had arisen by the increase and amalgamation of kw=mai. w)|kei=to—of the political condition of the district, as often.
prutanei=a—these bore the same relation to the community as the oi/ki/a did to the family. Hence the community entertained its guests there.
a)/rxontas—‘princes,’ some of whose names may have been immortalised in the names of Attic demes.
ou) cunh=|san—only common danger brought them together.

e)pole/mhsan—the war between Athens and Eleusis, given as an example of the early wars in Attica, was probably due to a quarrel about the frontier, which was the range of Mount Aegaleos, over which the Sacred Way after
wards ran. Whatever the result, the position of Athens in the Dodecapolis was certainly raised by the war.

*qhseu\s—probably the legend of the coming of Theseus to Athens represents a second Ionic invasion of Attica, to which the strife between Athene and Poseidon, who is identical with Aegeus, father of Theseus, also points. See Plut. Thes. c. 13.
e)basi/leuse—‘became king.’ Cf. c. 58 nosh=sai, ‘to fall sick.’
meta\ tou= cunetou=—i.e. uniting power to the ability which he had already.

katalu/sas ... a)podei/cas ... cunw/|kise—the first participle precedes the second in time, and the second gives the action which resulted immediately in that of the main verb. Cf. c. 76 a)rth/santes ... a)nelku/santes a)fi/esan, 93 a)fikome/nous ... kaqelku/santas pleu=sai. cuntelou/ntwn—‘contributed to it,’ in taxes, hence ‘were members of the community.’
cunoi/kia—neuter plural, the annual festival celebrating the Union, held on the 16th of Hecatombaeon. Plut. Thes. c. 24.
poiou=sin—active not middle, of the body appointing the festival, cf. c. 34, 5.

*(h a)kro/polis—i.e. h(\ a)kro/polis nu=n e)sti po/lis h)=n, the city was a mere stronghold. ‘What is now the acropolis, and the ground lying under it to the south was the city’ (J.). (The bracked h( would imply a contrast with some older acropolis.) The same observation is true of London and Paris.
pro\s tetramme/non—here in its literal sense, but oftener metaphorical, as in c. 25, 2; Plat. Phaedo, p. 66 D.

*tekmh/rion de/—Thuc. disregards the Athenian legends, as suited only to poetry. Deposing the picturesque and enthroning the reasonable, he judges the remote past solely hy the indisputable evidence supplied by the present. For the use of tekmh/ria and shmei=a, non-forensic pi/steis like e)nqumh/mata (c. 11, 8) and gnw=mai (c. 11, 9), cf. 39, 2, 41, 2, 50, 2.

kai\ a)/llwn—the lost allusion to the most ancient temple of Athene, namely the shrine of Athene Polias attached to the Erectheum and containing the venerable wooden figure of the goddess (co/anon) and occupying the site of her struggle with Poseidon, would have been the best evidence that the original site of the city was the Acropolis.

ta\ e)/cw—the early temples not on the Acropolis lie at the south of it, viz. the Olympieium at the S.E., begun by Pisistratus, remarkable for its size, and only finished under Hadrian; the Pythium, or temple of Apollo patrw=|os, of which there are no remains, Pausanias says it was close to the Olympieium; the shrine of the Earth-Mother, situated within the te/menos of the Olympieium; and that of Dionysus in the low ground near the Ilissus. The Pisistratids probably did much to make these temples popular.

ta\ a)rxaio/tera—the Anthesteria, held in
Anthesterion (11th to 13th). The first day was called h( *piqoigi/a, the second *xo/es, the third *xu/troi. Aristoph. Ran. 215, Eur. I. T. 960, Harpoc. and Suidas s.v. xo/es. [
th=| dwdeka/th|]—gives one day only, and with it *)anqesthriw=nos mhno/s would be required. The date of the xo/es seems inserted from the same source from which Harpocration drew.
poiei=tai—passive of poiou=si, not of poiou=ntai. See 2 above, and c. 11, 4.
oi( a)p' *)a.—i.e. oi( a)/poikoi tw=n *)aqhnai/wn. nomi/zousi —‘are accustomed to do.’ Cf. 5 below, c. 38, 1.

*th=| krh/nh|—S. of the Olympieium, on the Ilissus. The Pisistratids furnished it with nine pipes and beautified it with columns. It was part of the Tyrants' policy to improve their cities and to encourage every form of art.
*kallirro/h| —the name still survives to show the early importance of this spring. See Ruskin, Oxford Lect. on Art, p. 136, Pausanias, I. 14, 1. [
ta\ plei/stou a)/cia]—Thuc. is arguing that in earlier times the spring was in general use.

pro\ gamikw=n— for the loutro\n gamiko/n, the water being brought from the spring by a maid called h( loutrofo/ros. Pollux III. 43, VIII. 66. But Harpoc. says that a boy brought it. e)s a)/lla—e)/qos h)=n kai\ tw=n a)ga/mwn a)poqano/ntwn loutrofo/ron e)pi\ to\ mnh=ma e)fi/stasqai Harpoc. Cf. Dem. in Leoch. 18, 30. Probably a figure holding a pitcher, which contained water from the spring, was placed on the tomb. Eustathius says the object was to show that the dead had never used the nuptial water.

nomi/zetai—‘it is the custom.’ The connection between the loutro
 gamiko
 and the loutro
 tw=n a)poqano/ntwn is as familiar as utraque taeda. In Eur. Hec. 612, the bringing of the water to wash the dead body of Polyxena snggests to Hecuba the loutro
 gamiko/n.
*katoi/khsin—c. 102, 5.
po/lis—this meaning is common in Inscriptions and official documents.
*th=| ... oi)kh/sei—causal, with geno/menoi kai\ oi)kh/santes. d' ou)=n—resumes from c. 14. e)pi\ polu\—temporal.
au)tono/mw|—independent of any capital.
kai\—‘even.’
o(/mws— answers kai\ and may be omitted in translating.
oi( plei/ous —restricting oi( *)aqhnai=oi. panoikesi/a| geno/menoi/ te kai\ oi)kh/santes—all go closely together, ‘having been born and having lived with their whole family.’

a)neilhfo/tes—having recovered from the effects of the Persian Invasion, when they had abandoned their homes. Not merely ‘had restored their homes,’ which took them only a short time. Cf. VI. 26, where it is said that Athens in 415 a)/rti a)neilh/fei e(auth\n a)po\ th=s no/sou kai\ tou= cunexou=s pole/mou.

*kata\ to\ a)rxai=on—lit. ‘according to early custom,’ ‘primitive,’ not to\ a)rxai=on ‘in early times,’ ‘ancient.’ The early po/lis was held together mainly as a religious union, with
its local cult.
a)polei/pwn—joined to preceding plural, and might have been a)polei/pontes. Cf. c. 65, 10.

*(gph=rxon—‘had homes ready to receive them.’ It appears that the whole of the country population was opposed to war. The rich landed gentry had town houses, but rarely lived in them and felt the loss of their fine country places. Cf. c. 65; Isocr. VII. 52. The farmers and peasants were ruined by the invasion. Cf. [Lys.] 20. 33.

*)eleusini/ou— at the foot of the Acropolis, at the N.E. It was regarded with great awe, and even in the time of Pausanias some mysterious sanctity belonged to it. The Boule sat there the day after the Eleusinian Festival ended.

to\ *pelargiko\n—(a) a fortification built by the ‘Pelasgians’ on the W. side of the Acropolis, the only side accessible to an enemy; (b) a space below this fortification and also above it. It is to this space on either side that the curse attached. (On the orthography, Herodian says, *pelargiko\n a)nti\ tou= *pelasgiko/n. Cf Lobeck, Phryn. p. 109.

e)pa/raton—what was the reason of this? Only the W. side was ‘cursed’ since only on that side could buildings be placed; but this space was part of the pomoerium of the original settlement, the Acropolis being then the te/menos of Pelasgian Zeus. Hence no human beings were to live there. mh\—due to the prohibition implied in e)pa/raton. toio/nde— i.e. mh\ oi)kei=n au)to/, the relative construction disappearing. See c. 4, 5.
*pelargiko\n a)rgo\n—such paronomasi/a is common in oracles. See c. 54, 2.
a)/meinon—a favourite word at Delphi, suiting well the oracle which worked by suggestion rather than command.
e)cw|kh/qh—‘was filled with settlers.’
*cumbh=nai—‘to have been fulfilled in a manner con- trary to their expectations,’ because the troubles were the cause instead of the result of the occupation.
h)\ prosede/xonto—Haase suggested h)\ {h(=|} prosede/xonto, but the relative may be omitted.

gene/sqai—sc. dokou=si from dokei= above. So Burke, Reflections, ‘In England we are said to learn manners at seeond-hand from your side of the water, and that we dress our behaviour in the frippery of France’ (i.e, it is said that we dress).
proh/|dei—i.e. warned them that the place would some day be inhabited in time of adversity.
