mh\ e)p' a)gaqw=|—after oi)=da the regular negative is ou). This mh\ implies a sense of authoritative declaration in oi)=da, and is not a colloquial license. M. T. 688. mh\ belongs to a)gaqw=|.
*kateskeua/santo—‘fonnd quarters.’
w(s e(/kasto/s pou—Aristoph. Eq. 792, Andoc. ap. Suid. s.v. ska/ndic. Andocides refers to the difficulty of getting good food.
e)xw/rhse—from this early trans. use of xwrei=n comes the meaning ‘receive’ of persons, as in St. Matthew xix. 12.

*(/hptonto—cf. Plat. Phaedo, 64 A o)rqw=s a(pto/menoi filosofi/as. Thuc. speaks of the Athenians generally: while the country people were settling down as best they could, the Athenians were meanwhile busy with the details connected with the war, both ta\ e)/cw, cumma/xous a)gei/rontes, and ta\ e)/ndon, nau=s e)cartu/ontes. th=| *p..—c. 56, 1.
e)n tou/tw| p.— cf. VII. 50, 4 e)n panti\ a)qumi/as.
*th=s *)at. e)s *oi)no/hn—for order cf. c. 21, 1, 25, 3.

*oi)no/hn—there were two roads to Attica, the one a bad one by the coast, the other an inland one, leading over Cithaeron by the Pass of the Oak's Heads (*druo\s *kefalai/) and passing Eleutherae, which is probably the site of Oenoe. In any case Oenoe was on the frontier between Attica and Boeotia and just where the road from Athens and Eleusis branched off, one way to Plataea, the other to the Peloponnese.
w(s e)kaqe/zonto —the imperfect implies a prolonged stay. Cf. c. 19, and see c. 3, 1.
prosbola\s—the siege was preliminary to the invasion. See 19, 1.
pareskeua/zonto—for the omission of w(s with the participle, cf. c. 91, 1.
*au)tw=|—follows the gender of the predicate, instead of that of the antecedent.
frouri/w|—because it commanded the pass. A similar importance attached to Phyle and Decelea.
a)/llws—‘in other ways.’
*ai)ti/an te—to the end of the chapter is parenthetical.

e)/laben ... dokw=n ... ou) parainw=n—dokw=n gives the cause of e)/laben, parainw=n the cause of dokw=n. Cf. c. 86 a)nqw/rmoun ... gnw/mhn e)/xontes ... fobou/menoi. au)tou=—of what has just been described, as often.

e)n th=| cunagwgh=|—in bello conflando. So Isocr. oi)=mai to\n po/lemon qew=n tina sunagagei=n. e)peidh/ te— this te joins cunele/geto to e)n th=| cunagwgh=|. Four periods are distinguished, (1) the time when Sparta was seeking a casus belli, (2) the time when the contingents were assembling at the Isthmus, (3) the march to Oenoe, (4) the delay at Oenoe
h(/ te—this te belongs equally to e)peidh\ cun. o( strato/s, but the order is distorted for the sake of the antithesis between the three periods. Cf. c. 13, 2.
kata\ th\n—i.e. h( kata\ th\n a)/llhn p. sxolaio/ths. Cf. Intr. p. xl.
a)/llhn—exclusive, ‘as well.’
ma/lista de\—the most inelegant section in the book. The repetition of what has been said in 2 above is clumsy.

*)epelqo/ntes a)
—the a)
 belongs to katalabei=n only; of course a)
 is constantly attracted to a partic. which forms the protasis; but sometimes the a)
 also belongs to the partic., which is part of the apodosis, as c. 53, 4 biou\s a)
 ... a)ntidou=nai.
(In some cases it is not easy to decide whether the partic. belongs to prot. or apod., as Demosth. Phil. 1, 1.)
*)en ... o)rgh=|—see c. 59, 2.
*pa=san i)de/an—adverbial, = pa/nta tro/pon. peira/- santes—se. au)th=s. In Attic peirw=mai = conari. Only Herod. and Thuc. among prose writers use the aetive in this sense. [
tw=n e). *qhbai/wn]—Intr. p. xxxix.
o)gdohkosth=|—i.e. about June 20th.
a)kma/zontos—denotes the time preeeding ripeness, in Attica the end of May and the greater part of June.

h(gei=to de\—Archidamus has been already referred to again and again as the general. But ef. c. 47, 2, 71, 1; III. 1, 1, 26, 2, 89, 1; IV. 2, 1; V. 54, 1, 57, 1; VII. 19, 1. h\gemw
 is the technieal word for the Peloponnesian general, cf. I. 128 *pausani/as o( h(gemw
 th=s *spa/rths, and the name of the h(gemw
 —generally one of the kings—in command of a Spartan expedition is regularly given as a matter of form. As regards Sparta, h(gemw
 is regularly the title of a king or regent. Thus Brasidas is ealled only strathgo\s or a)/rxwn.
*kaqezo/menoi—for the tense, ef. c. 18, 1.
*)eleu- si=na kai\ to\ *q. pedi/on—the country round Eleusis.
peri\ tou\s *(reitou\s—two salt lakes on the boundary between the land of Athens and Eleusis, at the eorner of the Thriasian plain. From Eleusis Archidamus had followed the Sacred Way.

*ai)ga/lewn—instead of ‘turning off to the eastward,’ as Grote says, Archidamus probably continued along the direct road to Athens, i.e. the Saered Way, erossing the pass of Daphni, and only then turned north towards Mount Parnes. This agrees better with e)n decia=| e)/xontes to\ *ai). (Mount Skarmanga). The question is eomplicated by the uneertainty of the position of the deme Cropia.

xro/non polu\n—with e)/temnon. e)mmei/nantes—‘having settled there.’ e)mme/nein is regularly used of persons: thus e)mme/nw tai=s spondai=s, not ai( spondai\ e)mme/nousin is the ordinary idiom. For exeeptions, see c. 2, 1 not. crit.
*(ws ... taca/menon]—by no means in accordanee with the desultory nature of Archidamus' operations. On le/getai, see c. 57, 1.
e)s to\ pedi/on—the Attic plain.
e)kei/nh| th=| e)sbolh=|—temporal. See c. 13, 9, 57, 2. Rutherford, Syntax, p. 68.
*tmhqh=nai—the infinitive after periora=n is found only in Herod. and Thuc.; p. then = e)a=n, the notion of perception or want of it being lost. Cf. c. 18, 5. M. T. 903, 6.
*)enstratopedeu=sai—for e)n in compounds with ad- verbial force, cf. c. 44, 1.

me/ros—see c. 21, 3. There were probably heroes of Marathon to be found among the Acharnians, who were by no means inclined to see their vines
cut down without a blow being struck. The deme was proud of its distinction in war. See Aristoph. Ach. 180.
o(rmh/sein —transitive, governing tou\s pa/ntas.
*toiau/th| me\n—resuming and dismissing gnw/mh| toia=|de in 1 above. Cf. 9, 1 and 6.
*kai/ tina—the principal sentence.

*pleistoa/nakta —when Euboea and Megara revolted from Athens 445 B.C., and Pericles had crossed to Euboea, Pleistoanax invaded Attica, but retreated after ravaging the Thriasian plain, as Pericles returned.

memnhme/noi. .o(/te...a)nexw/rhse—‘remembering the time when.’ Cf. c. 54, 4 mnh/mh e)ge/neto . o(/te (o( qeo\s) a)nei=le. Eur. Hec. 112 oi)=sq' o(/te xruse/ois e)fa/nh cu\n o(/plois. Only o(/te is used in prose to mark a date. See c. 98, 1. So ‘audivi eum eum diceret.’
e)sbalw\n ... ou)ke/ti proelqw\n— both temporal; cf. c. 68, 3, 71, 2, where also the time of the first precedes that of the second.

e)s *)e. kai\ *qriw=ze—i.e. e)s *)e. kai\ to\ *qria/sion pedi/on. e)s to\ p. ou)ke/ti—‘without advancing further.’ Cf. I. 114 to\ ple)on ou)ke/ti proelqo/ntes. With the eomparative the -e/ti is superfluous, but idiomatic.
h( fugh\—Thuc. writes as though he had mentioned this before, but nothing is said about it in I. 114, and it is again referred to incidentally V. 16. It must have been a very famous event.
*(ws ei)ko\s—with e)fai/neto. e)n tw=| e)mfanei=—)(e)n tw=| a)fanei= I. 136. e)n in an adverbial phrase is eommon.
plh\n —here an adverb. Cf. c. 34. So ad = w(s, Livy XXI. 22, 3 ad mille oetingenti, though that use is limited to cases in whieh mille or millia intervenes.

ta\ *mhdika\—‘at the time of the Persian war.’ Cf. I. 3, 4 ta\ pro\ *(/ellhnos. Adverbial aceusative, as in to\ prw=ton. mh\ periora=n—distinguish (a) ou)k e)do/kei periora=n, ‘it did not seem good to overlook it,’ (b) e)do/kei ou) periora=n, ‘it seemed that they were not overlooking it,’ (c) e)do/kei mh\ periora=n, ‘it seemed better not to,’ i.e. ‘they determined not to,’ implying ‘preferenee or deprecation.’ Rutherford. Syntax, p. 132.

*kata\ c. g.—so gi/gnomai is often used with participial expressions. Cf. c. 3 e)k tou= i)/sou gi/gnesqai. The style here beeomes more animated, the conflicting passions being described, as usual, in short eo-ordinate sentences.
oi( me\n— apposition to the universal subject. Cf. c. 16, 1.
pantoi/ous, w(s a)kroa=sqai—i.e. every man, to whatever side he belonged, eould quote his own oraele-monger.
w(/rmhto—with infin., as in c. 59. para\—c. 72, 2.
panti/ te—this te sums up the preeeding three.
strathgo\s w)\n—Pericles being strathgo\s au)tokra/twr (speeially given unlimited powers) could prevent any of his colleagues from leading them out.
u(pecaga/goi— cause assigned by the people. Hence optative.
*gignw/skein peri\ tou= mh\—cf. c. 55. For the reason of his action, see Intr. p. lxix.
e)kklhsi/an te ... th/n te—the double te implies two coneurrent acts having the same object in view.

e)poi/ei—‘summon.’ e)kklhsi/a means the regular meeting (kuri/a e)kklhsi/a) which only a strathgo\s au)tokra/twr could prevent. It was ordinarily held in each Prytany. cu/llogos means a special meeting (sugklhto\s e)kklhsi/a). Cf. c. 59 and IV. 114, 120. These were summoned by the Prytanes at the request of the Strategi. (Gilbert, Beitr. zur innern Geschichte, p. 14, explains this passage differently.) As so many eountry people were now in Athens, all opposed to the war, it would have been very dangerous to eall a meeting.

ou)de/na—but he could not prevent the custa/seis: club intrigues and sueh strained eombinations of opposed interests as oecur in times of excitement took the plaee of ordinary politics. In this hazy atmosphere the figure of Cleon looms indistinctly. (We cannot penetrate into the workings of the e(tairei=ai to which Thuc. refers; but Grote is quite mistaken in saying that Cleon rose now ‘as an opposition speaker.’ He was preparing for the great attaek on Pericles that was made in 430 B.C. Intr. p. lxxvi.)
di' h(suxi/as—c. 13, 2.
*tou= mh\—purpose, a rare construction outside Thuc.
e)spi/ptontas e)s kakourgei=n—the eommon object is accommodated to the participle. See c. 13, 2.
a)grou\s—the Attic plain.
*frugi/ois—somewhere between Athens and Acharnae in the plain.
troph\ e)ge/neto—pass. of t. e)poih/santo, c. 19.

*to\ palaio\n c—made 461 B.C., the Thessalians being enemies of the Dorians and Boeotians from early times. The allianee was made when Sparta sent away the foree which Athens sent to help to subdue the helots.

*polumh/dhs kai\ *)aristo/nous—these suggestive names are one outeome of the visit of Gorgias to Larissa, which had previously prided itself on i(ppikh\ rather than sofi/a. Plat. Meno, 70 B, Isoer. 15, 155.

a)po\ th=s sta/sews—the Sehol. says h( *la/rissa e)stasi/ase pro\s e(auth/n: dio\ e(kate/ra meri\s a)/rxonta ei)=xe. le/gei de\ o(/ti e(kate/ra sta/sis du/namin *)aqhnai/ois a)pe/steilen. oi( me\n ga\r dhmokrati/an h)/gagon, oi( de\ o)ligarxi/an. These explanations are based only on the passage. It is more probable that Thue. means that the troops of Larissa were in two divisions, each having its own general Cf. c. 36, 1; VI. 62. The meanings of me/ros and sta/sis are much alike, and as me/ros sometimes has a political, so sta/sis perhaps has a military sense. Cf. centuria. A. Philippi, Rhein. Mus. 36, p. 245, proposes a)rxhgo\s th=s sta/sews for a)po\ t. s. Larissa was the most important state in Thessaly. Its prinees elaimed to be descended from Heracles, Pind. Pyth. 10. (Herodian settles the orthography. It must
be admitted that the analogy of Thebes, and of Sparta to some extent, favours the explanation of the Sehol.)
kata\ po/leis —though the cities of Thessaly had separate prinees, they seem to have been connected by allianee.
*brilhssou=—Mt. Pentelicon, N.E. of Athens. See 3 below.

*xili/ous o(pli/tas—10 for each ship, as usual. These marines were generally Thetes. Cf. VI. 43 They were called e)piba/tai. *karki/nos—related to the famous tragic poet of the same name, at whom Aristophanes jests several times.
*prwte/as—had been one of the commanders of the 10 ships sent to Coreyra in 433. Intr. p. lxvii.
*(/osou—see c. 13, 7.
*)wrwpo\n—to get there from Pentelieon, they would pass the demes Cephisia, Aphidna and Oenoe, and cross the pass of Deeelea.
th\n *grai+kh\n—the name of the coast opposite Eretria. It is probably the plaee whieh gave the name Graeci to the colonists of Italy. See Busolt, G. Gesch., I. p. 14
*)aqhnai=oi u/ph/kooi—Oropus fell into the hands of Boeotia in 412 B.C. Thuc. leaves his note, made probably in 431, unaltered.
*)anaxwrhsa/ntwn—then the eountry people returned to their demes.

fulaka\s—to give warning to the eountry people of any fresh invasion and to prevent ships sailing in or out of Megara. Cf. also c. 32, 69. See c. 93, 4. The arrangements were quite different when an enemy was in Attica. Cf. c. 13, 7.
dh\—Thuc. thinks of the changes which were soon found necessary. Cf. c. 94, 5.

e)/docen au)toi=s—in the Ecclesia. The position of Pericles was now improved by the retreat of the enemy, and the departure of the country people. In the eity itself and in Piraeus he had a large majority. Both Diodorus and Plutarch call attention to this inerease of influence, but assign the wrong reason.
poihsame/nois—might have been aecus. (c. 7, 2), but Thuc. and Lysias keep the dat. more than other writers. Cf. v. 9 9.

a)nalou=n—old form of a)nali/skein. ei)ph=|—of the proposer of a motion, e)piyhfi/sh| of the president for the day, who put the question. In VIII. 15, after the revolt of Chios early in 412, ta\ xi/lia t. eu)qu\s e)/lusan ta/s e)pikeime/nas zhmi\as tw=| ei)po/nti h)\ e)piyhfi/santi kai\ e)yhfi/santo kinei=n. kinei=n—only of things disturbed through neeessity.

e)s a)/llo ti—explained by what follows. Cf. c. 1 e(ch=s. nhi/th|—old word for nautikw=| in this phrase. Thuc. is giving the formal language of the yh/fisma. qa/naton—‘the penalty they fixed was death.’ zhmi/an goes elosely with e)pe/qento, whieh is mid. beeause the motion then passed applied to themselves.
*)ecaire/tous—a reserve fleet, distinct from the fulaka/s, inspected yearly; any ships not in first-rate condition were replaeed.
kata\ to\n—the addition of the article adds formal preeision to the language.

trihra/rxous—the ships were docked, so that the eaptains would have nothing to do unless there were an attack by sea. See c. 94. w(=n—goes baek to trih/reis. xrh=sqai—it is easy to supply e)/doce, but by no means certain that Thuc. intended this. See c. 13, 1 gi/gnesqai and 5 oi(=s xrh/sesqai. h)\n de/h|—the apod. is implied in tou= au)tou= k.
*)ekei=—the Messenians of Naupactus, placed there by Athens 455 B.C., the Acarnamans and Zaeynthians.

*meqw/nhn—contrast the order in e. 18, 1 and 3 below. M., now Modon, is in Messenia, but after the Messenian Wars, circa 650 B.C., Messenia belonged to Laeonia. About the same date, the inhabitants of Nauplia, expelled from Argolis, were settled in Methone by Sparta, to hold the port in her interest as the Messenians afterwards held Naupaetus for Athens.
prose/balon—they thought to take it by assault, judging a regular approaeh unnecessary.
o)/nti ... e)no/ntwn—see on e. 4, 4.
ou)k e)no/ntwn—se. tw=| tei/xei. There were however men in the place, but it was ungarrisoned. The attaek was a surprise.
*peri\ tou\s x. t.—the only phrase in which the plur. of xw=ros oceurs in Thue. Cf. c. 101, 2; III. 102, 4.
*brasi/das—Thuc. admired Brasidas and relates many of his adventures. They may be read again, adorned with rhetorieal effects, in Diodorus.
froura\n e)/xwn—‘with an expeditionary force,’ sent to protect the eoast of Messenia. Cf. froura\n fai/nein in Xen., ‘to send out a force.’
tetramme/non—‘with their attention oceupied.’ Cf. c. 40, 2. So versus ad.
e)ph|ne/qh—by a decree passed in his honour, the usual sense of e)painw= in such eases.
*sxo/ntes—cf. c. 33, 3.
*feia\n—now Katakolo, the landing-place for visitors to Olympia.

e)pi\ du/o h(—cf. c. 86, 5. A rare use of e)pi/. Cf. Andoc. II. 8 lu/pas e)pi\ xro/non plei=ston fe/rein. th=s koi/lhs *)/hlidos—the physieal conditions of the eountry as well as the feud between Elis and Pisatis over the management of the games dating from the 7th cent. B.C., prevented any real union in this district. The N. part, in the valley of the Peneus, was h( koilh/, and was taken by the Aetolian Epeans or valei=oi (Lat. vallis) from the earlier population.

loga/das—Ionie for e)pile/ktous, used by no other Attic prose writer. Eur. Hec. 544. Suidas s.v. loga/dhn. au)to/qen—i.e. from the neighbourhood of Pheia itself, whieh, being in Pisatis, belonged to the perioiki/s. e)k th=s perioiki/dos—epexegesis of au)to/qen, but also showing that the
relieving party was drawn not merely from the immediate neighbourhood of Pheia, but from Pisatis and Triphylia generally (h( perioiki/s, the sense being political not geographical).
*)ane/mou katio/ntos—cf. c. 84; VI. 2, 4. The regular word of a breeze getting up at sea.
e)pe/bhsan e)pi\—so I. 111; VII. 69; less eommonly simple dat. Contrast e)pibai/nw with gen., ‘to set foot in.’
*)ixqu=n—the promontory on whieh Pheia lay, now C. Katakolo.
to\n ...lime/na—probably Pontikokastro. [
oi(...e)pibh=nai]—this could only apply to a)/lloi tine/s: but it is probably a note on oi( *messh/nioi kai\ a)/lloi.
*prosebebohqh/kei—plup., because this had caused the departure of the Athenians.
*fulakh\n—predicate, kai\ joining the two phrases which express the objects of the expedition. For peri\ of vague reference, cf. c. 7, 3.
*kleo/pompos—was strategus again in 430; c. 58 (? 431/430 or 430/429. See note l.c.)
*qro/nion—some way inland; the capital of the Epi- cnemidian Locrians, on whom see c. 9, 4.
te—introduces the third fact.
au)tw=n—the inhabitants of Thronium, the people being named instead of the plaee, as often.
*)alo/ph| —its ruins, like those of Thronium, are on the road from the modern Atalante to Thermopylae.
*ai)ginh/tas—Athens had been frequently at war with Aegina, the last war being 460-456 B.C., when Aegina surrendered. See I. 67. {
e)n}
tw=| au)tw=| q—Cl. shows that Thuc. always inserts e)n in this phrase. Otherwise he uses the gen.
au)tou/s te—‘brutale applieation du droit du plus fort.’ M. Henry.
ou)x h(/kista—with ai)ti/ous. [th=| *p. e)pikeime/nhn]—had this been the object Athens would have directed her attacks on Peloponnese from Aegina; but we hear nothing of this.
e)poi/kous—i.e. klhrou/xous. This measure was certain to make Pericles very popular.
kai\— ‘and so.’
*qure/an—thus the Aeginetans would form a buffer between Laconia and Argolis. This region was a constant source of dispute between the two.
oi)kei=n ... ne/mesqai— these limit e)/dosan and ‘denote occupation, not property.’ Bloomf. Cf. c. 30. sfw=n—emphatic. ‘We help you because you helped us.’

u(po\ to\n seismo\n—about 464 B.C. Just after, the helots revolted, and the Messenians were expelled in consequence. See c. 25, 1. The Spartans now paid back Athens for placing the Messenians in Naupactus,
*qurea=tis—had been in the hands of Sparta since 495 B.C.

div2.p:
*kata\ selh/nhn—see c. 4, 2 on teleutw=ntos tou= mhno/s. w(/sper kai\—probably Thue. drew his knowledge of natural
phenomena from Anaxagoras, whose influence on Pericles and many of the thoughtful men of the time was very great. A. was called o( *nou=s, his chief doctrine being nou=s e)sti\n o( diakosmw=n te kai\ pa/ntwn ai)/tios. Soerates when a young man once believed in him. See Plato, Phaedo 97 C, where S. speaks of A's physical theory with good-humoured banter. Cf. c. 102, 3. According to a story in Cicero (de Rep. I. 16) and Plutarch, Per. 35, the people were alarmed at this eelipse, and Pericles explained it after Anaxagoras.
e)ce/lipe— this chapter correets, while it ignores, the current superstitions about eclipses. Herod. I. 74 tells a similar tale of Thales.
geno/menos kai\ e)kfane/ntwn—see c. 4, 4.
a)ste/rwn —Mars and Venus.

div3.p: *puqe/w—Ionic gen. of *pu/qhs. Cf. *thre/w below.
ei)=xe—sc. gunai=ka. Cf. Andoc. I. 50 o(\s e)/xei sou th\n a)delfh/n. *sita/lkhs—see c. 95-102. pro/cenon—their representative in the kingdom of the Odrysae.
*th\n mega/lhn basi/leian—the great kingdom existing in 431.

e)pi\ plei=on th=s a)/llhs—there are several ways of explaining this. The old rendering was ‘made it more powerful than the rest of Thrace,’ but this strains e)pi\ plei=on. The others are (1) ‘extended his kingdom over a great part of Thrace,’ (2) ‘established it over a greater territory than the rest of Thrace comprised,’ i.e. it included more than half of Thrace, (3) ‘formed it on a larger scale than the rest of Thraee.’ Probably (2) is right; I. 9, 3, 71, 3 are similar.
*prosh/kei ou)de/n—at a time when Athens was trying to form a conneetion with Thrace, it was natural that people should try to eonneet Athenian history with Thraeian.
to\ e)/rgon—a hint at the murder of Itys by Procne and Philomela. Ovid, Met. VI. 620. For the attitude of Thuc. towards these myths, see Grote I. p. 389.

polloi=s—the ordinary prose rule for the agent with perf. pass, which Thuc. generally follows, is that the dat. is used when the subject is nonpersonal: when the subject is a person, u(po\ and gen. is invariably used.
e)n a)hdo/nos mnh/mh|—‘in referenees to the nightingale.’
ei)ko\s de\—for this argument cf. c. 11, 8. It was used only by orators and historians: philosophers laughed at it.
kh=dos—an Ionie word for ‘a connexion by marriage,’ found in Herod., Tragedy and late writers.
dia\ tosou/tou— ‘at so short a distance.’ Cf. c. 12, 1.
pollw=n h(merw=n— depends on o(dou=, see c. 13, 7.
*ta\ e)pi\ *q—the Chalcidian towns, which were causing much anxiety at the time.
*perdi/kkan—he had acted against Athens in the matter of Potidaea. I. 57-62. cunelei=n— ‘to help to establish their influence over.’
*te—‘and so.’
e)poi/hse—contrast with e)poih/santo in 4 above.
*sa/dokon—this presentation of the freedom of Athens amused and disgusted many. See Aristoph. Acharn. 141.

*)aqhnai=on—Muller-Strubing places kai\ *sa/dokon . .*)aqhnai=on after cu/mmaxon e)poih/santo above, on the ground that Thuc. could not say that an Abderite made a man a citizen: but it is plain that Thuc. refers to formalities earried out by the Proxenus when a member of his state was made a citizen of the state of which he was Proxenus. (So muei=n, ‘to initiate’ into the mysteries, a privilege belonging to the Eumolpidae, and Ceryees is used inexaetly of the man who introduces a candidate for initiation. Cf. [Dem.] 59, 21, Andoc. 1, 132.
*cunebi/base—a great gain to Athens. Cf. Intr. p. lxviii.
*qe/rmhn—eaptured by Athens in 432. I. 61, 2. t'—‘and so.’
*formi/wnos—he had gone with reinforeements to Potidaea in 432. See c. 2, 1. He had been Strategus in the Samian War, and again held offiee in 430 and 429. I. 64, 117; e. 69, 80, 102.
*ou(/tw me\n—the usual way in whieh Thue. summarises and dismisses a subject to pass to another. Cf. e. 4, 9, 15, 20.
*oi(—the influence of the art. extends to *pelopo/nnhson, so that o)/ntes is attributive.
e)/ti—where they were left c. 25. *so/llion—here Demosthenes landed in Aetolia in 426. It remained in the possession of Athens to the peace of Nicias. It appears to be S. of Astacns.
th\n gh=n kai\ po/lin—the art. covers both nouns, they being inseparable. Cf. c. 64 h( lampro/ths kai\ do/ca. ne/mesqai—epexegetie, th\n gh=n kai\ po/lin being object to paradido/asi. Cf. c. 27, 2.
*)/astakon—near the mouth of the Achelous.
*kata\ *)akarnani/an—‘opposite.’ Cf. Aristoph. Ran. 626 kat' o)fqalmou\s = coram te. A rare use.
tetra/polis— the Samaeans were the most important, and in ancient times gave their name to the state. In Od. I. 246 Cephallenia is ealled Same, in IV. 671 Samos.
*palh=s—the names of the people are given instead of the cities. Cf. c. 9, 4.
*fqino/pwron—in September.

*megari/da—for the policy of this, see Intr. p. Ixxii. Megara had a hard fate, gross time-server as she was. In 455 she revolted from Sparta to Athens; then in 445, when Athens was in a bad plight, revolted from her and rejoined Sparta. In 427 Nicias seized Minoa, an island off Megara. In 425 Aristophanes, in the Acharnians, gibed at her sufferings in a spirit worthy of Lauderdale. In 424 the Athenians became masters of Nisaea and the Long Walls that connected Megara with that port. Then the walls were pulled down. In the truce of 423 the
line between the Athenians and Megara was carefully defined. Athens lost her influence there by the peace of 421, when Minoa and Nisaea were restored to Megara.
*mega/rois—i.e. the district of Megara, as with Eleusis c. 19.
*)ege/neto—of a sum total, as c. 13, 3.

muri/wn— with the 3000 hoplites at Potidaea, the total becomes 13,000, as mentioned in c. 13. Phormio, who had been sent with 1600 more to Potidaea, must have returned already to Athens, though, as often in Thuc., this fact is only referred to incidentally and later See c. 58, 2.
o(/milos—so c. 34, 8, 36, 4, 65, 4. Outside Thuc. it is found only in Herod., Tragedy and late authors, as Dion. Hal., Plutarch, Lucian.
*kai\ a)/llai—the result was a sore famine in Megara.

div2.p: *)atala/nth—in 426 B.C. part of the island disappeared in an earthquake when it was oeeupied by the Athenians.
frou/rion—predicate. h( e)pi\ *lokroi=s—e)pi\ = ad oram sita. So III. 89, 3.
*)opou=ntos—see c. 9, 2.

div3.p: *)epikou/rous—speeially used of mereenaries and tyrants' body-guards. *xru/sidos—*xru=sis is masc., *xrusi\s fem., c. 2, 1.
*th=s peri\ q—an uncommon use of peri/. See on c. 99, 3, and for the order, cf. c. 18, 1.
peiraqe/ntes—see c. 19, 1. Supply prospoih/sasqai. a)pe/pleon—imperf., as the journey was broken.
*sxo/ntes ... a)pathqe/ntes ... a)poba/llousi—the first participle is temporal, while the second belongs closely to the verb and defines it like an adverb of manner.

e)c o(mologi/as —‘after an agreement had been made with them,’ the Corinthians, so that they had reason to expect the surrender of the islanders. The antithesis is between a)path\ and o(mologi/a, i.e. e)c o\mologi/as a)path\ gi/gnetai, as e)c is constantly used of persons, to denote a change of condition; cf. transfuga ex oratore etc.
a)prosdokh/tois—active. See c. 3, 4.
biai/oteron—‘not without a struggle,’ with considerable diffieulty.
*no/mw|—‘custom.’ See c. 35, 1.
tafa\s—funeral) )ta/fos, tomb.
e)n tw=|de tw=| p—see e. 1, init.
a)poqano/ntwn —in the siege of Potidaea, during the skirmishes with the invaders in Attica, and in the two coast expeditions.

*)osta=—the bodies had been burnt already at the scene of the action, then the bones were collected and buried at Athens. Cf. Plato, Phaedo, 80 D e)/nia me/rh tou= sw/matos, o(sta= te kai\ neu=ra kai\ ta\ toiau=ta w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n a)qa/nata/ e)stin. proti/qentai—proponunt.

a)pogenome/nwn—ef. c. 51, 5. An Ionie word. Herod. II. 85. Suidas, s.v. a)pege/neto, says ou(/tws *)antifw=n kai\ *qoukudi/dhs. Probably it was used in ritual, as
a)poktinnu/nai for a)poktei/nein. pro/trita—so Aristoph. Lys. 611. Cf. pro/pempta. Both words puzzled ancient commentators. We should say ‘two days’ (before the e)kfora/).
skhnh\n poih/santes—in the agora, whieh was in the deme Cerameicus.
h)/n ti—not the things whieh the dead were supposed to require for their existenee below, but fancy presents.
e)peida\n—used here like o(/tan. Contrast 6 below, and c. 72, 3.

kuparissi/nas—the sehol. says that cypress was used beeause it does not easily deeay. Cl. says this is mere imagination; but at Veniee carved chests of cypress were used in the time of Shakspere for keeping valuable stuffs in. (‘Taming of the Shrew,’ II. 1 In cypress chests my arras.) The faet that it was used for coffins may be the reason why it was saered to the dead.

fulh=s—the members of a fulh\ were buried together (a) because the fulai\ were the largest aggregates based on the family, (b) because they were the basis of military organisation. h(=s e(/kastos—e(/k. is put into the relative clause, as in c. 17, 3.

kenh\—every effort had to be made to reeover the dead; only for those who were not found after eareful search was the symbolic burial sufficient. Eur. Hel. 1241 *(/ellhsi/n e/sti no/mos o(\s a)\n po/ntw| qa/nh| [kenoi=si qa/ptein e)n pe/plwn u(fa/smasin. tw=n a)fanw=n—with kli/nh. For the expression, cf. VIII. 38 a)pople/wn e)n ke/lhti a)fani/zetai.
*(o boulo/menos—the generic art. is post-Homeric.
ce/nwn—thus the aliens would hear the funeral oration, in which Athens was always extolled.
ai( prosh/kousai—this limits gunai=kes, lit. ‘I mean those who are related.’
e)pi\ to\n ta/fon—the women might be present at the grave, but did not walk in the proeession from the agora.

*proastei/ou—that part of the Cerameieus which was outside the gates was used as a cemetery. It was to Athens what the Appian Way was to Rome. It was just outside the Dipylon, the chief and double gateway of Athens. Probably it means ‘the potters' quarter,’ the Athenian potteries being famous. Cf. the potters' field in St. Matthew, XXVII. 7, whieh was bought ‘to bury strangers in.’
plh\n—see c. 21, 2.

e)n *maraqw=ni—see not. crit. Some critics, while admitting e)n *salami=ni, deny that e)n can be used with *maraqw=ni, and no case where the metre requires e)n before *maraqw=ni is found. The names of the sites of famous battles are used elliptically.
au)tou=—on the battle-field.
kai\—as well as burning the bodies.
ta/fon e)poi/hsan—‘made them their grave.’ The mound raised over it still exists, as also the remains of the trophy of victory set up in 490 B.C.
*(h|rhme/nos u(po\—the subject is a person; therefore u(po\ and not the dat. is used with the perf. pass.

mh\ a)cu/netos—i.e. cunetw/tatos. a)ciw/sei—Grote and Shil. say a)ci/wsis means the estimate one has of oneself; a)ci/wma that which others have of one. Such a wide difference does not exist here. a)ci/wsis is the recogintion of a man's gnw/mh. proh/kh| —rare for proe/xh|. e)p' au)toi=s—the prep. marks the occasion. Cf. 8 below, 35, 1, 42, 1. So in the orators.
e)/. to\n pre/ponta—mark the order. c. 2. 2.
*cumbai/h—sc. qa/ptein tou\s e)k tou= pole/mou, i.e. at the end of each campaign.
*kairo\s e)la/mbane—‘at the right moment,’ = k. kate- la/mbane. Cf. c. 18, 2.
u(yhlo\n pepoihme/non—together. Ste. however places the stop after u(yhlo/n. w(s e)pi\ plei=ston —so w(s e)pi\ to\ polu/ IV. 29, 3; e)pi/ ple/on c. 53, 1 (cf. c. 29, 2 note). Cf. Eur. Sup. 857 fol.

e)/lege—now follows the lo/gos e)pita/fios. It is more worked up than any other speech in Thuc., and conforms closely to the rhetorical rules. The other l. e)pita/fioi extant are one ascribed to Lysias, one to Demosthenes (see 44, 2), the Menexenus ascribed to Plato; fragments of one by Gorgias (see Intr. p. xlii.), and a considerable part of one by Hypereides. Doderlein says of the speech ‘Arte dicentis ad laudes Athenarum inflexum ac potius ad comparationem vitae Atheniensium liberae, liberalis, vere vitalis, cum tetrica angustaque et aerumnosa Spartanorum disciplina.’

*)epainou=si—e)/painos filled l. e)pitafi/ous. to\n prosqe/nta—it is not known who instituted the custom. It was of course ascribed to Solon. After a time, the subjects dealt with became traditional commonplaces. Dion. Hal. enumerates them (Ars Rhet. VI.) as patri/s, ge/nos, fu/sis, a)gwgh/, pra=cis. Then he shows how the subjects should be treated.
w(s kalo\n—sc. o)/n. M. T. 875.
no/mw|—probably ‘institution.’
a)rkou=n—used as an adj.

a)\n e)do/kei—censeam, often instead of censeo, as a polite expression, ‘I am inclined to think’; if I had to settle the matter I should hold. Cf. Burke, On American Taxation, ‘For my part I should choose (if I could have my wish).’
e)/rgw| dhlou=sqai—in a public burial, in honour paid to the tomb (a very important matter to the Greeks), and in privileges to the family.
tima/s, oi(=a—the change to neuter shows that only an instance of the many kinds of timai\ is given.
peri\—not local, but ‘at’ meaning ‘on the occasion of.’

paraskeuasqe/nta— with oi(=a. kai\ mh\ k.t.l.—Gottleber makes pisteuqh=nai subj. of kinduneu/esqai, i.e. kai\ (to\) pollw=n a)reta\s pisteuqh=nai mh\ kinduneu/esqai e)n e(ni/. (This is better than making pisteuqh=nai depend on kinduneu/esqai, as then h)\ ou)/ would be required after
pisteuqh=nai.)

e)n e(ni\ kinduneu/esqai—cf. Eur. I. T.1057-8 kai\ ta)/m' e)n u(mi=n e)stin h)\ kalw=s e)/xein
h)\ mhde\n ei)=nai. For the pass. kinduneu/etai cf. c. 43, 5.
pisteuqh=nai—for omission of to/, cf. c. 39, 4.
eu)= te kai\ xei=ron—sive bene sive male dixerit.
to\ metri/ws ei)pei=n—explained by what follows as meaning neither e)ndeeste/rws dhlou=n nor pleona/zein.
e)n w(=|— in a case where. Cf. c. 1. In this phrase, the relative does not refer to any definite antecedent, but rather to the whole preceding clause.

do/khsis—even if the speaker is sure he has hit the mean, he finds it hard to convey that impression to his hearers. The word do/khsis, impression, is tragic, and used by no other prose writer. See c. 14, 1.
a)lhqei/as— truthfulness.

e)ndeeste/rws—cf. c. 50 xalepwte/rws. Thuc. uses a considerable number of such comparatives. They are rare in other prose writers (Dobree, Advers. II. 208), except indeed only after e)/xein intrans., as Plato, Phaedo, 75A e)/xei de\ e)ndeeste/rws. pro\s—prae. Cf. c. 62, 3, 65, 10.
a)kou/oi —protasis to a)\n nomi/seie.

tw=| u(perba/llonti au)tw=n—viz. tw=n e)pai/nwn, that which transgresses the limit in these panegyrics they actually discredit. See on c. 59, 3 to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s gnw/mhs. fqonou=ntes—not that they envy the dead (which the speaker says is not the case c. 45, 1), but they do not like to hear another's praises exaggerated, whether he be living or dead (peri\ e(te/rwn e)/painoi). Cf. Herod. III. 52 fqone/esqai kre/sson e)sti\n h)\ oi)ktei/resqai. Pind. Pyth. I. 85 kre/sswn oi)ktirmou= fqo/nos.
*)epeidh\—resumes e)moi\ d' in 1 above.

e)dokima/sqh —properly of the preliminary test to which newly-appointed officials had to submit to prove they were qualified. Hence dedokimasme/nos, like spectatus, ‘tried and approved.’ The word shows Pericles has in his mind a custom rather than a law.
*)/arcomai—here begins a subsidiary introduction, the object of which is to get rid of the conventional topics in few words, and lead up to the prothesis (see 4 below).

progo/nwn —dismissed with merely a respectful mention, as Pericles' real business is with the present, not the past. He begins with pro/gonoi, the qeoi\ xqo/nioi, as poets and orators begin with the gods. Plato does it sometimes at the beginning of a long discussion; cf. Livy's conclusion to his preface, and the opening of Demosth. de Cor.
prw=ton—not pleonastic, for the analysis shows that the a)rxh\ of the speech contains three points.
di/kaion .. pre/pon—the former of one's duty towards others, the latter of one's duty towards oneself.
au)toi=s—with di/dosqai. kai\ p. de\ a(/ma—like non modo ... sed etiam.
e)n tw=| toiw=|de—‘on such an occasion as this.’
oi( au)toi\—predicate with oi)kou=ntes. The Athenians prided themselves on being au)to/xqones. diadoxh=|—instrumental.
*pate/res—he passes to the period of the Persian Wars.
pro\s oi(=s—they received Attica; they left the maritime confederacy.
a)rxh\n—Pericles avoids stating the steps by which the Athenian h(gemoni/a was turned into an a)rxh/.

*ta\ plei/w—is accus. of respect, and refers especially to the internal improvements, made in the age of Pericles, of whatever kind. As for the material improvements—buildings and walls—Pericles' connection with them precluded him from referring to them in detail.
h(mei=s—Pericles was born about 490 B.C. Hence ma/lista, ‘more or less.’
e)n th=| kaq —lit. ‘living in settled life,’ i.e. ‘in the vigour of life,’ the time between growth and decay. Cic. Cat. maj. 76 constans aetas quae media dicitur.
e)phuch/samen—‘have improved it.’
au)tarkesta/thn—by the increase of the revenue and the advance of culture.

*(=wn—au)tw=n kai\ tw=n pate/rwn. oi(=s k.t.l.—of the Persian Wars, the reduction of Naxos (468 B.C.), the war with Thasos (465), those with Corinth, Epidaurus and Aegina (458), those in Boeotia (457 and 447), that with Euboea (445) and Samos (440).
e)kth/qh—offensive measures) (h)muna/meqa, defensive. [

po/lemon]—this would require *(ellhniku/n, since *(/ellhn can only be used as an adj. with persons, as VII. 42, 1 a)kontista\s barba/rous kai\ *(/ellhnas. a)po\ de\—this introduces the prothesis, or statement of the theme of the main portion of the speech (the pi/stis).

e)pithdeu/sews—‘principles’ on which concrete e)pithdeu/mata are based. Pericles will explain the meaning and point out the results of the ideas which underlie the Athenian constitution, and show that it is based on philosophy and intelligence. (Aristotle did not admire Pericles much, because Athens degenerated so rapidly after his death; and Plato thought little of most men who took part in public affairs: but the passage in Phaedo, 82 A oi( th
 dhmotikh/n te kai\ politikh
 a)reth
 e)pithdeuko/tes, h(
 dh\ kalou=si swfrosu/nhn te kai\ dikaiosu/nhn, e)c e)/qous te kai\ mele/ths gegonui=an a)/neu filosofi/as te kai\ nou=, could not apply to Pericles and the circle of Anaxagoras. See Appendix in Archer—Hind's edition).
au)ta\—cf. c. 1 e(/kasta, 43, 1.

meq' oi(/as—the prepositions are important. a)po\ gives the remote origin, e)c the immediate cause, meta\ the circumstances under which the result was produced. From both a)po\ and e)k must be distinguished u(po/, of the agent (see Class. Rev. III. 436 a),
politei/as—of public and active life) (tro/pwn, of personal relations, and intellectual life.

tau=ta dhlw/sas—‘I will
explain this before’ etc. The main emphasis is on the partic. as c. 12, 2.

e)pi\ tw=| paro/nti—‘under the present circumstances,’ i.e. at the end of the first campaign. There will be practical lessons to learn from the description. Intr. p. lxxii. In the same sense e)pi\ toi=s parou=sin is used VIII. 54, 4.
a)preph=— predicate, with lexqh=nai. Cf. c. 102, 6.
a)stw=n—so that they might lay to heart the lesson to be learnt.
ce/nwn— see c. 34, 4.
cu/mforon—neut. The general topic of the pi/stis is to\ cumfe/ron. It is changed at c. 43 for to\ kalo/n. e)pakou=sai—‘to hear with attention’) (u(pakou/ein ‘to hear and obey.’
*ou) zhlou/sh|—the institutions of Sparta were based on those of Crete.
para/deigma—probably a reference to the embassy sent from Rome to Athens in 454 B.C. to examine the laws of Solon. Livy III. 31. (Hertz, N. Jahrb. 1881, p. 283 fol.)
o)/ntes—the partic. is constructed with the subject instead of with politei/a|, so that the pride of the people is directly appealed to.
o)/noma—adverb. accus.

e)s o)li/gous . . oi)kei=n—‘the administration is in the hands not of a few but of the majority.’ oi)kei=n is here intrans. = ‘to be administered,’ and the subject is h( politei/a. Cf. Plat. Rep. VIII p. 547 C pw=s oi)kh/sei (au(/th h( politei/a);
d. ke/klhtai—‘our constitution is called a democracy.’ Then me/testi de\ k.t.l. explains that, though named a democracy, the name does not mean that the claims of excellence are disregarded.
pro\s ta\ i)/dia d——‘in protecting their private interests,’) (e)s ta\ koina\ below.

pa=si— i.e. o)li/goi, as well as dh=mos. The two cardinal principles on which the democracy rested were i)sonomi/a and e)leuqeri/a. All being equal in the eyes of the law, the majority of necessity controlled the state. Pericles was convinced that complete democracy was necessary, as only under such a government had all an equal chance of developing their abilities; all being, as Isocr. says, e)k th=s dhmokrati/as pepaideume/noi. kata\ de\—antithesis to me/testi pa=si rather than to kata\ me\n tou\s no/mous. a)ci/wsin—existimatio, the consideration accorded to merit, recognition of personal claims

eu)dokimei=—he alludes especially to officials elected by show of hands, such as the strategi. Those offices which required no special knowledge were filled by lot. Whether the best men were always elected is doubtful. Pericles only claims that nothing stood in the way of merit.
ou)k a)po\ me/rous— ‘not on account of his rank so much as.’ me/ros = a particular class, such as the o(moi=oi of Sparta.
a)gaqo/n ti dra=sai—see c. 64, 1; Plat. Rep. I. 332 A.
a)ciw/matos a)fanei/a|—the result of a)ci/wsis is a)ci/wma, a position in the state: ‘by the obscurity of his position.’

kekw/lutai—sc. a)gaqo/n ti dra=sai th
 po/lin, a clear statement that abilities are to be devoted to
the advancement of the state. (This was the theory of all the best Athenian statesmen: there was some sense in the Seriphian's insult to Themistocles, ou) di' au(to
 a)lla\ dia\ th
 po/lin eu)dokimei=.)
*)eleuqe/rws—the same liberal spirit that we show in public life underlies all our private relations.
ta/ te .. kai\ —parataxis: ‘as ... so.’
politeu/omen—lit. live in the state, ta\ pro\s to\ k. being internal accus. ‘as regards our public life,’ quod attinet ad rempublicam.
e)s th\n u(poyi/an—‘in respect of that mutual suspicion often felt (th\n) in the daily business of life.’
e)pithdeuma/twn—the outcome of following any particular e)pith/deusis (see c. 36, 4).
di' o)rgh=s . . e)/xontes —c. 13, 2.
ei) ... dra=|—this merely = to\n drw=nta, i.e. no time is referred to at all. If it were, e)a/n ti dra=| would be required. Cf. c. 64, 6.
kaq' h(donh/n ti dra=|—genio indulget, ‘does as he likes.’ This is true generally; but in their religious opinions the Athenians were intolerant.

a)xqhdo/nas prostiqe/menoi—‘assuming an ill-humoured expression.’ th=| o)/yei ‘on our faces’ may be omitted in trans.; unless, indeed, it belongs not to prostiqe/menoi, but to luphra/s, ‘annoying to see.’ a)zhmi/ous is active in meaning. a)xqhdw\n (= a)/xqos) is poetic. Thuc. still alludes to Sparta, where people could not do as they liked, through the rigorous system of police control enforced by the ephors.
*)anepaxqw=s—‘yet, in spite of this freedom from restraint in our private intercourse, we are in our public acts most careful to reverence the laws.’ Both ta\ i)/dia and ta\ dhmo/sia are adverbial.
ai)ei\—constantly used of the officials who held office for a year, and denoting the continuous succession of magistrates.
a)kroa/sei—‘showing respect to,’ = a)krow/menoi, which means lit. ‘listening eagerly to.’ Cf. c. 21, 3.

au)tw=n—with o(/soi. a)/grafoi—Soph. Antig. 454 a)/grapta ka)sfalh= qew=n|no/mima du/nasqai qnhto\n o)/nq' u(perdramei=n. Xen. Mem. IV. 4, 19. They are the natural laws that are engraved on the heart of every right-minded individual, so that none doubt it is disgraceful to transgress them. Cf. Milton: ‘Those unwritten, or at least unconstraining laws of virtuous education.’
ai)sxu/nhn ... fe/rousi—‘bring universally admitted disgrace,’ sc. toi=s paranomou=si.
*)anapau/las—an old Attic word, frequent in trag.
th=| gnw/mh|—‘for the mind,’ referring to the humanising and artistic value of the festivals.
a)gw=si—namely, at the panhgu/reis, the chief festivals, when business ceased. Such were the Panathenaic Festival and the Dionysia.

qusi/ais—not the ordinary sacrifices, but those performed at the e(ortai/, the most important of which were panhgu/reis. diethsi/ois—
‘which succeed one another throughout the year.’ At Athens the festivals were more frequent than elsewhere, and perhaps ridicule was cast upon them by the Spartans, just as the Romans ridiculed the Jews and Christians for wasting time over their weekly sabbath.
nomi/zontes—= xrw/menoi: an Ionic use, cf. I. 74, end.
kataskeuai=s eu)—c. 65, 2.

kaq' h(me/ran h( te/ryis—i.e. h( kaq' h(. te/ryis. Cf. c. 18. 3. For the reason of this transposition, see Intr. p. xl. The object here is to contrast kaq' h(me/ran with diethsi/ois, in which there is a legitimate gain, since kaq' h(me/ran is always used of ordinary business, whereas diethsi/ois applies to the holidays: also to extend the force of kaq' h(. to e)kplh/ssei and to\ luphro/n, as in c. 7, 2 e)c *)itali/as belongs partly to poiei=sqai. to\ luphro\n— of the petty worries of life, which oppress the middle classes, and take all the pleasure out of life. Pericles allndes to Sparta. Cf. Burke, On American Taxation, ‘If I were to detail the imports, I could show how many enjoyments they procure which deceive the burden of life.’

*ta\ pa/nta—cf. c. 11, 6, 36, 4, ‘all that we need.’ The echo in pa/shs ... pa/nta is what Cornificius calls traductio. It is a variety of paronomasi/a. Cf. VI. 87, 4 e)n panti\ ga\r pa=s xwri/w|. VI. 11, 1 dia\ pollou= ge kai\ pollw=n o)/ntwn. oi)keiote/ra| k.t.l.—ht. ‘the enjoyment with which we reap the harvest of the good things produced in our own land is not more our own than that of the productions of the rest of the world,’ i.e. ‘we have the advantage of enjoying the products of other countries as freely as those of our own.’
ta\ a)gaqa\—not the products of the soil only, but those of the mind as well.
au)tou=—adv., cf. c. 7, 2.
*kai\—‘further.’ Here Pericles, who has not before openly alluded to Sparta, first avows the contrast.
tai=s mele/tais ... toi=sde—the second dat. restricts the first.
tw=n e)nanti/wn—with diafe/romen. koinh\n—Intr. p. lxx. end.

cenhlasi/ais—‘alien acts,’ one of the arcana imperii by which the Ephors tried to keep ont foreign manners. Strangers were not allowed to settle in Sparta. The Athenians felt this as an insult. Cf. I. 144. Aristoph. Av. 1012 w(/sper e)n *lakedai)moni cenhlatei=tai. o(\ ... w)felhqei/h—i.e. o(\ ei) i)/doi mh\ krufqe\n w)felhqei/h a)/n. Thuc. says that he was unable to obtain information about Spartan military matters owing to the concealment which the government practised. v. 9, 5. Cf. c. 8, 4, and to\ krupto\n th=s politei)as v. 68, 2.

tw=| a)f' h(mw=n ... eu)yu/xw| some what similar is c. 87, 1 ta\ a)po\ th=s tu/xhs. Demosth. 54, 36— h( a)p' au)tw=n e(toimo/ths. o)/sh kai\ o(/a pro\s to\ poiei=n o(tiou=n u(pa/rxei. A rare use outside Thuc.: not found in Aristoph., very rare in the orators.

e)s ta\ e)/rga—contrasted with paraskeuai=s.
Contrast c. 11, 5.
tai=s paidei/ais—‘respective methods of education.’

e)pipo/nw| a)skh/sei—of the laborious training to which young Spartans were subjected, being taught to imitate the courage and gravity of men. The life they led was half military, half monastic. At Athens e)pi/ponos was only associated with gh=ras, not with neo/ths. Plat. Rep. I. p. 329 D.

a)neime/nws diaitw/menoi—cf. I. 6, 3 prw=toi *)aqhnai=oi to/n te si/dhron kate/qento kai\ a)neime/nh| th=| diai/th| e)s to\ truferw/teron mete/sthsan. It was conflicting ideas that drove Athens and Sparta into war. Doderlein says ‘demonstratur (in this speech) non impotentia tantum et dominandi cupidine ad bellum tam atrox tamque diutinum impulsos esse, sed etiam diversa recti honestique aestimatione et constanti sui utrosque judicii propugnatione.’

tou\s i)sopalei=s k—Editors are not agreed as to the meaning of these words; there are two interpretations: (1) ‘equal dangers,’ i.e. dangers as great as any the Spartans, for all their training, venture to face (so most edd.); (2) ‘struggles in which equal, but not superior, forces oppose us.’ So Kr., Cl., Tillmanns. The general sense favours (1), the Greek favours (2). According to (2), the reservation is implied ‘we do not risk a battle against superior forces, as when the enemy invade Attica.’
*tekmh/rion—see c. 15, 3.

kaq' e(autou/s—i.e. alone, without the help of their allies. kaq' e(ka/stous is impossible because it would refer to detachments of the Lacedaemonians: had *peloponnh/sioi stood in place of *lakedaimo/nioi, it would have been right.

pa/ntwn—sc. tw=n cumma/xwn. au)toi\—‘by ourselves.’ The words are arranged so that a great emphasis falls on kratou=men, up to which point, the exact meaning of au)toi\, which is contrasted with meta\ pa/ntwn, remains in doubt.
peri\— = u)pe\r, as often in Isocr. and Demosth. Cf. c. 41, 5. Aristoph. Eq. 767 peri\ sou= ma/xomai, 781, 1038.
ta\ plei/w— cf. c. 11, 4 ta\ polla/.
*te—cf. c. 11, 4. This new fact has an important bearing on ta\ plei/w kratou=men, enhancing the value of the victories, and excusing the reverses.
e)pi\ polla\—with e)pi/pemyin. At the same time that we are busy with our fleet, we have to send out our citizens on many expeditions by land.
h(mw=n au)tw=n—i.e. having no allies available.
e)pi/pemyin— (see c. 14, 1) = dia\ to\ h(mw=n au)tw=n (‘partitive’) e)pipe/mpein. au)xou=sin—poetical word. Herod. II. 160. au)/xhma, very rare in Attic, occurs in c. 62, 4.
a)pew=sqai—middle.
u(f' a(. h(ssh=sqai—c. 34, 6.
*kai/toi—resumes the main thought which was in- terrupted at tekmh/rion de/: ‘and surely.’

r(aqumi/a|—‘with a light heart.’ Cf. a)neime/nws diaitw/menoi above. Not in its bad
sense. Shil. quotes [Arist.] Eth. VI. 1 ou)/te plei/w ou)/te e)la/ttw ponei=n ou)de\ r(a|qumei=n. po/nwn—this word had great significance to the Spartans and Thebans, denoting the ‘training’ which they thought so necessary to success. It is constantly used by Pindar, who holds that po/nos and dapanh/ (‘outlay’) together win victory in the games. Observe the paronomasi/a in po/nwn, no/mwn, tro/pwn. meta\ .. a)ndrei/as—the Spartan manliness is the result of military rules, the Athenian of habit formed through our mode of life. a)ndrei/as belongs to both gens., and no/mwn a)ndrei/as, tro/pwn a). form a chiasmus with r(aqumi/a|, po/nwn m. e)qe/lomen—‘omnes recentioris aetatis pro e)qe/loimen scripserunt e)qe/lomen.’ Wichmann. Sta. thinks that Dion. Hal. really wrote the indic., and that this, like other passages he quotes from Thuc., has been altered by Byzantine scribes in his text. The critics ‘corrected’ Dionysius from their MSS. of Thuc.

perigi/gnetai—Dion. Hal. says Thuc. ought to have written perie/stai, because e)qe/lw points to the fut., but there is no reference to time at all here, and if there were the pres. gi/gnomai can apply to the fut. Trans. ‘we are the gainers.’
toi=s me/llousin a)lgeinoi=s—it is a question whether the dat. is causal, ‘through coming troubles,’ or dat. commodi, ‘for the sake of.’ Probably it is causal.

e)s au)ta\—ta\ a)l. geina\ ‘when face to face with trouble.’ The kai\ is paratactic, ‘while,’ and the verb, perigi/gnetai, is gradually lost sight of, until we reach e)n a)/llois, which belongs rather to what follows. This is a good example of Thuc.'s polu/nous braxulogi/a. a)tolmote/rous ... fai/nesqai—with fai/nomai Thuc. more often omits than inserts the partic., where an adj. is used. Contrast c. 51, 3 sw=ma au)/tarkes o)\n e)fa/nh.

*filokalou=men—these words have been assidu- ously translated, paraphrased, and burlesqued. They not only defend Athenian a)ndrei/a, but contain sound advice to his hearers not to let their love of art degenerate into bad taste and mere display, nor their culture undermine their manliness.
eu)telei/as—‘simplicity,’ avoidance of the gorgeous ornamentation that afterwards characterised Asianism.

filosofou=men—‘combine culture with manliness.’ Observe the i)so/kwlon (equal number of syllables in two clauses), 11 syllables on each side of kai/: this is a variety of paromoi/wsis (Intr. p. lii.), and the paronomasi/a in filokalou=men, filosofou=men. a)/neu malaki/as—Demosth. 3, 24 and 25 has a passage probably suggested by this, in which he contrasts the magnificence of the public buildings with the simplicity of the private life in former times. Pericles refers to the Spartan idea, that learning was unsuited to men of action. The idea is not confined to Sparta.
plou/tw|—‘we employ our wealth as means for action, not as a subject for boasting.’ Cf. c. 41, 2.

to\ pe/nesqai—put
First, because emphatic. ‘To admit poverty is no disgrace.’ Cf. c. 37, 1. There were penalties for idleness at Athens.

ai)/sxion—another gnw/mh in the form of an antithesis. Cf. c. 11, 5, and 2, 3 and 4 below. The comparative implies ‘even if poverty were disgraceful (as some say).’ Plat. Apol. p. 39 A mh\ ou/ tou=t' h)=? xalepo/n, qa/naton e)kfugei=n, a)lla\ polu\ xalepw/teron ponhri/an: the first member must be negative in this idiom, in which opposition is mixed with comparison. Cf. ou)de\n a)/llo ... a)ll' h)\ in Plato.

*toi=s au)toi=s—sc. h(mi=n, all the citizens being meant. ‘In attending to our private business, we do not neglect the state.’ It was Pericles' object to induce all the citizens to take part in politics.
e(/tera pro\s e)/rga—i.e. trade, manufacture and agriculture.
tetramme/nois—c. 25, 2.
a)pra/gmona—to many, pra/gmata were tiresome. Cf. c. 64, 4, and Intr. p. lxxii.
au)toi\—‘we in person,’ the citizens in the ecclesia, as contrasted with the Spartan government, which was almost entirely in the hands of the Ephors and Gerusia.

h)/toi kri/nome/n ge—in Thuc., the more certain, but less important alternative is put first when these particles are used. But this does not seem to be the case in other authors. ‘At any rate we are sound judges, if we cannot originate.’ This contains an encouragement to the citizens to exercise their right of voting in the ecclesia, since they were capable of pronouncing an opinion on any policy proposed to them: but there are cases in which the citizens conspicuously erred in their judgment. Here, as in other parts, Pericles states his ideal of the constitution.
e)nqumou/meqa—of the statesmen.
tou\s lo/gous—alluding to the ‘laconic’ brevity of the Spartans.
a)lla\ mh\—i.e. ma=llon bla/bhn h(gou/menoi mh\ prodidaxqh=nai; the compar. as in 1 above.
prodidaxqh=nai—by the orators, to whom, in after years, the people became accustomed to look for political guidance.
pro/teron h)\—for pro/teron ... pri/n, a very rare construction except in Herod., Thuc., and Antiphon. Cf. c. 65, 12.

h)\ e)pi\ a(\ dei= e)/rgw| e)lqei=n—i.e. h(\ e)rgw=| e)lqei=n e)pi\ a(\ dei= (e)/rgw| e)lqei=n). Cf. Plat. Phaedo, p. 114 B oi(\ a)\n do/cwsi diafero/ntws pro\s to\ o(si/ws biw=nai, i.e. oi(\ a)\n do/cwsi diafero/ntws biw=nai pro\s to\ o(si/ws (biw=nai), where, though Stallbaum's quotations are irrevelant, his explanation is right, in spite of Archer-Hind's objection. The verb really belongs to the 1st member, and is ‘understood’ with the 2nd.
e)pi\ ... e)lqei=n—cf. e)pecelqei=n of actions) (diecelqei=n of words.
*(/wste—explains what precedes, as though it were o(/ti tolmw=men. e)pixeirh/somen—‘mean to undertake.’
e)klogi/zesqai—sc. ma/lista, ‘give the fullest consideration.’

o(\— adverbial accus. ‘on the contrary.’ Cf. quod before si. (This is the old explanation, that of Hudson; but it was generally
abandoned in favour of the view that o(\ is nom., and to be explained by anacoluthon. The edd. of the last decade have returned to the old view, especially since 1883—Schneider in N. Jahrb. '83, p. 457.) Cf. to\ de/. It refers to the whole of the preceding sentence.

yuxh\n—only here in Thuc.= ‘spirit’; elsewhere ‘life.’ Cl. compares eu)/yuxos. oi( k.t.l. —this defines courage, as distinct from qra/sos. Aristotle (Eth. II. 2, 7) places the virtue a)ndrei/a midway between the vices deili/a and qra/sos. Cf. Plat. Protag. 351 A, Aristot. Eth. III. 7, 11 fol.
deina\—of the hardships of war.
h/de/a—of the pleasures of peace.

safe/stata—courage is one of the four cardinal virtues (justice, temperance, wisdom, and courage). Socrates held that courage consists, not only in being used to danger, but also in the knowledge of good and evil.
mh\ a)potrepo/menoi—this sums up the preceding sections, in which the statement filosofou=men a)/neu malaki/as has been expanded. dia\ tau=ta=o(/mws.
*)areth\n—in its restricted sense, as Aristot. Rhet. I. 9, 4,=the power of doing good; not in the general sense of the Ethics (= perfection of man and of his functions).
e)nhntiw/meqa—the perf. denotes ‘we have always been unlike,’ a regular use of the perf. In Aristoph. Av. 385 the MSS. give h)nantiw/meqa against the metre.
drw=ntes—cf. Pliny, Ep. III. 4, 6 conservandum veteris officii meritum novo videbatur.
tou\s —‘our.’

bebaio/teros—‘a firmer friend,’ cf. Aristot. Eth. IX. 7, 2 oi( eu)= pepoihko/tes filou=si kai\ a)gapw=si tou\s eu)= peponqo/tas. o\ dra/sas k.t.l.—i.e. o( dra/sas th
 xa/rin e)sti bebaio/teros w(/ste sw/|zein th
 xa/rin o)feilome/nhn di' eu)noi/as e)kei/nou w(=| de/dwke th
 xa/rin. Here, as often, w(/ste is inserted where the simple infin. might have been used. Cf. c. 2, 4; Plat. Protag. p. 338 C a)du/naton w(/ste sofw/tero/n tin' e(le/sqai. th
 xa/rin—regarded from the side of both giver and recipient, thus combining the meanings ‘favour’ and ‘gratitude,’ as with gratia.

o)feilome/nhn— ‘as due to him’ (i.e. to the giver). o)feilome/nhn and sw/|zein are connected, being properly used of property given in trust to another's keeping. Plat. Rep. I. p. 332 A compared with ib. p. 333 C.
di' eu)noi/as—‘by (the continuation of) his goodwill towards him to whom he showed the kindness.’
de/dwke —as in Acts, 20, 35 maka/rio/n e)sti ma=llon dido/nai h)\ lamba/nein. Livy, XXII. 13 sub fin., Sallust. Cat. 6, 5

sw/|zein—as this means ‘to retain the good-will or gratitude of his friends whom he has benefited,’ the middle might be expected: but the object of the act. is to represent the result of the benefit, not on the mind of the doer but on the mind of the recipient; the doer is said to ‘keep safe’ what the recipient ‘keeps safe’ for him, viz. th\n xa/rin. a)mblu/teros—‘more indifferent.’ Is it not true?

e)s—‘as a.’ Cf. Andoc. II. 23 ei)s
xrh/mata mega/las dwre/as. xa/rin—free service which will win him gratitude. xa/ris, a free gift, is contrasted with o)fei/lhma, a loan, and so a debt.
th=s e)leuqeri/as tw=| pistw=|— ‘the confidence due to our liberal ideas.’ Cf. c. 37, 2 e)leuqe/rws. (Not ‘liberality.’)
a)dew=s—‘without fear,’ lest, by helping others, we should be injuring ourselves.
*te—sums up the preceding remarks.

pai/deusin— not ‘school,’ but ‘liberal education.’ Pericles represents Athens as the *(ella/dos *(ella/s. Cf. Plat. Protag. 337 D Athens th=s sofi/as prutanei=on. Isocr. 15, 295 Athens pa/ntwn tw=n duname/nwn le/gein h)\ paideu/ein dokei= gegenh=sqai dida/skalos. Plat. Laws 641 E all Greeks consider Athens filo/logo/s te kai\ polu/logos. kaq' e(/kaston—Athens as the sum of all the citizens (th\n pa=san), with a perfect politei/a, is contrasted with the individuals, with their perfect tro/poi. See c. 37, 1.

dokei=n a)/n—this a)/n, like the other two, belongs to pare/xesqai. par' h(mw=n—this refers to pai/deusin, and represents the excellence of the individual as proceeding from the spirit of the whole state.
e)pi\ plei=st' a)\n ei)/dh—‘to the most varied circumstances.’

meta\ xari/twn ma/lista eu)trape/lws—i.e. ma/lista meta/ te xari/twn kai\ eu)trape/lws, ‘with the utmost grace and versatility.’ Probably Pericles had in mind the famous lines of Pindar, Pyth. I. 92 to end, mh\ dolwqh=?s eu)trape/lois ke/rdess', k.t.l., and wished to show that eu)trapeli/a in the Athenian character was a virtue.
to\ sw=ma—=e(auto/n.
*)en tw=| paro/nti ko/mpos—‘passing boast.’
ta/de— see c. 42, 1.
du/namis—see c. 36, 4.
shmai/nei—cf. Antiphon, Tetr. *g. g, 3 w(s ou)de\ toi=s au)toi=s h)mu/nato au)to/n, au)to\ to\ e)/rgon shmai/nei. See c. 15, 4.
*tw=n nu=n—sc. po/lewn. a)koh=s krei/sswn—‘superior to what men have heard of her.’
e)s pei=ran e)/rxetai—‘proves herself in the hour of trial.’
tw=| polemi/w|—collective. [

e)pelqo/nti]—spurious, for (1) it destroys the balance to tw=| u(phko/w|, (2) the sense requires that enemies in general should be referred to, not merely enemies who attack Athens; nor could Pericles mean that Athens never attacked anyone.
e)/xei—=pare/xei. Cf. c. 61, 2.
oi(/wn—i.e. fau/lwn. ou)x u(p' a)ci/wn—=u(p' a)naci/wn, the neg. preceding the prep. as usual. Contrast c. 49, 3.
*shmei/wn—‘clear proofs,’ viz. in the results of Athenian activity. ou) dh/ toi—dh\ as in c. 40, 3, emphasizing ou) ‘by no means,’ while toi ‘assuredly’ also belongs to

ou). a)ma/rturon—‘without witnesses,’ since all contemporaries, and above all her enemies knew her greatness from her acts in every land and sea. The word has its forensic sense, as used
of a plea supported only by the speaker's own testimony.
toi=s te nu=n—agent; this disappears in later Attic, except in the cases already noticed. See c. 7, 2.
kai\—at the beginning of a parenthesis. See c. 2, 4.
*(omh/rou—i.e. not needing a poet to exaggerate our history. Of course Thuc. did not object to Homer as a poet, but only as a historian.

o(/stis— i.e. poihth/s. A similar change to a relative clause is not uncommon in Isocrates; e.g. 5, 153 tou\s mh\ mo/non kexarisme/nws dieilegme/nous, a)ll' oi(/tines a)\n ou(/tw poih/swsi ta\s sa\s pra/ceis qauma/zein w(s ou)deno\s a)/llou. (The view that Pericles is intended to reprove Homer for saying so little of the ‘sons of Theseus’ is quite untenable.)
e)/pesi—‘poetry.’

to\ au)ti/ka—‘for the moment.’ Cf. I. 21 ou)/te w(s poihtai\ u(mnh/kasi pisteu/wn, ou)/te w(s logogra/foi cune/qesan e)pi\ to\ prosagwgo/teron th=? a)kroa/sei h)\ a)lhqe/steron. The mythical element in early Greek history was due to the influence of epic. See Intr. C. III. init.

tw=n de\ e)/rgwn—the influence of the rel. is here lost, on the principle of c. 4, 5, 34, 5. The me\n aud de\ are paratactic. The gen. belongs equally to u(po/noian and a)lh/qeia. u(po/noian—‘the conception of the facts,’ aroused by poetry. So u(ponoei=n ‘to conjecture.’
h( a)lh/qeia—i.e. the knowledge gained from investigation of the facts.

a)lla\—antithesis to ou) ... parasxo/menoi. kalw=n te ka)gaqw=n —the MSS. kakw=n is explained to mean ‘of the harm and of the good we have done.’ For kakw=n cf. kakopaqei= above. But Pericles is talking of Atheniau prowess, not contrasting the harm done to her enemies with the benefits conferred on her friends: nor is a)gaqa\ ‘benefits’ here, but ‘acts of valour,’ which of course inflict harm on enemies. Nor is the reference to the Greek estimate of eu)tuxi/a, as a compound of good and ill, for which see c. 44, 1: for Pericles is here dealing not with tu/xh, but with Athenian gnw/mh. The substitution of kakw=n for kalw=n in this phrase, even if it made sense, would be a miserable joke.

cugkatoiki/santes—i.e. while opening the whole world to our prowess, we have at the same time everywhere established monuments of that prowess, in colonies and states made subject to us, and in the scenes of many brave actions.
toiau/ths—this word sums up the whole of the e)/painos A, and prepares the way for e)/painos B.
dikaiou=n—an Ionic and old Attic word, used once by Plato, Laws, p. 934 A. Its usual sense is that of a)ciou=n, but sometimes it = ‘to punish.’
oi(/de .. mh\ a)faireqh=nai au)th\n—the clue to the construction is ou)k a)fairou=mai tou/sde th\n po/lin. tw=n leipome/nwn—c. 2, 4.
ei)ko\s—c. 10, 1.
u(pe\r au)th=s— repeats peri\ ... po/lews. ka/mnein—an exhortation to persevere in spite of the hardships of the war.
*dio\ dh\ kai\—‘this is the very reason why.’
th=s po/lews —in preference to tw=n a)ndrw=n, (1) to encourage his listeners (2) because the clearest proof of the greatness of the Atbenians was the greatness of Athens herself.

peri\ i)/sou—‘for an equal prize.’ Kr. quotes Dem. 8, 60 ou)x u(pe\r tw=n i)/swn u(mi=n te kai\ toi=s a)/llois e)/sq' o( ki/ndunos. (kinduneu/ein, a)gwni/zesqai and so forth, with peri/, u(pe/r or e(/neka are common in the orators. In Andoc. I. 10 ei)s to\n a)gw=na to/nde kate/sthn, peri\ tw=n musthri/wn w(s ou)/te moi h)se/bhtai, the comma should be placed after musthri/wn.)

tw=nde—referring to what precedes. In speeches o(/de is fairly often used thus of ou(=tos. Cf. 40, 2, 60, 6, 63, 2, 71, 3, 72, 1, 3. The meaning was aided by gesture and emphasis, so that the use is akin to the deictic o(/de. The phrase ou)/tws ei)=xen frequently refers to what follows in the orators. Antiphon 6, 9 and 14, Isocr. 4, 163.
mhde\n—hypothetical rel., so that every nation is included, though Pericles has Sparta in his mind.

o(moi/ws—this, like mhde/n, softens the expression and makes it vaguer. It also increases the force of the exhortation ka)mnein u(pe\r th=s po/lews, by increasing the number of states with which Athens is contrasted.
e)f' oi(=s—for tou/twn e)f' oi(=s. Cf. c. 34, 6.
shmei/ois—approaches very near the sense of paradei/gmasi: the manifest proofs are the acts in which the fallen had a share.
*kai\—‘and in fact.’
u(/mnhsa—originally of poetic praise, then of a panegyric in prose. Plat. Repub. 364 A.

ai( tw=nde—sc. tau=ta, their deeds justify my words; for ‘they added fresh lustre to the glories which I praised in our city’: therefore, in speaking the praises of the city, I was praising them. The sense is ta\ th=s po/lews a(\ u(/mnhsa, tau=ta e)kei=noi e)ko/smhsan tai=s a)retai=s. L. and S. wrongly supply th\n po/lin, with several edd., to e)ko/smhsan. a)retai\—‘valiant deeds.’

ou)k a)\n—the whole result of this sentence is positive, but the idiom by which the verb after ou)x w(/sper agrees with the thing in the simile and not the thing compared, has nothing to do with this passage. (Plat. Gorg. 522 A a)porei=n poiei=, ou)x w(/sper e)gw\ hu)w/xoun u(ma=s.)

polloi=s—ethic dat., and equivalent here to pollw=n, but preferred because of the gen. following. ‘There are few Greeks of whom it could be said that tbe report of their deeds does not do more than balance the reality.’
tw=nde—depends on lo/gos. tw=| e)/rgw|—=tw=n e)/rgwn th=? a)lhqei/a| c. 41, 4.
a)ndro\s a)reth\n—‘virtue in a man.’

prw/th te—=ei)/te prw/th mhnu/ei ei)/te teleutai/a bebaioi=. For some, especially the younger men, their death was the first mhnuth\s of the worth which they had not had a previous chance of showing; for others it was but the final confirmation of what had been amply proved before.
katastrofh/— Soph. O. C. 103: meiosis for death.

*toi=s ta)=lla xei/rosi—not referring to any among the dead, but purely hypothetical, and intending to lead to a conclusion a fortiori. If men who have often proved themselves base can by one act rehabilitate themselves, how much more are these men noble who never in any case sbrank from danger? The dat. depends on di/kaio/n (e)sti).
proti/qesqai— =protima=sqai (see 4 below), pass. They may have preferred wealth and ease to serving their country: in estimating them, we must prefer their one great sacrifice.
a)fani/santes—so that not the least trace of their failings remains.
w)fe/lhsan —the aor. are gnomic.
e)k tw=n i)diw=n—‘through their private life.’ Pericles is thinking of the indifference to state affairs against which he warns his hearers. See Intr. p. lxxiii.
*th\n e)/ti—‘the continued enjoyment’ of wealth.

peni/as e)lpi/di, w(s .. au)th
—=ou)/te e)lpi/di, w(s diafugw
 th
 peni/an ka)
 e)/ti plouth/seien. But peni/as is attracted to e)lpi/di because of the antithesis to plou/tw|. e)/ti—some day, as in prophecies and threats.
plouth/seien—ingressive.

a)nabolh\n e)poi/hsato—these periphrases will be found collected in the index, s.v. poiei=sqai. poqeinote/ran—a strong word used of things that are desirable. poqei=n is the regular word in oratory to describe the supposed anxiety of tbe hearers to have information on any point. Antiph. 5, 64; Andoc. 1, 70; Lys. 14. 1; Isocr. 12, 167; 15, 43; Isaeus 11, 19; Dem. 4, 28; 21, 77; 50, 43; Aeschin. 2, 7 and 44.

au)tw=n—again a loose reference to what has been described, here = plou/tou h\ e)/ti a)po/lausis and to\ e)/ti plouth=sai. labo/ntes—=u(polabo/ntes, as ‘I take it’ is used by us for ‘I suppose.’ Often in Thuc.
met' au)tou=—sc. tou= kindu/nou. It goes with e)fi/esqai also.

tw=n de\—viz. the enjoyment and the hope: ‘to face this danger in exacting vengeance before tbey indulged in these hopes.’ The chief emphasis is on met' au)tou=. (Only Bh., Kraz and Ste. among recent edd. retain e)fi/esqai).
e)lpi/di me\n—the construction differs from that of e)/rgw|, which is adverbial.

tou= katorqw/sein—the fut. is due to the prominence of tbe idea of futurity here. Cf. c. 13, 9. The infin. approximates in these cases to its use in Oratio Obliqua, in that the writer allows the thought of the person to whom he refers to influence the tense (a)fane/s e)stin ei) katorqw/somen). It is characteristic of Thuc. to present an action as it was regarded by the actors themselves. M. T. 113.

e)/rgw|—‘but in the task actually before them at the moment, tbey resolved to trust to themselves’: i.e. the future must be left to tu/xh (Providence); the present required gnw/mh. e)n au)tw=|—what can this be but the act just described, i.e. e)n tw=| ... sfi/sin au)toi=s pepoiqe/nai? The sense is ‘in carrying out their resolution,’ i.e. in the struggle
itself.

to\ a)mu/nesqai kai\ paqei=n—cf. Isocr. 2, 36 h)\n d' a)nagkasqh=?s kinduneu/ein, ai(rou= teqna/nai kalw=s ma=llon h)\ zh=n ai)sxrw=s. 4, 95 toi=s kaloi=s ka)gaqoi=s ai(retw/tero/n e)sti kalw=s a)poqanei=n h)\ zh=n ai)sxrw=s. Intr. p. xl.
to\ ai)sxro\n tou= lo/gou—i.e. to\ o)neidi/zesqai w(s deiloi/ (Schol.).
e)/fugon—antithesis to u(pe/meinan, as very often, e.g. Lys. 13, 27 and 63.

to\ e)/rgon—=to\n ki/ndunon. di' e)laxi/stou kairou= tu/xhs—human gnw/mh is often crossed by divine tu/xh, and in this case was so modified that their highest hopes were not realised. The edd. quote Horace Sat. I. 1, 7 horae momento cita mors venit aut victoria laeta, but horae momento denotes a far greater length of time, and does not take in tu/xhs. But this sentence, the close of the e)/painos tw=n a)poqano/ntwn, in its intense solemnity, resembles (mutatis mutandis) the words of St. Paul (1 Cor. 15, 52, 54) ‘We shall all be changed in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye. ... O grave, wbere is thy victory? O death, where is thy sting?’ So here Pericles refers to the rapidity and sud denness with which tu/xh acts. Hence ‘in a moment ordained by Fate, at the crisis not of fear but of glory—they passed.’ (Behrendt rightly objects to Steup's proposal.)

a)phlla/ghsan—absolute, a poetical use. Dr. Kennedy (Cam. Phil. Proceedings 1882, p. 20 fol.) well says that the speaker's voice ‘sinks to the sad and solemn cadence of a)phlla/ghsan.’ Supply tou= bi/ou.
*kai\—‘and thus.’ Here the pi/stis B is summed up, preparatory to passing on to the protroph/ (exhortation).
proshko/ntws th=| po/lei—‘in a manner worthy of Athens.’
tou\s loipou\s—=tou\s leipome/nous of 41, 5.
a)sfaleste/ran— sc. dia/noian, though they should pray for a spirit less fatal (in its results). This again shows that tu/xh had, in Pericles' view, to some extent crossed the purpose of the fallen.
eu)/sesqai—for a)sfa/leia is the gift of God alone. Cf. c. 87, 3. eu)tolmi/a depends on human resolution.
lo/gw|—i.e. from the words of the orator.
w)feli/an—explained in o(/sa ... a)gaqa\ e)/nestin. (On the orthography, Herodian remarks w)fe/leia: poihtikw/teron dia\ to\ i_ kai\ parocu/netai.)
h(\n—with mhku/noi. Cf. c. 42, 1.

pro\s—coram, with a verb of speaking. See c. 5, 7. Cf. III. 53, 4 pro\s ei)do/tas pa/nta lele/cetai. kaq' h(me/ran—this daily contemplation of the greatness of Athens will lead to a lasting love for her: and that love should be an incentive to noble actions.
tolmw=ntes —‘by courage, by knowing what was their duty, and by their sense of honour in the hour of conflict.’
au)ta\—i.e. th\n du/namin, but expressing the details of the power. Cf. c. 1. ou)=n—‘on that account.’
ka/lliston—because, while they contributed to the advancement of the state, they obtained a splendid return.

e)/ranon—‘contribution’; both the
association and the money subscribed to it were termed e)/ranos, which denotes combination for financial purposes of whatever kind. The object is th\n a)reth/n, k. e)/ranon being predicate.

proie/menoi—stronger than the ordinary e)/ranon e)sfe/rein, and used because it is the regular word for sacrificing anything for the state; e.g. Lysias 21, 12 u(mi=n ou)de\n proei=ntai tw=n sfete/rwn au)tw=n.
*koinh=| ... i)di/a|—the antithesis is as obvious as it is forcible. They gave their lives for the common good; they gained for themselves undying fame.

ga\r—Pericles refers to the distribution of profits made by a financial e)/ranos. (All this is quite clear when Andoc. I. 133-135 is compared: he speaks of the members of an e)/ranos got up by Agyrrhius to farm the tax on imports and exports; the object of the business-men who joined it was dianei/masqai ta\ koina/.)
to\n a)gh/rwn e)/painon—the praise (which rewards good deeds).
e)la/mbanon—the tense represents the result of the act (dido/ntes) as growing out of the act itself, as in Lat. ita vitas dederunt ut acciperent, contrasted with ita vitas dederunt ut acceperint.
e)pishmo/taton—the pred. serves to connect the adj. with the rel. clause which follows.
ou)k ... ma=llon, a)ll'—cf. c. 40, 1; 44, 4; a)lla\ for h)\ (only after a neg.) gives greater emphasis to the second clause.

para\ tw=| e)ntuxo/nti ... kairw=|—a curious expression, since para\ with dat. is confined to persons; ‘on every fitting occasion, whether by word or deed.’ This construction is only found when the thing is almost personified; here ai)ei/mnhstos para\ kairw=| lo/gou implies persons: in c. 89, 9 and VIII. 95, 4 Thuc. writes para\ tai=s nausi\n ei)=nai, in v. 26, 5 genome/nw| par' a)mfote/rois toi=s pra/gmasi. There is only one case in the orators, viz. Andoc. I. 116 h\ sth/lh par' h(=| e(/sthkas keleu/ei.

*shmai/nei—c. 8, 3. Cf. v. 20, 2 e)s ta\ progegenhme/na shmai/nei. a)/grafos mnh/mh—cf. c. 38, 3, which shows that by th=s gnw/mhs k.t.l. is meant ‘engraved on the heart rather than in material records.’ The difficulty is to explain the art. with e)/rgou; it is due to sthlw=n above, the records having been referred to in that word. As the memory is carried in men's hearts, it is confined to no particular country.
*to\ eu)/daimon ... to\ de\ e)leu/qeron—predicates, the art. being added because the adj. is used as a noun.

mh\ periora=sqe—‘do not be too anxious about the dangers of war’; the advice is the result of the doctrine ‘happiness is attained by courage,—by retaining a cheerful spirit in peril,’ which cheerfulness Pericles claims to be characteristic of the Athenians as the result of their free institutions (39, 4), and now urges them to retain in the war.

*ou) ga\r—a paradox: misery is identical with cowardice, since cowardice must involve misery. Therefore those who are prosperous must avoid cowardice (i.e. be ready to sacrifice their lives), whereas to those who are already miserable cowardice involves no addition to their misery. This decides the meaning of periora=sqe above.
h( e)nanti/a metabolh\—‘the change from good to bad fortune.’
kinduneu/etai—c. 35, 1.
e)n oi(=s—‘in whose case.’
ma/lista— ‘in comparison with others,’ as often. Cf. c. 49, 1, and ma=llon e(te/rwn. ta\ diafe/ronta—‘the difference.’
*meta\ tou=—cf. I. 6, 5; VI. 65, 1. ‘Cowardice and disgrace together.’
ka/kwsis—=h( e)nanti/a metabolh\ above, according to the doctrine that cowardice is misery, and therefore to the prosperous involves degradation: ka/kwsis: tapei/nwsis Hesych.
meta\ r(w/mhs—‘when he is fired by courage and the general hope,’ viz. that his side will win.
a)nai/sqhtos— ‘painless.’

*dio/per—‘This is the reason why,’ viz. because in their death they were eu)dai/mones, or, as he says presently, eu)tuxei=s. nu=n—belongs to tw=nde=tw=n nu=n qaptome/nwn, and inserted because since the gnw/mh with which 43, 3 opened, Pericles had been generalising.
toke/as—poetical, for gone/as. pa/reste—contrast e)pi/stantai below: cf. c. 11, 1. It is clear that the Greek orators interchanged direct address and reflection more rapidly than we can do.
polutro/pois—of experiences as varied as those of Odysseus.
to\ d' eu)tuxe\s—sc. e)sti/n; here follows a remarkable definition of eu)tuxi/a. Intr. p. xl. fol.

th=s eu)prepesta/ths—belongs both to teleuth=s and lu/phs. ‘This is good fortune, to have gained an honourable death, like theirs, or an honourable grief, like yours.’ With u(mei=s supply w(/sper. kai\ oi(=s—the change from oi(\ a)\n shows that Pericles is not now speaking generally, but referring to the fallen particularly, so that oi(=s ... cunemetrh/qh=oi(=s a)\n w(/sper toi=sde cummetrhqh=|. e)neudaimonh=sai—=eu)daimonh=sai e)n au)tw=| (i.e. tw=| bi/w|). Infin. of purpose. Intr. p. xli.

e)ntalaipwrh=sai—‘whose life has been meted out to prosper in and to suffer in alike,’ i.e. ‘they may be deemed happy in whose life prosperity and adversity are equally balanced.’ A philosophical definition of human eu)tuxi/a, for which cf. Pindar, Pyth. 7, 20 fanti/ ge ma\n ou(/tw ken a)ndri\ parmoni/man qa/llousan eu)daimoni/an ta\ kai\ ta\ fe/resqai: that man, says Pericles, is happy who has ta\ kai\ ta\ in equal proportions. (Alii alia, says Herw.: those who do not like this explanation will find others elsewhere. Sta. reads e)nteleuth=sai {h( eu)daimoni/a} cun.)

*mh\} poqei=n ... u(pomnh/mata—cf. the Funeral Oration
attributed to Demosth. 16 w(/sper i)/xnh gnwri/zousa nu=n h( tw=n oi)kei/wn au)toi=s kai\ fi/lwn mnh/mh pa=san w(/ran e)pi\ tou/tous fe/retai tw=| po/qw|, po/ll' u(pomnh/mata lamba/nousa. Plat. Rep. I. p. 329 A ta\s e)n th=? neo/thti h(dona\s poqou=ntes kai\ a)namimnh|sko/menoi. Add Andoc. I. 70 ei)/ ti/s ti u(mw=n poqei=. a)nasta\s u(pomnhsa/tw (if A desiderat aliquid which B is able and willing to give to him, A naturally reminds B of it; conversely, if D has something, which C has lost, and cannot give it to C, but cannot help reminding C of it, D naturally feels desiderium, po/qos).
w(=n— = au)tou\s w(=n. kai\ polla/kis—‘only too often.’

eu)tuxi/ais— related to eu)tuxi/a or to\ eu)tuxe/s as tu/xai or ta\ th=s tu/xhs to tu/xh, i.e. the plur. denotes instances of good luck rather than good luck in the abstract. This refers back to to\ eu)tuxe\s above: for, though a man cannot be judged prosperous till after his death, still instances of good luck may of course occur in life, and if these are as frequent as the misfortunes of life, the whole result will be to\ eu)tuxe/s. Cf. Soph. frag. ou) xrh/ pot' eu)= pra/ssontos o)lbi/sai tu/xas | a)ndro/s, pri\n au)tw=| pantelw=s h)/dh bi/os | diekperanqh=| kai\ teleuth/sh| bi/on. Pericles refers especially to the noble deeds of sons who will thus bring joy to their parents. Cf. 43, 4.

ai(=s—cf. Isocr. 14, 47 h)\n w(s eu)= pra/ttontas e)/lqwmen, e)/ti xalepw/teron e)/xomen, ou) tai=s e)kei/nwn fqonou=ntes eu)pori/ais a)lla\ ma=llon e)n toi=s tw=n pe/las a)gaqoi=s ta\s h(mete/ras au)tw=n sumfora\s kaqorw=ntes. lu/ph—sc. e)sti/n, ‘a man feels sorrow, not for the want of blessings which he loses before he knows them.’ w(=n is governed by both partic. and verb.
peirasa/menos—c. 5, 5.

ou(= a)\n—a conspicuous instance of the rule referred to on c. 13, 2; the gen. depends on e)qa/s, while a)faireqh=| would take accus. The change from w(=n to ou(= is another instance of irregularity in the form of rel. clauses.
e)qas—synonym of h)qa)s, Soph. El. 372; both forms appear in the ancient lexica: probably e)qa\s does not occur elsewhere in Attic prose.
*karterei=n—(sometimes joined with u(pome/nein). See c. 61, 2.
te/knwsin p—=paidopoiei=sqai. tw=n ou)k o)/ntwn—=tw=n teqnhko/twn. lh/qh—‘cause of forgetfulness.’

e)/k te .. kai\ a)sfalei/a|—these give the two grounds referred to in dixo/qen; for the variety of construction, cf. c. 36, 4; I. 138, 2, mh\ e)rhmou=sqai, by means of the soldiers and citizens she would acquire; a)sfalei/a|, by the increased anxiety of the parents to benefit the state, as explained in the next sentence.
cunoi/sei—sc. to\ pai=das e)pigi/gnesqai. Cf. c. 3, 3.

i)/son ti h)\ di/kaion—equal, in the sense of ‘democratic,’ conforming to the equality that characterises the Athenian polity; cf. c. 37, 1: just, in the sense of ‘regular’ or ‘sober,’ in accordance with a sane judgment of religion and politics.

e)k tou= o(moi/ou—=o(moi/ws, equally with otbers. Adverbial phrases with e)k and an adj. are common in Thuc., who has e)k tou= profanou=s, e)k tou= fanerou=, e)k tou= eu)qe/os,
e)k tou= ei)ko/tos, e)k tou= eu)prepou=s, e)k tou= ai)sxi/onos, e)k tou= dikai/ou, e)c i)/sou, and others. This one occurs also I. 143, 4, and elsewhere. One or two of these phrases were colloquial, as e)c i)/sou, e)c e(no\s (tro/pou or lo/gou), e)k panto\s (tro/pou) (these are the only ones found in Aristoph.); the rest are formed on the analogy of such simple phrases. The orators use them, but only with common adjectives: Thuc. confines them to speeches and highly-wrought passages. The 8th book contains only three examples.
