paraballo/menoi—discrimini objicientes: a dictionary may here be useful to some. To have children in peril would constitute having a stake in the state.
*parhbh/kate—antithesis to oi(=s e)/ti h(liki/a. ke/rdos— predicate, in an unexpected place, and so emphatic.
to/nde —‘your present life,’ i e. your sorrow will be short-lived, because your lives are drawing to a close.
to\ filo/timon— ‘love of honour,’ which would be gratified in their case, as they would be honoured on account of their children's fame.
e)n tw=| a)xrei/w| th=s h(liki/as—cf. c. 40, 2, = e)n tw=| gh/ra|. to\ kerdai/nein ... to\ tima=sqai—a true description of the ‘last infirmity’ of base and noble minds respectively.
*me/gan to\n a)gw=na—‘the struggle to emulate them will be a difficult one.’ The partic. is omitted after o(rw=. Cf. c. 49, 5. [

to
 ga .. e)painei=n]— the general statement, paisi\ d' au)=, is continued and explained in kai\ mo(lis a)
 ... kriqei=te. Then follows the reason in fqo/nos ga k.t.l. kaq' u(perbolh
 a)reth=s—‘by pre-eminent virtue.’ For kata/ cf. c. 27, 2.

a)ll'—would more naturally be a)lla\ kai/. fqo/nos—cf. Demosth 18, 315 ti/s ga\r ou)k oi)=den, o(/ti toi=s me\n zw=si pa=sin u(/pesti/ tis h)\ plei/wn h)\ e)la/ttwn fqo/nos, tou\s teqnew=tas d' ou(de\ tw=n e)xqrw=n tis misei=; toi=s zw=si pro\s to\ a)nti/palon—‘envy towards a rival attacks the living.’
pro\s—adversus (so Grundstrom and Golisch: Sta. propter).

to\ a)nti/palon— for tou\s a)ntipa/lous. to\ mh\ e)mpodw\n—=to\ mhke/t' e)mpodw/n. Cf. tw=n ou)k o)/ntwn c. 44, 3. This is the antithesis to toi=s zw=si, while a)nantagwni/stw| eu)noi/a| corresponds to pro\s to\ a)nti/palon, and teti/mhtai to fqo/nos. a)nantagwni/stw|—‘without opposition.’
teti/mhtai—gnomic perf., according to Goodwin; but may be the Homeric use of this word, with pres. sense.
*(/osai—as if gunaikw=n instead of gunaikei/as preceded.
e)/sontai—contrast pa/reste above. Cf. c. 44, 1.

u(parxou/shs—by no means attributing weakness, but referring to the restraints and household duties which nature imposed on women. Pericles refers to the Spartan women, who, according to Aristotle, lived a very different life from the stern asceticism of the Spartan men.

kai\ h(=s—i.e. kai\ mega/lh e)stin
h\ do/ca tau/ths h(=s. mega/lh h( do/ca—cf. VII. 68 to\ tou/sde kolasqh=nai ... kalo\s o( a)gw/n. kle/os—‘talk,’ a neutral word. Cf. Aesch. Ag. 611, Clyt. says ou)k oi)=da te/ryin ou)d' e)pi/yogon fa/tin | a)/llou pro\s a)ndro/s.

*ei)/rhtai—the act. or pass perf. is often used thus in bringing a speech to a close (Lys 12, the case referred to by Aristotle at the close of the Rhet. is an example; so probably Eur. Hec. 236. Cf. dixi.) Hence it is made prominent.

kai\ e)moi\—Shil. rightly explains this as connected with kai\ e)/rgw|, the sense being kai\ lo/gw| e)moi\ ei)/rhtai kai\ e)/rgw| oi( q. keko/smhntai. ‘I have done my duty in delivery of the oration, the city has in deed partly done hers and is prepared to do more.’

kata\ to\n no/mon .. pro/sfora—a modest description of what had been a metaphysical exposition of the relation of politics to character. Cf. Burke, Reflections, ‘I am unable to distinguish what I have learned from others from the results of my own meditation.’
au)tw=n—cf. c. 27, 1. Its position gives it the force of a dat. of interest.
me/xri h(/bhs—to the age of eighteen.

qre/yei—of people) (bo/skein of cattle. bo/skein is only used of people contemptuously, except by Herod., and Thuc., who uses the word once, VII. 48 nautiko\n polu\ bo/skontas: even there the notion of irksomeness comes in.
w)fe/limon—something more than a mere distinction.
toi=sde—the fallen, toi=s leipome/nois ‘the survivors,’ as in 41, 5.
a)gw/nwn—with ste/fanon, like tropai=on ma/xhs. protiqei=sa—‘offering.’
oi(=s—in general relation to the whole, ‘among whom.’
toi=s de\—cf. c. 65, 5, de\ in apodosis.

)*apolofura/menoi—the o)lo/fursis was part of the regular ceremony, and took place at the conclusion of the speech. [Lys.] Epitaph. end, a)na/gkh toi=s a)rxai/ois e)/qesi xrh=sqai, kai\ qerapeu/ontas to\n pa/trion no/mon o)lofu/resqai tou\s qaptome/nous. The Menex. ends thus, tou\s teteleuthko/tas a)polofura/menoi a)/pite, and [Demosth.] Epitaph. a)podura/menoi ... a)/pite. ‘When you have finished (probably aor., as Sta. says, not a)po-, gives this force) your lamentation.’

prosh/kei—sc. a)polofuresqai. a)poxwrei=te—Intr. p. xxxii. There is no doubt about the reading because xwrei=n was much less familiar to the copyists than i)e/nai, and the scholia sometimes explain the former by the latter.
*toio/sde—see c. 41, 2. Late authors make no dis- tinction between these pronouns.
ta/fos—contrast the meaning in 34, 4.
e)ge/neto—pass. of tafa\s e)poih/santo, c. 34, 1.
prw=ton—Thuc. never inserts the art. in these formulae.

*ta\ du/o me/rh—limiting apposition. The arrangements for the campaign are exactly the same as tbose of the pre
ceding year, though the Spartans now knew that the Athenians would not offer battle. It is clear therefore that Sparta too saw that the only hope was to wear Athens out. Cf. Intr. p. lxx.
kaqezo/menoi—c. 18, 1.

*(h no/sos—‘the famous plague.’ The account (c. 47-54) falls into three parts, (i) its origin (47, 48), (ii) symptoms and effects on sufferers (49, 50), (iii) effects on morality (51, etc.). This description has been imitated by many writers, as Lucretius VI. 1138-1251 who is in turn imitated by Vergil, Georg. III, 478 and Ovid, Met. VII. 523), Procopius, Persica II, 22, who describes the plague at Constantinople in Justinian's reign, A.D. 542, and John Cantacuzene, Emperor of the Eastern Empire, who described very poorly the great plague of 1347 with which the plague of Florence described by Boccaccio and the ‘Black Death’ in England are connected. Superstitious horror, followed by demoralisation, is common to all great plagues.
prw=ton h)/rcato—cf. c. 36, 1, 48, 1.

gene/sqai—the phrase occurs also I. 103 to\ mi=sos h)/rcato gene/sqai, c. 68, 2, III. 18 o( xeimw\n h)/rxeto gi/gnesqai, Isocr. 15, 82 h)/rxeto to\ ge/nos to\ tw=n a)nqrw/pwn gi/gnesqai, Andoc. 2, 9 h)/rxeto gi/gnesqai dusdaimone)steros. The tense of gi/gnomai must be the same as that of a)/rxomai; yet h)/rcato pra)ssein is good Greek, though h)/rxeto pra=cai is not (the reason is that gi/gnomai is inceptive, while pra/ssw is not, so that h)/rcato gi/gnesqai would be a contradiction in terms; thus h)/rcato gignw/skein would not do).
lego/menon—as though no/shma had preceded.
e)gkataskh=yai —Soph. O. T. 27 e)n d' o( purfo/ros qeo/s | skh/yas e)lau/nei, loimo\s e)/xqistos pa/lin. peri\—circa: c. 7, 3.
ou(/tws—with gene/sqai. e)mnhmoneu/eto—anacoluthon. as lego/menon me\n preceded. (Observe that this is not a solecism.) Cf. c. 65, 11.
*to\ prw=ton—with qerapeu/ontes, ‘as they treated it at first with no knowledge of its nature.’

ma/lista .. o(/sw| kai\ ma/lista—i.e. the mortality among them was greater than among any other class because they came in contact with the disease more than others. For the double superl. or compar. in proportion, cf. I. 68 prosh/kei h(ma=s ou)x h(/kista ei)pei=n, o(sw| kai\ me/gista e)gklh/mata e)/xomen, III. 45 ou)x h(=sson ta\s po/leis, o(/sw| peri\ megi/stwn, V. 90 pro\s u(mw=n ou)x h(=sson tou=to, o(/sw| kai\ e)pi\ megi/sth| timwri/a| a)\n para/deigma ge/noisqe. Cf. also c. 11, 1 kai\ e)pi\ po/lin dunatwta/thn ... kai\ au)toi\ plei=stoi e)rxo/meqa. pro\s i(eroi=s—ad loca sacra; cf. c. 87, 6, 94, 4.
i(ke/teusan—the aor. sums up all the instances (complexive).
e)xrh/santo—sc. o(/sa, which with i(ke/teusan=o(/sas i(ketei/as, but with e)xrh/santo=peri\ o(/sa. See L. and S. xra/w A. III.
te—does not belong to the preceding te, which added a third fact to ou)/te ou)/te, but=‘and so.’

u(po\ tou= kakou=—cf. 51, 1; but contrast 60, 6 xrh/masi nikw/menos. The verbs which commonly have u(po\ with things in prose are
such as nikw=mai, bla/ptomai, diafqei/romai, a)nagka/zomai, h(ttw=mai, pei/qomai (Isaeus only has pei/qomai and diafqei/romai, Lysias only a)nagka)zomai, e)pai/romai, dia)keimai) and the things so used must be such as can be easily personified, such as (1) natural phenomena, as xeimw/n, seismo/s, a)/ploia, (2) external circumstances, as ki/ndunos, sumfora/, plhgai/, desmoi/, ke/rdos, xrh/mata, no/mos, (3) emotions, as h(don h/, fqo/nos, (4) words which imply a person, as lo/goi, pra/gmata, du/namis, when the person is often inserted (as in u(po\ th=s tou= r(h/toros deno/thtos), and all the topics of rhetoric as u(po\ tw=n ei)ko/twn, u(po\ tou= dikai/ou. The construction is optional in these cases, as the following examples show: Aristoph. Av. 1438 pa)ntes toi=s lo/gois a)napterou=ntai, ib. 1447 u(po\ lo/gwn e)pai/retai; Isocr. 5, 40 ta\s po/leis w(malisme/nas u(po\ tw=n sumforw=n, 6, 65 w(malisme/noi tai=s sumforai=s.
*)/hrcato—sc. to\ kako/n. u(pe\r—beyond, i.e. further inland, ‘south of.’ So the plague in Justinian's reign was said to have come from Ethiopia and Egypt: the ‘Black Death’ was traced to the Levant.
th\n pollh/n—limiting apposition.
*)en tw=| *peiraiei=—it was imported, as in the case of the plague under Justinian.
fa/rmaka—so in Germany and England in 1349 the Jews were supposed to have poisoned the wells. The plague had broken out a few days after the Peloponnesians invaded Attica.
fre/ata—‘cisterns,’ for rainwater.
krh=nai—see c. 15, 5.
ou)/pw—probably the astronomer Meton suggested them in 414 B.C.
*)af' o(/tou—cf. 49, 2, 62, 4, 68, 2. Contrast the phrase e)c o(/tou=‘since which time.’
ei)ko\s h)=n—c. 10, 1.

ta\s ai)ti/as— = ta\s ai)ti/as tosau/ths metabolh=s, a(/stinas uomi/zei i(kana\s ei)=nai. In the adscript, du/namin sxei=n was meant to explain i(kana\s ei)=nai, e)s to\ metasth=sai to explain metabolh=s. (To the list of those who bracket here, which is given in the not. crit., add Hampke, Studien, p. 16).

a)f' w(=n ... skopw=n —take tau=ta below with a)f' w(=n,=the symptoms, by which it might be recognised in future. Cf. I. 21, 2 a)p' au)tw=n tw=n e)/rgwn skopou=si, III. 38, 4 a)po\ tw=n eu)= ei)po/ntwn skopou=ntes. a)/n— belongs to e)/xoi, cf. c. 41, 1.
*)/etos—Intr. p. xlii.

w(mologei=to e)k pa/ntwn—the other places in Thuc. in which e)k = u(po\ are I. 20, 2; III. 69, 1; V. 104; VI. 36, 2. The use is not found in Aristoph., and there are but very faint and doubtful traces of it in the orators. This use is Ionic, but occurs now and then in Attic (though Shil. denies the use altogether). o(mologou=mai often has para\ instead of u(po\ (Andoc. 1, 140; Lysias, 30, 12; Isaeus, 1, 38 and 42; 2, 16 and 40; 4. 15; 11, 10; Demosth. 34, 5; Dinarch. 1, 53 and 90; 3, 8), in Demosth. 29, 20 o(mologei=sqai
has pro/s; in Isaeus 5, 17 we have a(\ w(mologh/qh h(mi=n: so Plat Phaedo, p. 106 C.

proe/kamne—viz. before the plague established itself. Contrast the opt. and imperf. in c. 51, 1, where Thuc. uses the indef. form because he speaks of a long period of time, whereas here he refers to a definite moment, viz. just before the plague broke out.
a)pekri/qh—‘determined in this,’ i.e. ‘the symptoms eventually assumed the character of the disease.’ All who were ailing before were attacked.

*tou\s d' a)/llous—when once an epidemic has esta- blished itself, it shows itself ‘suddenly and without ostensible cause’ (Collier). These words must not be so pressed as to admit of no exceptions whatever; exceptions are mentioned in c. 51, 1.
prw=ton me\n—first stage; intense heat in head, inflammation in eyes, bleeding from throat and tongue, fetid breath, and, after these symptoms, sneezing and hoarseness.
a)/topon—cf. c. 51, 1, ‘unnatural.’
h)fi/ei—both a)fi/ei and h)fi/ei are Attic.
fa/rugc—see not. crit.: ancient grammarians were not agreed on the orthography. Herodian says fa/ruc, Hesych. fa/rugc.
*)ec au)tw=n—after the symptoms just described. See c. 4, 2.
ptarmo\s—due to inflammation of the mucous membrane.

kai\ e)n ou) pollw=|—second stage: the disease attacks the chest, the consequence of the passage of the morbid action along the membrane that lines the respiratory organ being violent coughing. For e)n ou) pollw=| contrast c. 41, 3.
po/nos—‘the disorder.’

o(po/te—third stage: the disease, on reaching the stomach, caused vomiting and great distress, and, in most cases, ineffectual retching; then the skin turned livid, and broke out in vesicles which degenerated into ulcers. Then came the crisis.
kardi/an—‘stomach.’
sthri/ceien— intrans., a medical use.
a)pokaqa/rseis—‘vomits of bile.’

o(/sai—evidently referring to different terms used to denote the various colours that bile has in different diseases, or stages of a disease; e.g. in cholera, the bile is first dark brown, then light green. Probably, as Grote says, Thuc. was acquainted with medical terms.

u(po\ i)atrw=n w)nomasme/nai—though the subject is non-personal, yet, if it be a nom, or fem. noun, it is not uncommon to find the agent with the perf. pass. expressed by u(po/, instead of by the regular dat.: see on c. 29, 3.
talaipwri/as—‘distress’ (tenesmus): a medical term.

*lu/gc—rendered ‘retching,’ but Collier says it should be ‘hiccough,’ because the hiccough is an important symptom of deadly maladies, especially of those which affect the membrane of parts within the chest. But (1) this leaves kenh\ unexplained, (2) the disease described is now unknown.
e)ndidou=sa— ‘producing,’ the same use of e)n as in e)mpoiw=, e)nti/qhmi. meta\
tau=ta—after the previous symptoms (see third stage).

lwfh/santa—with meta\ tau=ta. Cf. c. 2, 1. lwfa=:| pau/etai Hesych., cf. Plat. Phaedrus, 251 C lwfa=| th=s o)du/nhs (Collier takes this with spasmo/n, as do some edd., but this would require lwfw=nta to match e)ndidou=sa).
*to\ me\n e)/cwqen—adverbial, e)/cwqen being for e)/cw. Cf. c. 13, 7.
a(ptome/nw|—with qermo\n h)=n, ‘to the touch.’
sw=ma —for absence of art. cf. 8 below.
xlwro/n—‘pale.’
flu/ktainai—transparent vesicles, little blains which degenerate into sores.

ta\ de\ e)nto\s—the a)kmh\ of the disease is now reached. It came in the third stage, and was marked by internal fever, intolerable thirst, and sleeplessness: yet the body was scarcely weakened by its suffering.
mh/te— answered by h(/dista/ te. ta\s e)pibola\s—for the order, cf. 18, 1.
mhd'—not connected with mh/te, but only joins e)pibola\s to a)/llo ti h)\ and with it=nec nisi; cf. c. 16, 2.

gumnoi\—the nom. is justified by ta\ e)nto/s, part of themselves, With gumnoi\ supply o)/ntes. Cf. c. 45, 1 o(rw= me/gan to
 a)gw=na. So with tugxa)nw c. 87, 5, fai/nesqai c. 39, 4. In the two cases in which Thuc. uses diatelw= with adj., he omits w)/n (I. 34; VI. 89); contrast VII. 38 paraskeuazo/menoi diete/lesan. h(/dista a)
—i.e. h(/dist' a)
 e)/rripton, lit. ‘so as to have thrown themselves (had they been allowed).’ The infin. with a)
 is not common with w)/ste. M. T. 211, 592.
kai\ polloi\— ‘and in fact.’ Cf. c. 2, 4.

e)/drasan—cf. c. 11, 8. Here = sfa=s au)tou\s e)/rriyan. th=| di/yh| a)pau/stw|—the adj., being pred., is emphatic, as always; ‘which was unceasing.’ (There are not many examples quite like this in Thuc.: I. 49 e(ne/prhsan ta\s skhna\s e)rh/mous, c. 13, 5 ta\ xrh/mata ou)k o)li/ga, IV. 122 th=| i)sxu/i a)nwfelei= pisteu/ontes, and VII. 70, 6).

to\ ple/on kai\ e)/lasson—the art. omitted with e)/lasson, though the two things are mutually exclusive, as in I. 10 ta\s megi/stas kai\ e)laxi/stas. h( a)pori/a tou= mh\—the infin. after a noun, as in c. 60, 7 ai)ti/an tou= a)dikei=n. The mh\ is added because the whole result is neg., as often. Plat. Apol. p. 38 D a)pori/a| ... tou= mh\ e)qe/lein, ‘the neg. being added as after other neg. or prohibitive words’ (Shil.). Andoc. 2, 12 ki/ndunos peri\ tou= mhde\ au)tou\s swqh=nai, ‘a risk lest not even they should be saved.’ See also c. 62, 3; III. 75, 4 h( tou= mh\ cumplei=n a)pisti/a.
)*epe/keito—instabat; cf. c. 59, 1.
o(/sonper kai\— like w(/sper kai/, the kai\ merely making the two things parallel.
a)kma/zoi—iterative, in a rel. clause. Cf. VII. 70, 5 o(/son xro/non prosfe/roito nau=s. M. T. 521.
w(/ste—the result is in the partic. e)/ti e)/xontes, not in diefqei/ronto: this inversion of partic. and verb is very common.

oi( plei=stoi—belongs only to diefqei/ronto, a new subject oi( polloi\ (most of the minority who did not die on the 7th or 9th day) being inserted
in the next clause.
kai\ e(bdomai=oi—the main emphasis is on this, the second member, as constantly in Greek.
u(po\ tou= kau/matos—c. 47, 4.
ti duna/mews—cf. I. 5, 1 ti kai\ do/chs, III. 44, 2 e)xonta/s ti cuggnw/mhs. diafu/goien—‘pulled through.’

e)pikatio/ntos—fourth stage, only reached by comparatively few, marked by ulceration of the bowels, after the internal fever had abated; then followed violent dysentery, leaving the patient so weak that he generally died.
a)pefqei/ronto —poetical word. See not. crit.
*)en th=| kefalh=| p. i(druqe\n—Kr. thinks this an adscript, and is followed by F. Muller.
tw=n ge—effects seen in the convalescents ‘a seizure of the extremities remained as a mark (of the disease)’.
a)nti/lhyis—for e)pi/skhyis. Elsewhere a). = an objection to an argument, as Plat. Phaedo p. 87 A. [

au)tou=]—if the conjecture au)to\ = to\ perigene/sqai, it clearly involves a contradiction, since Thuc. is giving the signs of the disease before the recovery, but it might stand in the sense of to\ kako/n. e)pesh/maine—absolute, cf. c. 8, 3, 43, 3. Cf. Eur. Hec. 1215.
*)es ai)doi=a—art. omitted, as often with parts of the body.
parauti/ka a)nasta/ntas—‘immediately on their recovery.’ The loss of memory was temporary.
h)gno/hsan —aor., giving the result of the imperf. e)la/mbane.
*krei=sson lo/gou—cf. c. 41, 3, but here = ‘not to be described.’
xalepwte/rws—see e)ndeeste/rws 35, 2.
h)\ kata\ —quam pro.
e)dh/lwse .. o)\n—cf. v. 9 dei/cw ou) paraine/sai oi(=o/s te w)/n. For the aor. cf. c. 51, 5.
a)/ptetai—cf. c. 48, 2.
a)tu/fwn—see c. 52.
*tekmh/rion de/—see c. 15, 4: only here without ga\r fol- lowing.
a)/llws—‘at all,’ after peri\ toiou=ton. peri\ toiou=ton —i.e. peri\ ta\ sw/mata. ai)/sqhsin parei=xon—‘gave an opportunity of observing the effect’ (on animals).
a)pobai/nontos —cf. c. 87, 3 a)poba/nti, the imperf. being used here of the repeated result. In c. 11, 9 the plur was used, pres. partic. of the result as it will affect each man.

*paralipo/nti—as a(ptome/nw| 49, 5, u(perba/nti 96, 1. a)topi/as—‘omitting many peculiarities,’ polla\ a)topi/as being like me/ga i)sxi/os 97, 4, and the common expressions ei)s tosou=to, ei)s tou=to with gen., as Demosth. 21, 62 ei)s tosou=t' a)naidei/as a)fi/keto. Cf. c. 17, 4.
diafero/ntws—lit. differently to one as compared with another, i.e. peculiarities ‘which marked individual cases.’ pro\s=‘compared with,’ as in 62, 3.
e)pi\ pa=n—cf. e)pi\ me/ga 76, 4, e)pi\ plei=ston 34, 8, 35, 3; translate with th\n i)de/an, ‘its general nature.’ epi\ is local.
i)se/an— contrast the meaning in c. 19, 1.

parelu/pei—para- denotes simultaneous action or intrusion on something more important.
Cf. Plat. Phaedo 65 C logi)zetai ka/llista o(/tan au)th\n tou/twn mhde\n paraluph=|. Cf. parenoxlei=n. kat' e)kei=non—i. e. throughout the time that the plague lasted.
ge)noito—contrast the mood in 49, 1: here the general form is required by the sense. Cf. 49, 6.
*)amelei/a|—causal, some might have been saved had they been treated.
qerapeuo/menoi—‘in spite of’ etc.

e(/n te ou)de\ e(
—a very strong neg., for which cf. Demosth. 23, 70 e(
 ou)d' o(tiou=n tou/twn, and for ou)de
 resolved, Andoc. 1, 29 ou)/te mei=zon ou)/t' e)/latton ou)de\ e(/n. w(s ei)pei=n—qualifies the universal statement Shil. remarks that Thuc. never writes w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n o(/ ti xrh=n prosfe/rontas—i.e. o(/ ti xrh=n prosfe/rein w(/ste w)felei/n. The partic. really belongs to xrh=n. This irregularity is found also with dei=. Kr. Gr. Gr. 56, 10, 5.

prosfe/rontas —a medical term, to interfere with the course of a malady, etc., by any means. Cf. Plat. Phaedo 63 D dei=n ou)de\n toiou=ton prosfe/rein tw=| farma/kw|. tou=to—c. 53, 3 o(/ ti h)/dh h(du\ ... tou=to k.t.l., 64, 6. This ‘epanaleptic’ ou(=tos is commonest after relative clauses, as Isaeus, 1, 28 *klew/numos o(\s h)=n h(mi=n oi)keio/tatos ... ou(=tos k.t.l., but at any rate in colloquial Attic it was freely used even when no rel. preceded.
*)isxu/os pe/ri—cf. c. 62, 1, ‘as regards physical strength or weakness,’ i.e. ‘whether strong or weak.’
cunh/|rei—subject au)to/ = to\ no/shma.

*deino/taton—pred. to (a) a)qumi/a, (b) o)/ti .. e)/qnh?skon. pollw=| ma=llon—sc. h)\ diefqei/ronto u(po\ tou= kakou=, because the worst possible thing to do in illness is to lose hope: they abandoned themselves to despair and really threw their lives away, instead of resisting.

a)f' e(te/rou q.— = a)po\ tou= e(/teron qerapeu=sai. a)napimpla/menoi—the technical word for taking infection. Cf. Plat. Phaedo, p. 67 A mh\ a)napimplw/meqa th=s tou/tou fu/sews. So a)naple(ws, infected, ib. p. 83 D.
tou=to— i.e. the contagion, because (a) the fear of catching the disease caused neglect of the sick, (b) while those who attended the sick caught it.

*mh\ qe/loien—according to the MSS., which are quite worthless in such a case, the orators said mh\ qe/lein and mh\ e)qe/lein indiscriminately Shil. prints )qe/loien here; so some other edd. after mh\. It is probable that e)qe/lw is, after all, the invariable prose form. (See Rutherford, New Phryn. p. 416, Meisterhans, p. 142.)
a)pw/llunto ... e)kenw/qh?san—the complexive aor. again gives the result of the verb in imperf. Cf. c. 50, 1.
tou= qerapeu/sontos—cf. Aesch. Prom. V. 27 o( lwfh/swn ga\r ou) pe/fuke/ pw. The art. refers to no person in particular. Kr. Gr. Gr. 50, 4, 3. The fut. partic. with art. is not common. M. T. 826.

a)reth=s— = filanqrwpi/as. Cf.
c. 40, 4.
ai)sxu/nh|—cf. c. 43, 1.

o)lofu/rseis—the complorationes over those who died: friends had to go because relatives actually wearied even of performing the proper offices for the dead. The kai\ before o)lofu/rseis shows that having already neglected to attend to their sick, they also took no notice of them when they died.
tw=n a)pogignome/nwn—cf. c. 34, 2. The imperf. is used of the constant deaths, as a)pw/llunto etc. above.
e)ce/kamnon—‘wearied of,’ so a)poka/mn ein occasionally.
u(po\ . . nikw/menoi—c. 47, 4.
*)epi\ ple/on—c. 35, 3. Thuc. uses this expression about a dozen times in this sense (ma=llon).
ponou/menon—cf. c. 49, 3.
e)n tw=| qarsale/w| ei)=nai—cf. c. 60 e)n i)/sw| (ei)=nai), III. 22, 6 e)n a)po/rw| ei)=nai, and many others.
kou/fhs—‘vain,’ because a)\n diafqarh=nai implies ‘if they fell ill with any other disease.’ They fancied that they could only die of old age.
u(p' a)/llou .. diafqarh=nai—see on c. 47, 4.
*)epi/ese .. h( cugkomidh\—the in version makes both emphatic.

h( cugkomidh\ e)k tw=n a)—for the art. not repeated before the prep., cf. c. 18, 3, 38, 1. (a) The noun or adj. must be connected with a verb which takes the construction used with it (komi/zomai e)k tw=n a).) to admit of this inversion of the order, (b) if the words which are inverted precede (see on c. 7, 2), the object is to produce an antithesis; but if, as more commonly, they follow the noun or adj., it is merely for the sake of convenience.
ou)x h(=sson— = ma=llon.

*kalu/bais—Aristoph. (see c. 17, 1) says e)n tai=s piqa/knaisi kai\ gupari/ois kai\ purgidi/ois. w(/ra| e)/tous—Suidas gives w(/ra e)/tous: to\ e)/ar kai\ to\ qe/ros, and rightly takes w(/ra to denote the best time, as we use ‘the season.’
ou)deni\ ko/smw| —it may be judged from tragedy how important the Greeks thought it to make a graceful exit from the world.
a)lla\ kai\ —expresses ou)deni\ ko/smw| in a positive form. [

a)poqnh/|skontes] —a gloss on h(miqnh=tes. (It is not possible to take this as imperf. partic., like a)pogignome/nwn in 51, 5, since not nekroi\ a)poqnh/|skontes, but nekroi\ a)poqnh|sko/ntwn would be necessary; for nekro\s a)pe/qanen could not be right) kalindou/menoi—kalindou=mai is figurative in meaning) (kuli/ndomai is literal.
*)enapoqnh|sko/ntwn—gen. abs. ‘men dying there.’

e)/xontes — = ei)do/tes. o(/ ti—cf. Eur. Or. 418 douleu/omen qeoi=s, o)/ ti pot' ei)si
 oi( qeoi). i(erw=n kai\ o(si/wn—cf. Isocr. 7, 66 th
 dhmokrati/an kos mh/sasan th
 po/lin kai\ toi=s i(eroi=s kai\ toi=s o)si/ois, and 53, 4 qew=n fo/bos h)\ a)nqrw/pwn no/mos.
*qh/kas—for tafa/s, ‘modes of burial.’ This meaning is sufficiently proved by Sta., who quotes Plat. Rep. 427 B.

e)pithdei/wn—neut., whatever was required for the burning and
burial.
e)pi\ pura\s—governed both by e)piqe/ntes and e)pibalo/ntes. For e)pi\ pura\s ... e(piqe/ntes . . u(fh=pton, see c. 13, 2.
o(\n fe/roien—M. T. 522.
*prw=ton h)=rce—cf. c. 36, 1.
kai\—besides those instances of a)nomi/a just mentioned.
e)pi\ ple/on—cf. c. 51, 1, ‘to a greater extent’ (than ever before), since the ai)sxu/nh which followed the breach of the a)/grafoi no/moi (c. 37, 3) was no longer felt.
a)nomi/as—governed by h(=rce. a)pekru/pteto mh\—c. 49, 5.
kaq' h(donh\n—as 37, 2, but with a bad sense.
a)gxi/strofon—Ionic word, not found elsewhere in Attic prose.
metabolh\n—43, 5.

o(rw=ntes—plur., though tis precedes, as after e(/kastos, e(/teros, pa=s, ou)dei/s. tw=n t'—the te is answered by kai\ before ou)de/n, and each pair is introduced by a single tw=n, since eu)daimo/nwn . qnh|sko/ntwn apply to one set of persons, kekthme/nwn . . e)xo/ntwn to another set.
*)epaure/seis—Ionic for a)polau/seis, which Thuc. also uses, c. 38, 42. It was revived by late writers from Aristotle onwards: Andocides uses it once.

pro\s to\ terpno\n—cf. c. 65, 8 pro\s h(donh/n ti le/gein. e)pau/resis is the advantage, gain, or good to be got out of any act: generally it is neither immediately realised, nor does it take the form of mere sensual enjoyment; but now honourable ambition and forethought no longer prompted action.

*to\ me
 protalaipwrei=n—the art. and inf. depend, as accus of respect, on pro/qumos h)=n. The purpose of the art, is to contrast the two clauses introduced by me
 ... de/, since below o(/ ti de\ h)/dh h(du\ = to\ de\ h)/dh h(du/. Cf. c. 87, 5, VI. 17 to\ me
 e)s th
 gh=n e)sba/llein, ikanoi/ ei)si, tw=| de\ nautikw=| ou)k a)
 du/nainto bla/ptein. tw=| do/canti kalw=|—‘for the sake of what seemed honourable’; cf. VIII. 63 ou)ke/ti a)/llois h)\ sfi/sin au)toi=s talaipwrou=ntas. tw=| do/canti kalw=| differs from tw=| kalw=| in that the former denotes that no man had the will to strive after that which he himself conceived to be good; much less would he trouble himself about Good as a principle One reflected, tou=to/ moi dokei= kalo
 ei)=nai, a)lla\ pri
 e)p' au)to\ e)lqei=n diafqarhsomai. (There is probably no reference here to good as universally admitted, as some have supposed: do/can applies to individual cases.)

nomi/zwn—the partic. again appended somewhat freely to the preceding clause. Cf. 1 above and 4 below. Here not ou)dei\s but e(/kastos must be supplied: somewhat similar is VI. 27 tou\s dra/santas h)/|dei ou)dei/s, a)lla\ . . e)zhtou=nto kai\ prose/ti e)yhfi/santo (sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi); IV. 59 ou)dei\s ... h)\n (sc. tis) oi)/htai/ ti ple/on sxh/sein, a)potre/petai, VI. 84 u(pola/bh| mhdei\s w(s ou)de\n prosh=kon u(mw=n kh?do/meqa, gnou\s o(/ti k.t.l. h)/dh te h(du\ kai\— te ... kai\ = sive .. sive, the first clause answering to sw/mata, the second to xrh/mata in 2 above.

pantaxo/qen to\ e)s au)to\ kerdale/on— = (o(/ ti)
pantaxo/qen e)s to\ h)/dh h(du\ kerdale)on h)=n, ‘or contributed to the pleasure of the moment, regardless of the source from which it was obtained,’ i.e. men did not care how disgraceful were the means by which they strove to gratify their immediate desires. The sanctity of oaths and contracts was no longer respected; for the sake of gain fraud and crime became kalo\n kai\ xrh/simon, and what was gained was immediately squandered.
pantaxo/qen—cf. Intr. p. xl.: all means, good or bad, were alike to them.
tou=to—cf. c. 51, 2.

kalo\n—1st Cor. 15, 32 fa/gwmen kai\ pi/wmen: au)/rion ga\r a)poqnh/skomen. (Thuc. does not say they really thought these base things kalo/n: it was not to\ do/can kalo\n that changed, but to\ kaqesthko\s kalo/n. The public standard of morality is a very different thing from what each man in his heart thinks moral.)

*to\ me\n—‘on the one hand,’ answered by de/, instead of to\ de/. kri/nontes—anacoluthon, as though the preceding clause had been pass. = u(p' ou)deno\s no/mou a)pei/rgonto. Such a slight irregularity is not uncommon in Thuc. and tragedy, as Eur. Hec. 971 ai)dw/s m' e)/xei ... tugxa/nousa. Cf. III. 36 e)/docen au)toi=s . e)pikalou=ntes. (Shil. quotes IV. 108, as a ‘still bolder anacoluthon.’ But the cases are almost certainly wrong there. As ei)wqo/tes k.t.l. is clearly general, prob. the gen. abs. should be read.)
e)n o(moi/w|—cf. c. 49, 5, 61 e)n i)/sw| dikaiou=n, 60 e)n i)/sw| (e)sti/).
kai\ mh\—sc. se/bein. e)lpi/zwn—cf. c. 11, 6; had a plur. been nearer and ou)dei\s not so near, Thuc. would have written e)lpi/zontes, as VII. 28, 3.
me/xri tou=—so v. 73, 4.

biou\s a)
—the a)
 belongs also to a)ntidou=nai, = biw=nai a)
 kai\ a)ntidou=nai. timwri/an—with tw=n a\marthma/twn. The art. and a)ntidou=nai shows that they sinned well knowing that retribution awaited them if they lived. With the general description, cf. St. Matthew, XXIV. 12, where Christ speaks of the destruction of Jerusalem, dia\ to\ plhqunqh=nai th
 a)nomi/an yugh/setai h( a)gaph\ tw=n pollw=n. polu\ de\—sc nomi/zontes, and for the interchange of words of saying and thinking which have to be supplied from the context, cf. c. 13. kateyhfisme/nhn—sc. timwri/an, i.e. no/son. h(
 ... ei)=nai—cf. c. 13, 5, 24, 2, 102, 5.
ei)ko\s —c. 10, 1.

*toiou/tw| me\n—the description is now concluded, the following particulars heing added as an afterthought (a) to illustrate the superstition rife at the time, (b) to indicate the locale of the plague.
peripeso/ntes—cf. c. 59, 2, and the phrase, sumfora=| peripesei=n, constantly occurring in the orators.
*)en—‘during,’ though kako\n is not temporal. Cf. c. 63, 1.
oi(=a ei)ko/s—cf. c. 5, 4, and w(s ei)ko/s VIII. 2, 3.
e)/pous —‘verse,’ 41, 4.
oi( presbu/teroi—limiting apposition. Cf. 4, 2, 11, 1, 16, 1, 21, 3.

h(/cei
—common in prophecies, Eur. Sup. 1222 pikroi\ ga\r au)toi=s h(/cet' e)kteqramme/noi | sku/mnoi leo/ntwn. St. Matt. XXIV. 14 to/te h(/cei to\ te/los. po/lemos kai\ loimo\s—there is intentional paromoi/wsis here, as often in oracles. The change of limo\s to loimo\s would be suggested by Il. 1, 61 ei) dh\ o(mou= po/lemo/s te dama=| kai\ loimo\s *)axaiou/s, and Hesiod, W. and D. 242 me/g' e)ph/gage ph=ma *kroni/wn | limo\n o(mou= kai\ loimo/n.
*)wnoma/sqai—‘that famine, and not pestilence had been the original word.’ (This translation is imperfect because it introduces a comparatively modern association.)
u(po\ tw=n palaiw=n—might have been dat.
e)pi\ tou= paro/ntos—cf. e)pi\ tw=| paro/nti c. 36, 4. The gen. is more distinctly temporal = ‘at the moment.’
pro\s a(\ e)/pasxon—cf. VI. 34 tw=n a)nqrw/pwn pro\s ta\ lego/mena kai\ ai( gnw=mai i(/stantai. mnh/mhn e)poiou=nto— act. of mnh/mh e)ge/neto in 4 below, and = a)nemnh/sqhsan in 2.
de/ ge—these particles always cap a previous statement, whether made by the speaker himself or an opponent. They are sometimes separated.
katala/bh|—c. 18, 2.
*(/ote—see c. 21, 1.
to\n qeo/n—as Apollo was both healer and destroyer, they thought that the god was helping the enemy by sending the plague. Cf. the opening of Il. 1, and O. T. first chorus.

*peri\ me\n ou)=n—Thuc. leaves this doubtful, without expressing his own opinions: then he goes on with the facts, de\ being equivalent to d' ou)=n. ‘As concerns .., they thought that what was happening corresponded to it.’
o(/ ti a)/. kai\ ei)pei=n— = o(/ ti kai\ a). ei)pei=n. tau=ta me\n—e)sti is regularly omitted in this phrase, as in sed haec hactenus. Cf. IV. 41, 4; VII. 87, 6.

*to\ pedi/on—the Attic plain, as c. 20, 1. This resumes from c. 47. parh=lqon—after ravaging the plain (contrast c 19), and reaching the north-east parts of it that lie between Mt. Parnes and Pentelicon (Brilessus), they worked their way down the south-east coast district of Attica.
*pa/ralon— = the part of Attica stretching south of Mt. Hymettus and Brauron right down to C. Sunium.

*laurei/ou —the mines here, which were an important source of revenue to Athens (Aesch. Persae, 237 a)rgu/rou phgh/ tis au)toi=s e)sti, qhsauro\s xqono/s), were farmed out on hereditary leases. See Kennedy's Demosth., Intr. to the speech against Pantaenetus. [
ou(=]—Intr. p. xxxix.
h(=| pro\s *p. o(ra=|—partem quae spectat ad P. Cf. c. 93, 4.
e)/peita de\—c. 4, 2. The addition of de\ emphasizes the antithesis.
*kai\ to/te—with w)/n. Pericles had entered on a fresh year of office in Hecatombaeon 430 (Intr. p. lxv.) since the last mention of him as Strategus.
peri\ tou= mh\—c. 22, 1.
*)/eti d'—cf. c. 13, init.
th=| *p.—the dat. depends on e)pi/ploun. e(toi=ma—cf. c. 3, 4.
*)epi\ tw=n—see c. 80, 2

i(ppagwgoi=s—this is the first occasion on which the Athenians used transports. (The Persians used them, Herod. VI. 48.) They were triremes (IV. 42; VI. 43); in 424 they were sufficiently novel to provide Aristoph. with a joke, Eq. 599. It was very important to have cavalry in the plundering expeditions, in order to be able to penetrate as far inland as possible.
*xi=oi kai\ *l.— cf. c. 9, 4.
nausi/n—the dat. of accompaniment, only used in naval and military phrases.
*(/ote—the imperf., as usual, after o(/te, denoting that the act described in the principal clause occurs at the same time as that described in the temporal clause. Cf. on c. 21, 1, and c. 99, 6.
th=s *)attikh=s—for the order, cf. c. 18, 1, and contrast 4 below, where the emphasis is on *)epi/dauron, whereas here the point is that the Peloponnesians were still in Attica, cf. 6 below.

*)epi/dauron—the most important place yet attacked by the Athenians; it would have been valuable to them, as it lay on the road to Argos, which was then neutral (c. 9, 2) and might possibly join them if they obtained possession of so considerable a state: and other towns, as Troezen and Hermione might have fallen into their hands.

e)/temon—it is not clear why Pericles ravaged the country before attacking Epidaurus: probably he had planned a stratagem to seize the place with a small force while the main body was scattered about and was keeping the troops that guarded the town (only a third of the whole force of Epidaurus, c. 47, 2) occupied.

e)s e)lpi/da h)=lqon—the phrases e)lpi/s e)sti, e)n e)lpi/di ei)=nai, e)lpi/da e)/xein have the simple infin. aor. in most cases, as c. 80, 1; but in c. 85, 4 e)lpi/dos ou/shs has the fut. infin., and in 102, 3 e)lpi\s has a)\n paqei=n; while in I. 144, 1 we have e)lpi/da tou= perie/sesqai. Cf. on c. 13, 9.

ou) me)ntoi—this failure is probably due to a rally of the inhabitants similar to that of the Plataeans, c. 3. proexw/rhse—impersonal; cf. I. 109 w\s au)tw=| ou) prouxw/rei; III. 18 e)peidh\ ou) prouxw/rei h(=| prosede/xonto; al.
*)ek th=s *)e.—the attack on Epidaurus was the greatest enterprise of Athens before 427.
*(alia/da—the country round Halice, an unimportant town on the south-east coast of Argolis.
*(ermioni/da—Hermione had a territory of some extent on the coast of the Gulf of Hermione.

*prasia/s—on north-east coast of Laconia. It suffered severely from the war, and is a proof how effective the method
of Pericles was. Intr. p. lxx. Aristoph. Pax, 242 i)w\ *prasiai\ trisa/qliai kai\ penta/kis. ou)ke/ti—nothing is said of the route taken by the Peloponnesians after they left Laurium.
kate/labon—always takes pres. or perf. part.: IV. 129, 1 (pres.), I. 59, 1 (perf.).

*(/oson xro/non—this has to be supplied with kai\ oi( *)a., i.e. the sense is not that the plague raged during the simultaneous ravaging in Attica and in Peloponnese, but ‘both while the Peloponnesians were in Attica, and while the A. were away on the expedition.’
e)/n te th=| strati/a|—the order is chiastic: th=| gh=|—new=n—strati/a|—po/lei. Thuc. is very fond of the chiasmus.

e)le/xqh—constructed with acc. and infin. regularly (a) when it is used in the sense of ferunt, fertur; cf. c. 20, 1, 47, 3, 77, 6, 93, 4, 98, 3, 102, 5; I. 69; V. 74. Plat. Phaedo, p. 110 C le/getai ei)=nai toiau/th h( gh=, in a myth. It is then oftener in the pass.: the act. occurs e.g. I. 9, 2, 138, 4. If however Thuc. wants to imply that he disbelieves the report, he uses w(s, as in c. 48 e)le/xqh w(s e)sbeblh/koien. (He always inserts some qualification when he is not sure of the truth of what he relates:) (b) when it = keleu/w. It is not often found with accus. and infin. otherwise. See c. 13, 2 and cf. Andoc. 1, 57 ei)pei=n kaki/an ei)=nai ta\ geno/mena. h)sqa/nonto—from the smoke of the pyres.
*th=| e)sbolh=|—see c. 20, 1.
e)ne/meinan—sc. e)n th=| gh=|. Complexive aor., as also e)/temon. The shortest period they remained was 15 days, 425 B.C. The ordinary time was about 30 days.

*(/agnwn—Intr. p. lxxv. He had been Strategus in 440 B.C., and was again re-elected in 429, c. 95. He led the colony to Amphipolis in 437 B.C., and was honoured as founder until the death of Brasidas in 422 B.C., when the latter took his place in the regard of the people (v. 11). After the Sicilian disaster, when a very old man, he was elected one of the ten *pro/bouloi. *kleo/pompos—c. 26, 1. custrathgoi\ —It is not clear whether Thuc. means they were now in office for the official year Hecatombaeon 431 to Hecatombaeon 430, or for the year 430 to 429. Probably it is the former, and they were now nearing the end of their year of office. The expression probably points to the extraordinary position held by Pericles from Hecatombaeon 432 to Hecatombaeon 430. Intr. pp. lxvi., lxxiv.
mhxana/s—Intr. p. lxxv. Pericles wanted to reduce Potidaea in order that, in case peace should be concluded with Sparta (c. 59, 2), Athens might retain the town.

*paraskeuh=s—with a)ci/ws. e)pinemome/nh—‘spreading among.’ Cf. c. 54, 5. e)pigi/gnomai is only used of a disaster
which is new. The partic., as well as the verb, governs tou\s *)a. e)ntau=qa dh\—following a partic., as in I. 94, 5, = to/te dh/ nosh=sai—‘fell ill,’ ingressive.
cu\n— un-Attic use. See c. 2, 1.
*formi/wn—c. 31, 2, and 2, 1; I. 64, 2. Only the 3000 hoplites referred to in I. 61, 4 were at Potidaea when Hagnon went there.
*kata\ xw/ran me/nontes—so I. 28, 5; III. 22, 6. Isocr. 4, 176; Demosth. 24, 5; Aristoph. Plut. 367, et al. Cf. Horace's certa sede manet.

*(ws ... e)te/tmhto—the plup. has nothing to do with h)lloi/wnto, (i.e. the meaning is not that the land had been ravaged before the change came over their feelings), but describes the state of the country as it lay ruined before their eyes. The other places in which w(s has the plup. (III. 23, 1, 26, 4, 27, 1, 69, 2) are similar. Cf. on c. 3, 1.
o( po/lemos —referring to the other miseries besides the ruin of the trees, crops and buildings, such as the difficulty of living and the burdens of service.
h)lloi/wnto—plup., because the change had come over them before Hagnon's expedition, during Pericles' absence. Intr. p. lxxv.

*)en ai)ti/a| ei)=xon—cf. the following, e)n o)rgh=| e)/., c. 18, 5, 21, 3, 65, 3; e)n h(donh=| e)/., III. 9; e)n o)rrwdi/a| e)/., c. 89, 1. This idiom is not found in the orators, but occurs in tragedy.
peripeptwko/tes—see c. 54, 1.

pro\s tou\s *l.—with cugxwrei=n. pre/sbeis—Sta. reads presbei/as with MT only. Dion. Hal. thinks that Thuc. ought to have given a detailed account of these transactions. The reason he does not do so is that nothing came of them.
pantaxo/qen—not local, but = ‘utterly.’
a)/poroi kaqestw=tes—i.e. ei)s a)pori/an k. c. 81, 8; ei)s tosau/thn a)pori/an e)lqei=n Isocr. 8, 47; ei)s tou=to katasth=sai a)pori/as Demosth. 22, 132; ei)s a)/poron pesei=n Aristoph. Clouds 702.
*(orw=n ... poih/sas—see c. 4, 4.
pro\s ta\ p.—c. 22, 1, 64, 6 pro\s pa\s cumfora/s, 88, 3 p. th\n parou=san o)/yin. h)/lpize—of bad events, as in I. 1, 1.
cu/llogon—c. 22, 1. Pericles still held his extraordinary power. Intr. p. lxvi., and it was perhaps by virtue of this that he was able to have a special meeting summoned. Cf. c. 13, 1.
e)/ti d'—i.e. he had not yet been suspended from office and brought to trial (a)poxeirotonhqei/s). Intr. pp. lxxv. fol. will make this clear.
e)strath/gei—‘held office,’ implying that he was still au)tokra/twr. He was just completing another year of office, and was Strategus elect for the official year soon to begin. Cf. c. 55, 2.

to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s g.—cf. VII. 68 th=s g. to\ qumou/menon. This neuter partic. as noun abstract presents the idea as an action going on, not as an abstract notion separate
from all associations of time and circumstance. Cf. c. 87, 3. It is frequent in Euripides.
pro\s ... katasth=sai—the ordinary construction is e)s (see 2 above), but tre/pesqai has e)pi/, pro/s, e)s, and several verbs e)pi\ or e)s in Thuc. Cf. c. 65, 9.
katasth=sai—sc. th\n gnw/mhn. e)/lece—the Schol. labels the speech dhmhgori/a *perikle/ous pro\s *)aqhnai/ous. The speech was also known in antiquity as h( oi)kei/a *perikle/ous dhmhgori/a.
*kai\ . kai\—parataxis; cf. c. 46, 1.
prosdexo- me/nw| ... gege/nhtai—cf. c. 3, 2. M. T. 900.
ta\ th=s o)rgh=s— ‘this outburst of wrath,’ as ta\ th=s tu/xhs; see on c. 44, 2.
cunh/gagon—the aor. of momentary action, as continually in tragedy.

o)/pws—the subjun. is certainly to be preferred to the fut. indic. here, as this is a pure final clause. M. T. 364 (o(/pws is Thuc.'s favourite final particle, but is rare in other prose authors except Xen.).
ei)/ ti—he does not doubt it, but softens the expression.
*plei/w—with w)felei=n. This sentence contains a triple antithesis.
o)rqoume/nhn .. sfallome/nhn—the state is personified.
kaq' e(/kaston—because it is when prosperity has engendered selfishness and oblivion of corporate life that states go to ruin.

*kalw=s fero/menos—cf. v. 15, 2, 16, 1; f. of the course that affairs take. This gnw/mh is the premiss of the following enthymeme (see c. 11, 7) ‘It is well for the citizens that the state should prosper even if they have to sacrifice themselves: for the citizens must fall with the state, and when the state prospers, the citizens easily overcome their troubles. Therefore the citizens must sacrifice themselves for the state.’ Cf. 4 below.
to\ kaq' e(auto\n—cf. c. 11, 3.
diafqeirome/nhs—there is paronomasi/a between this and fero/menos, also between kakotuxw=n and eu)tuxou/sh|. pollw=| ma=llon —sc. h)\ e)n kakotuxou/sh|.
*(opo/te—‘since,’ so that the verb to be supplied is e)sti/. Andoc 1, 7 and 89.

ei)=s e(/kastos—cf. VI. 41 ei)=s te e(/kastos kai\ h( cu/mpasa po/lis; VIII. 89 h)gwni/zeto ei)=s e)/kastos. mh\—the sentence does not end regularly, the construction being carried on to suit the parenthesis o(\ nu=n u(. dra=te. We expect kai\ mh\ a)fi/esqai. Cf. Plat. Phaedrus, 272 D panta/pasi ga/r, o(\ kai\ kat' a)rxa\s ei)/pomen tou=de tou= lo/gou, o(/ti ou)de
 a)lhqei/as mete/xein de/oi to
 me/llonta r(htoriko
 e)/sesqai. tai=s kat' oi)=kon k.t.l.—epexegesis of dra=te. Cf. VI. 11 o(/per ... pepo/nqate: dia\ to\ perigegenh=sqai ... *sikeli/as e)fi/esqe. Shil notes that Latin idiom expresses the epexegesis of facio by ut.

kat' oi)=kon— cf. Aristoph. Lys. 261 a(\s e)bo/skomen kat' oi)=kon, ‘at home.’ This phrase differs from kata\ th\n oi)ki/an = ‘about the house,’ Aristoph. Thesm. 402, and has a wider sense than kat' oi)ki/an,
‘in private,’ Aristoph. Vesp. 1180.
tou= koinou=—objective gen. to swthri/as, but put first for the sake of the emphatic antithesis to kat' oi)=kon. u(ma=s—he dexterously throws the charge back on them.
cune/gnwte—the prep. here has an adverbial force. Cf. c. 64, 1.
di' ai)ti/as e)/xein—cf. c. 59, 2, and 11, 3 This idiom is rare in other Attic prose writers (not found in orators).

*kai/toi—there is no prothesis to this speech (see on c. 36, 4), the reason being that in c. 59. 3, and 65, 1 Thuc. explains the object which Pericles had in the *pi/stis, and so had no need to insert it here.

e)moi\—the analysis makes the pi/stis begin here. But the Schol. who notes on these words paragrafiko
 e)n deino/thti must have taken this to be part of the prooi/mion and thought that the pi/stis began with c. 61. (I begin the pi/stis here with Fr. Muller, against the Schol., Altinger and Leitschel, because the object of Pericles in the pi/stis certainly was th=s e)p' au)to
 o)rgh=s paralu/ein tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, 65, 1. *to\ paragrafiko
 comes in the prooi/mion, but Thuc. may have meant the last part of 4 to represent this.)

toiou/tw|— here follows another enthymeme: ‘You are unjustly angry with Pericles: for he is able, patriotic, honest and can tell you what is best for you; without all these qualities, a statesman is of little use. Therefore, as Pericles has them all, it is wrong to blame him.’

ou)deno\s h(/sswn—this is all purely rhetorical, for no proof is offered of the premise, which might be disputed. This illustrates excellently Aristotle's remark that, whereas exact truth is the object of the syllogism, probability is the object of the enthymeme.

filo/polis—to us philanthropy and cosmopolitanism mean far more than citizenship and patriotism; but in antiquity the former were vague abstractions which interested none but philosophers, whereas the latter were realities for which every right-minded man was ready to sacrifice himself.
xrhma/twn krei/sswn—cf. c. 65, 8. Probably Pericles already knew that Cleon was preparing to charge him with intercepting public money. Intr. p. lxxvi.
kai\—‘as’; so after i)/sos III. 14, 1; o(moi=os VI. 11, 1; VIII. 76, 4.
e)nequmh/qh—c. 40, 2.
ou)k a)\n o(moi/ws—meiosis. Cf. for o(moi/ws, c. 44, 3.
oi)kei/ws—like an oi)kei=os, ‘as a loyal citizen,’ who regards himself as much bound to the state as to his family.
tou=de—this I am speaking of, viz. patriotism.

vikw/menos— the reading adopted is far more likely than the MSS. genitive, as the partic. corresponds to gnou\s and e)/xwn. (The gender would be masc., cf. c. 47, 4. So Kr., but recent edd., except Cr., make it neut., with tou=de for subj., against which it may
be urged (a) to/de nika=tai means ‘this view is rejected,’ unless to/de is personified, in which case (b) we should expect xrh/masi also to be personified, and to become u(po\ tw=n x.)
tou/tou— i.e. xrhma/twn, cf. tou=de above.
a)po/doito—there are readings poloi=to and a)po/loito in inferior MSS.

*kai\ me/sws—with ma=llon e(te/rwn. ‘If you thought that I had somewhat more of these qualifications than others.’ ‘Propria laus tantum abest ut sordeat in ore virorum vere magnorum ut liabeat etiam ingenuae magnificaeque simplicitatis plurimum.’ Doderlein. ma=llon e(te/rwn—me/sws ei)=pe kai\ ou) sfo/dra, dia\ to\ fortiko/n. Schol.

au)ta\—cf. c. 1. ge —emphasizes tou= a)dikei=n: ‘you followed my advice because you thought me filo/polis, xrhma/twn krei/sswn. Is it not then absurd to impute a)diki/a to me?’ He seems again to refer to the plots of Cleon.
*kai\ ga\r—this takes up tou= ge a)dikei=n, and belongs to pollh\ a)/noia, ‘for undoubtedly it is intensely foolish to go to war.’
ai(/resis—viz. between peace and war.
polemh=sai ingressive, cf c. 15, 2, 58, 2.

ei) d'—there is not any doubt about it; cf. c. 39, 4, and Andoc. I. 33 ei) me/n ti h)se/bhka ... ei) de\ ou)de
 h(ma/rthtai/ moi, Aeschines, I. 112 ei) me
 h)=n o( a)gw
 ou(tosi\ e)n po/lei e)kklh/tw|, u(ma=s a)
 h)ci/wsa ei) d' o( a)gw/n e)stin *)aqh/nhsin ... a)namimnhskein prosh/kei. h)=n—viz. when the Spartan embassies were sent threatening war. Intr. p. lxviii.
eu)qu\s—with u(pakou=sai. o( fugw\n—Shil. takes this as general, but then the pres. partic. would be expected. Pericles alludes to those who had been opposed to war. kinduneu/santas is emphatic.

*(o au)to/s ei)mi—this, like e)ci/stamai, metaba/llete, pei- sqh=nai, metame/lein, and e)gkarterei=n, is left without further definition. The gloss a(\ e)/gnwte well gives the general idea of the passage which is clear but exceedingly condensed.
a)kerai/ois—cf. c. 18, 5; before you had suffered from the invasion and the plague.
lo/gon—‘policy,’ as announced in c. 13, and before the war.
e)n tw=| a)sqenei= th=s gnw/mhs—cf. c. 87, 3. Antiphon, Tet. A, 3.3 to\ qumou/menon th=s gnw/mhs, and c. 59, 3.

u(mete/rw|—put with a)sqenei= rather than gnw/mhs for the antithesis to e)mo/n. It is not uncommon for a neut. adj. with art. to have an epithet; cf. IV. 87, 3 tw=| u(mete/rw| eu)/nw|. mh\—with fai/nesqai. dio/ti—its ordinary sense is ‘because,’ but often from Aristotle onwards = ‘that.’

to\ lu/poun—in order to secure a permanent advantage in the future, it may be necessary to submit to some temporary inconvenience (c. 53, 3), which a too hasty judgment may mistake for the only outcome of a far-sighted policy.
e)/xei—involves. so ‘makes itself felt.’

a(/pasi—with dh/lwsis; the individual's perception of the immediate inconvenience being contrasted with the deferred
realisation by the nation of the advantage.
e)c o)ligou=—c. 11, 4.

tapeinh\ . e)gkarterei=n—cf. I. 50, 5 nh=es o)li/gai a)mu/nein; v. 111, 2 ta\ u(pa/rxonta braxe/a perigi/gnesqai. Shil. points out that this is not the same as tapeinote/ra h)\ w(/ste e)g.; being milder, it does not allege utter want of endurance: ‘You are weak in patiently abiding the change.’

*paralo/gw|—that which is sudden and unexpected— for instance death in certain mortal but lingering diseases— does not necessarily overthrow one's original calculations. Hence the addition of to\ ... cumbai=non to to\ ai)f. kai\ a). a)/llois —neut.
*)antipa/lois— = i)/sois tw=| mege/qei au)th=s. c. ta\s megi/- stas—c. 2, 2.

e)qe/lein—Shil.'s excellent remark that e)qe/lw = ‘I am willing,’ bou/lomai = ‘I wish,’ needs this much modification, that e)qe/lw is always used by a superior to an inferior, just as they speak of the ‘will’ of the gods. (In Plat. Gorg. 508 C, Shil. says a distinction is hardly recognised: but there o( boulo/menos = ‘anyone who wishes,’ as usual, and o( e)qe/lwn = ‘anyone whose will and pleasure it is’—ei)mi\ e)pi\ tw=| boulome/nw| w)/sper oi( a)/timoi tou= e)qe/lontos. At the same time, the example shows that the meanings of the two do overlap. Schmeizer on Plato, Phaedo, c. 50.)
u(fi/stasqai— = ‘endure’ takes accus.: for meaning with dat., see L. and S.
a)fani/zein— c. 34, 3.
e)n i)/sw|— = o(moi/ws. dikaiou=si—c. 41, 5.
do/chs—with e)llei/pei, as proshkou/shs with o)rego/menon, the order being due to the elaborate antithesis.

o(/stis . . to\n—the change of expression relieves the sentence. Isocr. 6, 90 e/le/sqai mh\ to\ tou/tois r(a=|ston, a)ll' o(\ pre/pon e)/stai. a)palgh/santas— only found in Thuc.: for the force of a)po\, cf. a)panqei=n, a)pe/rdw, a)potu/ptw. tou= koinou= th=s s.—c. 60, 4.
po/non—with a)pe/deica u(popteuo/menon, the object being repeated in au)to\n owing to the length of the sentence.

mh\— subordinate to u(popteuo/menon. u(pa/rxon—with e)nqumhqh=nai, and both e)s th\n a)rxh\n and mege/qous pe/ri belong to u(pa/rxon, ‘your possession of which, as bearing on your empire in respect of its greatness,’ i.e. ‘the existence of which, as it bears on the greatness of your empire.’
ou)/t' e)gw\—sc. e)xrhsa/mhn au)tw=|. kompwdeste/ran—‘as the pretension it involves is rather arrogant.’
para\ to\ ei)ko\s—‘unduly.’
*oi)/esqe—in this passage the topic to\ dunato\n is used; Index, s.v. to/poi. merw=n—depends on tou= e(te/rou. e)pi\ ple/on—sc. ne/mesqai (c. 29, 2), ‘to any further extent you wish.’
a)/llo—exclusive, cf. c. 14, 1; ‘nor any nation either.’ basileu\s is not the Persian king, but goes with ou)k e)/. o(/stis. ou)dei/s. tw=n e)n t. p.—cf. c. 41, 3.
w(/ste—the value of Attica cannot be compared with the value of the sea.

ou) kata\ .. xrei/an—‘not to be measured by the advantage derived from,’ i.e. is much greater than that. Shil. quotes many examples of ou) or mh\ kata\ meaning superior to; the same may mean inferior to, as in the phrase ou) kat' a)ci/an common in tragedy.
w(=n—sc. e)sterhme/noi. ou)d' ei)ko\s—neque decet, c. 10, 1.
xal. fe/rein—sc. e)sterhme/noi. [

au)tw=n]—probably due to a note e)sterh=sqai au)tw=n. ma=llon h)\ ou)—cf. III. 36, 4 po/lin diafqei=rai ma=llon h)\ ou) tou\s ai)ti/ous. Shil. notes that h)\ implies a negative, just as pri\n does (A. J. of Phil. II. B. L. G. on pri(n): and all sentences implying a neg. may be strengthened by an expressed neg. M. T. 815. Thus kinduneu/w peri\ tou= mh\ swqh=nai means the same thing as kinduneu/w peri\ tou= swqh=nai. khpi/on—a parterre of flowers. (The other view that khpi/on means a mode of dressing the hair is due to Aelius Dionysius: Eustath., p. 907, quotes Aelius, whose gloss also appears in Photius, Suidas, and more than once in Scholia; cf. Pollux, II. 29 kh=pos ga\r ou) mo/non futalia/, a)lla\ kai\ kallsmo\s ko/mhs, kat' *ai)lion *dionu/sion, kai\ koura=s dia/qesis tw=n e)n kefalh=| trixw=n. *qoukudi/dhs de\ khpi/on fhsi.)

e)gkallw/pisma—of display in dress. Cf. Plato, Phaedo, p. 64 D ta\s a)/llas ta\s peri\ to\ sw=ma qerapei/as ... oi)=on i(mati/wn diafero/ntwn kth/seis kai\ u(podhma/twn kai\ tou\s a)/llous kallwpismou/s. gnw=nai—sc. ei)ko/s. a)ntil. au)th=s diasw/swmen—c. 13, 2.
a)nalhyome/nhn ... filei=n—the change of construction is due to the change in the sense of gnw=nai, which at first = know, then = judge or decide. M. T. 915.
u(pakou/sasi —with gen. of a perpetual attitude of submission, with dat. (61, 1) of submission at a particular moment.

pate/rwn— the topic changes to to\ sumfe/ron. See 2 above. Demosth. 3, 36 mh\ paraxwrei=n th=s ta/cews h(\n u(mi=n oi( pro/gonoi meta\ pollw=n kai\ kalw=n kindu/nwn kthsa/menoi kate/lipon kat' a)mfo/tera—i.e. kata\ to\ katasxei=n kai\ diasw/santes paradou=nai. But, as applied to his hearers, katasxei=n does not mean to acquire new empire, which Pericles discouraged; but to assert their mastery over their existing empire, and not think of surrendering it to Sparta: katasxei=n = both to get and to keep.

fanh=nai—sc. ei)ko/s. meta\ po/nwn—cf. I. 70, 8 meta) po/nwn kai\ kindu/nwn moxqei=n, ib. 19, 3 meta\ kindu/nwn ta\s meleta\s poiei=dqai. When abstract sing. nouns are used in these phrases (Thuc. has examples), as met' a)lhqei/as, the art. is rare.
prose/ti —once Thuc. uses pro\s as an adv., III. 58, 5: elsewhere prose/ti. au)ta\—c. 36, 4.

ai)/sxion—Demosth. 2, 26 polu\ r(a=|on e)/xontas fula/ttein h)\ kth/sasqai. e)/xontas—decame/nous, while a)faireqh=nai is the opposite of katasxei=n kai\ diasw/sasqai. i)e/nai o(mo/se—cf. c. 81, 5, obviam ire. fronh/mati katafronh/mati—paronomasi/a, in the style of Gorgias. Intr. p. lii.
The antithesis between confidence and disdain is an antithesis between an instinctive feeling of superiority and a consciousness arising from knowledge of the enemy's inferiority. Cf. Livy, XXI. 41 non eo solum animo quo adversus alios hostes soletis pugnare velim; sed cum indignatione quadam atque ira, velut si servos videatis vestros arma repente contra vos ferentes.
*au)/xhma—Intr. p. liii. au)/xhma is not identified with fro/nhma, but is substituted as the natural result of it.
kai\ —‘mere.’

a)maqi/as eu)tuxou=s—fortune sometimes favours cowardly fools, and produces in them a habit of boasting. Pericles probably meant Cleon, and Thuc. suggests him by kai\ (= ‘even’) deilw=| tini. katafro/nhsis o(\s a)\n—cf. the definition in c. 44, 1. Sc. tou/tw| e)ggi/gnetai. gnw/mh|—certain knowledge, contrasted with a)maqi/a eu).; again suggesting Cleon, who made the un-Socratic discovery that a)maqi/a is a)reth/! Intr. p. lxxiii.
*to/lman—one of the effects of katafro/nhsis, but not always of fro/nhma, which is compatible with cowardice.

h( cu/nesis—stands very close to gnw/mh, but only in the intellectual sense of clear insight and circumspection. For the principle that true courage is impossible without cu/nesis, cf. c. 40, 4. (This illustrates the close connection between Ethics and Metaphysics, so often insisted upon by modern thinkers.)

e)k tou= u(pe/rfronos—with e)xurwte/ran pare/xetai. ‘Intelligence gives greater solidity to courage as the result of a consciousness of superiority’; such a consciousness of superiority is therefore desirable.

e)lpi/di—cf. V. 102 e)pista/meqa ta\ tw=n pole/mwn e)/stin o(/te koinote/ras ta\s tu/xas lamba/nonta h)\ kata\ to\ diafe/ron e(kate/rwn plh=qos. ‘Courage trusts not to hope because fortune has hitherto been fair (that is the strength of the helpless); rather it trusts to insight based on a survey of realities; and that is a far safer prophet.’ In this elaborate antithesis (a) blind hope is contrasted with clear insight, (b) the foundation on which hope is built is contrasted with the foundation on which insight is built, the one being treacherous (tu/xh), the other being firm, (c) there is a contrast, in the form of chiasmus, between e)lpi/di and u(pa/rxonta, and between tu/xhs and gnw/mh. a)po\ th=s o(moi/as tu/xhs—referring to 4 above; cowards boast when tu/xh has been more than o(moi/a to them: the helpless hope on when tu/xh has been as much as o(moi/a to them; for an equal share of Heaven's favours is enough to make them suppose they will not be destroyed But brave men, trusting in gnw/mh, can bear up even under a temporary withdrawal of their share of Heaven's favour (c. 64, 2). (These words, if retained after th\n to/lman, give no sense, since there is no reason why courage should come a)po\ ... tu/xhs,
or why the effect of insight on courage should be limited by such a condition.)
a)po/rw|—neut.

gnw/mh|—Thuc. does not often contrast gnw/mh with tu/xh, by which gnw/mh may always be over-ridden. Intr. p. xli.; I. 144, 4; V. 75 tuxh| me\n kakizo/menoi, gnw/mh| de\ oi( au)toi\ e)/ti o)/ntes. It is common in the orators, as Antiphon, 5, 92, Andoc. 1, 140, Lys. 34, 2, Isocr. 2, 30.
*th=s te—the topic changes to to\ sumfe/ron; see c. 62, 3, Index s.v. to/poi. ei)ko\s—decet.
tw=| timwme/nw|—c. 59, 3. ‘You are bound to support the dignity which the state has obtained through our empire.’

u(pe\r a(/pantas—not a common use of u(pe/r. Cf. Isocr. ep. 4, 8 tou\s u(pe\r au(tou\s o)/ntas. tima\s—which, though belonging to the state, directly benefit every citizen; in those times the city was everything, the citizen nothing. Cf. 60, 3.

peri\ doulei/as a)gwni/zesqai—as remarked on c. 62, 3, sentences like a)gw\n peri\ tou= dokei=n a)di/kws e)piqumei=n and a)gw(n peri\ tou= mh\ dokei=n a). e). are identical in meaning. In the same way, with all verbs or nouns implying a contest, the noun with peri\ may describe either the object which the combatant referred to wishes to obtain, or the disaster he wishes to avoid, the two being the same thing regarded from different views: thus Lysias' e)nantiou=sqai peri\ e/leuqeri/as (13, 17) is the same as a)gwni/zesqai peri\ doulei/as. Cf. Lys. 3, 44 a)gwni/zesqai peri\ qana/tou; 21, 20 a). peri\ a)sebei/as. Demosth. 1, 5 ou) peri\ do/chs ki/ndunos a/ll' a)ndrapodismou= th=s patri/dos. doulei/as—i.e. dependence on Sparta, as d. often denotes merely the opposite of au)tonomi/a. kindu/nou w(=n— periculo ob offensas in imperio contractas, danger due to the hatred to which you have been exposed in that empire. w(=n = tou/twn a(/, cognate accus. to a)ph/xqhsqe. (One or two edd. prefer to take w(=n as masc., danger from those in governing whom you have incurred hatred; but that does not agree well with the abstract nature of the whole passage.)
*ei)/ tis—referring to the combination to which the overtures to Sparta were due.

kai\ to/de—i.e. to\ e)ksth=nai th=s a)rxh=s, ‘if that is the honourable part that any of you, prompted by his present apprehension and an indolent spirit, wishes to play.’ to/de is cognate accus. to a)ndragaqi/zetai. Cf. 1 above. The friends of peace did not admit that they wished e)ksth=nai th=s a)rxh=s, but Pericles asserts that their policy would lead to loss of empire and even worse disasters.
a)pragmosu/nh|— dat. of manner. The word is purposely chosen to include all who were playing into the hands of Sparta, if only by their apathy. Cf. Intr. p. lxxiii.

w(s turanni/da—it is remarkable that Cleon, who had done so much to get up the attack on Pericles, utters the same sentiment, III. 40. Cleon was
really by no means anxious for peace (see Intr. p. lxxiv. fol.), and it is probable that Pericles here points out the absurdity of Cleon's present attitude by adopting a phrase of which all knew that he was fond; leaving the friends of a)pragmosu/nh to settle matters with the friends of turanni\s as best they could.
a)/dikon dokei=—viz. ‘to the world.’ Pericles does not himself assert that the empire is a despotism, or that it was unjustly acquired: he alludes to an opinion then especially prevalent.
e)piki/ndunon—sc. e)sti/.
*oi( toiou=toi—i.e. oi( to/de a)ndragaqizo/menoi. e(te/rous pei/santes—‘if they should get others to adopt their views.’

kai\—with te/, sive ... sive. Observe the i)so/kwlon on each side of kai/, cf. c. 40, 1, and the o(moiote/leuta in a)pole/seian and oi)kh/seian. (These similar endings are not common in Thuc.: there are about a dozen in this book.)

ei)/ pou—the second protasis to po/lin a)pole/seian. e)pi\ sfw=n au)tw=n—‘by themselves,’ a hint that if they want their ideas carried out, they had better go and live somewhere else. For the phrase, cf. v. 67, 1; VI. 40, 2 au)th\ e/f' au\th=s; VIII. 63, 4.

to\ a)/pragmon—‘indolence is not secure unless it be ranged beside activity; nor yet is it expedient in a sovereign state, but only in one that is in subjection, to seek safety by submission.’ to\ a)/pragmon and to\ drasth/rion are for oi( a)pra/gmones, oi( drasth/rioi. Cf. c. 44, 1.

sw/|zetai ... tetagme/non—military words. If indolent persons wish to come out of the struggle safe, they had better take sides with the active; i.e. the peace party can only gain a secure peace by supporting the war party, instead of making overtures to the enemy. Cf. Demosth. 6, 25 ou) fula/cesq' o(/pws mh\ pole/mou zhtou=ntes a)pallagh=nai despo/thn eu(/rhte; cumfe/rei—subject a\sfalw=s douleu/ein, before which to\ is omitted, as in c. 35, 1, 39, 4.

a)sfalw=s d.— this is what to\ a)/pragmon really means, says Pericles, it is not swthri/a, as the friends of peace pretend, but doulei/a: a)sfalw=s corresponds to ou) sw/|zetai, douleu/ein to mh\ meta\ tou= drao thri/ou tetagme/non, which shows that the adv. is emphatic.
douleu/ein—cf. 1 above; a state now a)/rxousa becomes a slave by submitting. Cf. c. 42, 4. (For other views of this passage, see other editions.)
*di' o)rgh=s—c. 13, 2.
ei)ko\s h)=n—sc. dra=sai. Cf. c. 11, 8.

pra=gma ... gegenhme/non—for the change to a neut. expression cf. c. 47, 3. pra=gma is in apposition to the sentence generally, as in Andoc. 1, 39 tou=q' u(pe/qeto, deino/taton pra=gma oi)=mai. e)lpi/dos—cf. c. 11, 6, 85, 4, 102, 3.
krei=sson—cf. c. 41, 3.

oi)=d' o(/ti—cf. eu)= oi)=d' o(/ti, and dh=lon o(/ti. me/ros ti—‘considerably.’ [ti] eu)= pra/chte—either eu)= poiei=n, eu)= pra/ttein, etc., or a)gaqo/n ti poiei=n, a)gaqo/n ti pra/ttein,
etc., are the phrases. For the latter, cf. Isocr. 2, 20, Aristoph. Eccles. 108.

a)naqh/sete—‘you intend to attribute it to me.’ So the fut. indic. with ei) may follow optat. with a)/n, and even alternate with ei) and optat., as Andoc. 1, 30 deino
 a)
 ei)/h, ei) e\moi\ o)rgi/zoisqe kai\ th
 diabolh
 ... krei/ttw th=s a)lhqei/as h(gh/sesqe.
*fe(rein te—another reason why their indignation is unmerited is that the plague is sent by a higher power.

ta\ daimo/nia—this phrase, for ta\ th=s tu/xhs, only occurs here, and, as Cl. says, it is probably borrowed from the language of philosophers. Cf. qei=os, contrasted with a)nqrw/pinos, in Plato; also Andoc. 1, 139 ki/ndunoi qei=oi) (k. a)nqrw/pinoi. a)nagkai/ws —‘with resignation.’ The inevitable should be endured, not argued over.
ta/ te a)po\—there is chiasmus with I above; oi( e\nanti/oi, h( no/sos, ta\ daimo/nia, ta\ a)po\ tw=n p. e)n e)/qei h)=n— ‘was the habit of.’
e)n u(mi=n—‘by your act.’ Cf. c. 35, 1.
kwluqh=|—‘let it not be impeded,’ i.e. ‘let not your action check it.’
*dia\ to\—belongs to ei)/kein and a)nhlwke/nai. (The Schol., who makes a)nhlwke/nai depend on gnw=te, has the honour of having misled Shil.)
plei=sta de\—‘has never yielded ..., but has sacrificed.’
megi/sthn dh\—antithesis to o)/noma me/giston. Notice the frequent use of superlatives, esp. me/gistos and plei=stos. Cf. c. 11, 1.
h)\n kai\ nu=n—‘even if, in our present condition (i.e. in spite of our present power), we should give way at all. Pericles admits the possibility of a decline of the empire.’
kai\ e)lassou=sqai—‘to decay as well (as to grow).’
katalelei/yetai—permanent result in fut. M. T. 78.

*(ellh/nwn te o(/ti—epexegesis of h(=s = duna/mews. Cf. Plat. Rep. v. p. 469 B *(/ellhnas *(ellhni/das po/leis a)ndrapodi/zesqai. o(/ti—put late, because of the emphasis on *(ellh/nwn. pole/mois—temporal. Cf. c. 13, 9.
kaq' e(ka/stous—depends, as though it were one word, on pro/s. toi=s pa=sin—c. 11, 6.
*kai/toi—‘now it is true that,’ making an admission that increase of power does not increase the number of friends. The objection is answered in 5 below. (Only Bäumlein and Sta. make this clear.)
a)pra/gmwn—referring to other states, yet with a hint at oi( a)pra/gmones in Athens.
me/myait' a)/n— corresponds to the fut. zhlw/sei, fqonh/sei. kai\ au)to\s—with dra=n, ‘he who is ambitious like ourselves.’
zhlw/sei—note the difference between zh=los and fqo/nos. L. and S. s.v. zh=los. ei) ... ke/kthtai—=o(/stis ke/kthtai=o( kekthme/nos.
*)en tw=| paro/nti—‘for a time,’ i.e. until other nations become habituated to it. Cf. c. 41, 2.

e(/teroi e(te/rwn—c. 51, 1 and 4. Cf. I. 84 diafe/rein a)/nqrwpon a)nqrw/pou and 3
above; Livy, XXI. 10, 4 ex bellis bella serendo.

o(/stis ... lamba/nei—=o( lamba/nwn. e)pi\ megi/stois—cf. c. 29, 3 e)p' w)feli/a|. h( de\ k.t.l.—there is only one idea in the subject: lit. ‘that which is the splendour of the present remains also the glory of the future in memory for ever,’ by which he means great power, ta\ me/gista above. In the present, such power is viewed with dislike, though it is a splendid thing to have; but hatred is short-lived, and in the future will be changed into admiration and respect. Even if this great power decline, it is still remembered. The second member is the more important.

*)/es te to\ me/llon—there is chiasmus here; parauti/ka, e)s to\ e)/peita, e)s to\ me/llon, e)s to\ au)ti/ka. progno/ntes—‘providing for future glory and present escape from disgrace, secure both by making an effort now.’

e)pikhrukeu/esqe—see c. 1 e)pemei/gnunto. Cf. e)pidika)zesqai. oi(/tines—with this conclusion, cf. the close of Nicias' speech, VI. 14 to\ kalw=s a)/rcai tou=t' ei)=nai, o(\s a)\n k.t.l. pro\s—propter, c. 91, 4.
ou(=toi—c. 58, 3.
kai\ po/lewn kai\ i)diwtw=n—sums up the lesson of the whole speech. The interests of the individual cannot be considered apart from those of the community. Cf. Isocr. 3, 51.
*th=s e)p' au)to\n—‘the indignation directed against him.’
deinw=n—here regarded from the point of view of the sufferers; in 77, 1 from that of those who cause the suffering.
a)pa/gein th\n g.—cf. c. 59, 3.
*)anepei/qonto—c. 14, 1.
o( me\n—cf. c. 21, 3.
a)p' e)lasso/nwn—‘having less to start with,’ i.e. before the war.
e)ste/rhto—so Andoc. 3, 8; Aeschin. 2, 173 of this period.
{e)n} oi)kodomi/ais—‘consisting in buildings and costly furniture,’ with kth/mata. Cf. Dinarch. 1, 5 h( e)n tw=| le/gein du/namis. to\ de\ me/giston—‘above all,’ adverbial accus.
*pro/teron ... pri\n—this insertion of pro/teron is due to the comparative and negative nature of pri/n. It is very common. M. T. 658.
xrh/masin—cf. IV. 65 fugh=| e)zhmi/wsan. For the probable circumstances see Intr. p. lxxvi.
*(/usteron—Intr. p. lxxvii.
ou) pollw=|—about six months.

o(/per filei=—Thuc.'s objections to a thorough-going democracy are (1) that it is uncertain in its policy, (2) that it encourages rivalry among demagogues, and consequently party strife. Cf. Burke, Reflections, ‘Not being wholly unread in the authors who had seen the most of those constitutions, I cannot help concurring with their opinion, that an absolute democracy, no more than absolute monarchy, is to be reckoned among the legitimate forms of government.’

pa/nta—i.e.
made him strathgo\s au)tokra/twr. w(=n ... h)/lgei—cf. Eur. Hec. 1256 paido\s a)lgei=n, a poetical construction. Supply tau=ta, accus. of respect, to a)mblu/teroi, and to plei/stou a)/cion. h( cu/mpasa—the state is contrasted with the individuals of which it consists. Cf. c. 7, 2. cu/mpasa h( would contrast the whole with part of the city.
*(/oson te ... e)pei/ te—i.e. throughout his administra- tion, both before and after the outbreak of war. For te ... te, cf. c. 22, 1, 64, 2, 6.
prou/sth—Pericles had been decidedly the first man in Athens since the ostracism of Thucydides, son of Melesias, in 444 B.C.

e)n th=| ei)rh/nh| —i.e. the Thirty Years' peace of 445 B.C. (So Bloomfield rightly; for the period 458-445 was regarded as po/lemos, Andoc. 3, 6; Aeschin. 2, 174. Pericles' decisive appearance dates from B.C. 468, but as po/lemos below cannot include B.C. 458-445, ei)rh/nh cannot include 468-458.)
diefu/lacen—the aor. gives the result of his policy. Cf. c. 49, 5. Andocides and Aeschines dilate on the advantages gained by Athens during the peace.

megi/sth—attributes the greatness of Athens, on which Pericles so often insisted, to Pericles himself. Andoc. and Aesch. wrongly assign the creation of the reserve fund (c. 24) to the period of the peace. Andoc., being a consummate liar, probably did this on purpose, and misled Aesch. and puzzled some modern historians.

du/namin—sc. th=s po/lews. Cf. 13 below. Unfortunately Pericles failed to notice two sources of weakness: (1) the growing discontent of the allies, (2) the lack of rising politicians who would carry on his policy after his death.
*)epebi/w—‘lived beyond’ the beginning of the war.
d. e)/th kai\ m. e(\c—Intr. p. xvii.

e)gnw/sqh—here follows a defence of Pericles' war policy. The proofs offered of his wisdom are (1) the reversal of his policy led to disaster, (2) in spite of that reversal, Athens held out against great odds until ruined by internal dissensions. This may prove that his policy was good, but Thuc. goes too far in 13 when he implies that Athens would certainly have succeeded if Pericles' advice had been followed.
h( pro/noia e)s—cf. c. 64, 6, and for the order, c. 52, 1.
*(hsuxa/zontas—i.e. they were to adopt the policy of wearing out Sparta, and not to attempt to bring the war to an end by a few battles.
nautiko\n qerapeu/ontes—the object of Athens was to obtain the recognition of her maritime supremacy, as it existed in 431.
a)rxh(n mh( e)piktwme/nous— not to attempt conquests while the war lasted.

th=| po/lei kinduneu/ein—‘endanger the existence of the state,’ by distant
undertakings or great land battles.

oi( de\—other ancient authors contrasted Pericles with the demagogues who followed him, as Isocr. 8, 127, [Aristot.] Rep. Ath. 28 e(/ws *p. proeisth/kei tou= dh/mou belti/w ta\ kata\ th\n politei/an h)=n, teleuth/santos de\ *perikle/ous polu\ xei/rw. e)/cw tou= pole/mou—‘things which seemed to have no connection with the war,’ but really had; e.g. the rivalry between politicians, which led to bad government and consequent mismanagement.
sfi/si—for sfi/sin au)toi=s as c. 4, 1.
kata\—cf. 11 below.
tou\s cumma/xous— by producing ill-feeling towards Athens among the allies.
katorqou/mena—reflecting on the selfish policy of Cleon and Alcibiades.
bla/bh k.—‘proved injurious.’ bla/bh sums up ta\ kakw=s pepoliteume/na, the result of which was seen in the Decelean war.
*)aciw/mati—c. 37, 1.
xrhma)/twn d. a)dwro/tatos— Thuc. again alludes to Pericles' trial. Cf. c. 60, 5.
e)leuqe/rws—cf. c. 37, 2, ‘while respecting their liberty.’
ou) ma=llon—‘instead of.’

dia\ to\ mh\ . . le/gein—this is answered by e)/xwn. Cf. v. 16, 1 dia\ to\ eu)tuxei=n parallel to nomi/zwn, VII. 70, 4 dia\ to\ feu/gein parallel to e)piple/ousa. e)c ou) p.—contrast c. 17, 2 mh\ e)p' a)gaqw=|. e)p' a)ciw/sei—c. 34, 6. Cf. e)p' ai)sxra=| ai)ti/a| VII. 48, 4; and Livy, XXI. 49 haud cum imparatis, for cum haud imparatis.

pro\s o)rgh/n—‘angrily.’ (Arnold translates ‘so as to excite their anger,’ because pro\s o)rgh/n corresponds to pro\s h(donh/n; which no one would think of translating ‘willingly.’ But neither does pro\s h(donh\n = ‘so as to excite their pleasure’; rather pro\s h(. le/gein = ‘to speak pleasantly,’ ‘to say pleasant things’: moreover Arnold presses the antithesis too closely. a)nteipei=n is not the opposite of le/gein.) Cf. III. 43, 5; VIII. 27, 6. For Pericles' freedom of speech, cf Eupolis, frag. to\ ke/ntron e)gkate/lipe toi=s a)krowme/nois, comparing Pericles to a bee.
*gou=n—‘at any rate,’ introducing an illustration which explains in what sense the preceding statement is to be taken.
kate/plhssen—later demagogues, on the contrary, tried only to humour the people.
e)gi/gneto/ te—‘and so it came about that.’ This is an explicit statement that Pericles owed his ascendancy to the influence he had acquired by his abilities.
lo/gw| me\n—such a tempered democracy was the ideal constitution of Thuc. Cf. VIII. 24, 4, 97, 2.
u(po\ ... a)rxh/—the verbal substantive constructed like a pass. partic.

*oi( de\ u(/steron—answering e)kei=nos me\n in 8 above. So i)/soi ... o)/ntes corresponds to dunato\s w)\n. au)toi\ ... pro\s a)llh\lous—might have been au)toi\ pro\s a(tou/s. Cf. c. 5, 5 on diabouleuo/menwn. kaq' h(dona\s—depends on e)ndio(o/nai, ‘so as to suit any popular whim.’

kai\ ta\ pra/gmata—i.e. to gain their
object they were ready not only to flatter the people, but even to place the administration of the state entirely in their hands.
e)ndido/nai—after e)tra/ponto ‘they set themselves to.’
*)/alla—e.g. the rejection of the Spartan overtures for peace in 410 B.C., and the aggressive warfare of 424 B.C.
w(s—‘as is natural’ when the administration of a great empire is entirely in the hands of the people.

o( ... plou=s—sc. h(marth/qh, o( plou=s being viewed as an e)/rgon tou= pole/mou. Cf. III. 67 a(martano/mena e)/rga, Plato, Rep. VIII. p. 544 D po/leis h(marthme/nas. (h(marth/qh is not impersonal, a constr. nearly confined to perf. pass.)

a(ma/rthma pro\s ou(\s—the construction is similar to c. 44, 1 to\ d' eu)tuxe)s, oi(\ a)\n k.t.l., 62, 4 katafro/nhsis de\ o(\s a)\n k.t.l.; thus a(ma/rthma h)=n pro\s ou(\s e). follows the construction of h(ma)rtanon pro\s ou(\s e). ‘It was not so much an error of judgment with regard to the people whom they were intending to attack; the blunder they made was rather that the people responsible for the expedition did not consult the interests of those who had been sent out in their subsequent measures.’
o(/son ... e)pigignw/skontes—sc. a(ma/rthma h)=n. Cf. IV. 26 ai)/tion h)=n oi( *lakedaimo/nioi proeipo/ntes. oi( e)kpe/myantes—the extreme democrats.
ou) ta\ pro/sfora —of the measures taken after the mutilation of the Hermae, esp. the recall of Alcibiades.

kata\—‘in consequence of intrigues for the leadership of the democracy.’ Cf. kata\ peni/an c. 37, 1. Thuc. alludes to the position of dh/mou prosta/ths, recognised leader of the popular party. The list, according to [Arist.] Rep. Ath. 28, is Solon, Pisistratus, Cleisthenes, Xanthippus, Themistocles, Ephialtes, Pericles; after whom the popular leaders degenerated with Cleon and Cleophon.
ta/ te—‘they conducted the military operations without vigour.’ Thuc. shifts the blame of the disaster from Nicias to the home authorities.
a)mblu/tera—with less vigour than they had since the war broke out.
ta\ peri\—accus. of respect; e/tara(xqhsan being ‘ingressive.’
prw=ton—i.e. for the first time during the war. What ruined Athens in the war was the internal discord that broke out after Pericles' death.
*sfale/ntes ... paraskeuh=|—for the dat. cf. 7 above.
me\n—answered by kai\ ou) pro/teron, just as we sometimes find me\n ... te/, te .. de/. basile/ws— Darius.
prosgenome/nw|—from 407 B.C.
pro/teron ... h)\— cf. c. 40, 2. M. T. 653.
e)n sfi/si—for e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s. See c. 4, 1.

kata\—cf. 11 above. [peripeso/ntes]—peripi/ptein regularly takes the dat., and no case in which it takes any prep. but e)n is known The phrase sumforai=s peripesei=n is very common, and probably a commentator wrote this in the margin to illustrate kata\ .. e)sfa/lhsan.
*tosou=ton—me\n might have followed.
e)peri/s- seuse—sc. tau=ta from a)f' w(=n, ‘such an abundance of resources had Pericles, by means of which he of himself foresaw.’
au)tw=n—‘alone.’
pole/mw|— c. 13, 9.
*ei)si\—sc. oi( *zaku/nqioi. Cf. c. 26, 2.
tw=n e)k— attraction of prep., due to a)/poikoi.
*)epe/pleon—‘were on board.’
*knh=mos—c. 80 fol.
nau/arxos—an office held for a year. The admiral was almost as important as the kings, who commanded the land forces. His power increased when the Spartan navy became more important.
cunexw/roun—‘did not seem likely to yield,’ imperf. of uncompleted action. Cf. Eur. Her. Fur. 538 kai\ ta)/m' e)/qnh|ske te/kn', a)pwllu/mhn d' e)gw/.
*)aristeu\s—o( *)adeima/ntou, Herod. VII. 137. Herod. digresses to tell the story of this embassy, and mentions Aristeus, Aneristus, and Nicolaus.
*prato/damos—see not. crit. Mss. often Atticise un-Attic names.
i)di/a|—probably he represented the philo. Lacoman party at Argos; the city was neutral, c. 9, 2.
*sita/lkhn—c. 29. strateu=sai e)pi\— ‘send an army to relieve.’
h)=n ... poliorkou=n—c. 12, 2. h)=n = versabatur, ‘was engaged.’
di' e)kei/nou—‘with his aid.’
*farna/khn—satrap of Dascylium, the N. satrapy of Asia Minor, Sardis being the S. satrapy.
a)nape/myein—‘escort inland’; cf. a)nabai/nein.
*th\n e)kei/nou po/lin—i.e. Athens.
to\ me/ros—with bla/ywsin, ‘do their hest to injure,’ adverbial accus.
*peraiw/sein—‘send them across.’ No subject is given for e)/mellon, but ‘Sitalces and Sadocus’ has to be supplied from the context.
pri\n e)sbai/nein—generally pri\n takes aor. infin.; the pres. means ‘before the embarkation began.’
kai\ e)ke/leusen—sc. tou\s pemfqe/ntas. He ‘had given orders’ before the expedition started.

*ta\ ... tw=n e)pi\ *q.—‘the difficulties in Chalcidice.’ Aristeus had been sent with 2000 men from Corinth to aid Potidaea when it revolted, I. 60. pa/ntas—probably Cleon was responsible for the death of the Spartan envoys. They should have been kept in prison as hostages. Pericles had no voice now in the government, and Thuc. hints that he views this act as a blunder.
dikaiou=ntes—c. 41, 5.

oi(=sper . . u(ph=rcan—attraction for a(/per u(ph=rcan. Shil. quotes Dem. 19, 321 ta\s eu)ergesi/as a(\s u(ph=rcan ei)s u(ma=s, lsocr. 14, 57 th\n au)th\n eu)ergesi/an h(/nper au)toi\ tugxa/nomen ei/s u(ma=s u(pa/rcantes, Aeschin. 2, 26 ta\s eu)ergesi/as a(\s u(mei=s u(ph/rcate. ou(\s e)/labon—probably some special occasion is here referred to, and the merchants
were captured by privateers.
pa/ntas dh\—‘without exception,’ dh\ strengthening pa/ntas. Cf. c. 77, 2.
mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn—c. 72, 1.
*)anasth/santes—cf. c. 96, 1. pollou\s is attracted to the partic, and stands for polloi/, by a common idiom.
*)/argos—the Peloponnesians were very anxious to weaken the influence of Athens on the west coast, as they wanted to improve their means of communication with Sicily.
*)/hrcato prw=ton—c. 36, 1, 48, 1. the account which follows is inserted to clear up an uncertainty which existed in Thuc.'s time with regard to the history of the northern Argos.
*)a. th\n a)/llhn—Intr. p. xxxvi.
a)resko/menos th=|— the pass. of a)re/skw is only found in Herod. and Thuc. of Attic writers.
th=| ... katasta/sei—he found that his brother Alcmaeon had killed their mother Eriphyle. Emigration was then the last resource of the discontented.
o)nomo/sas—the time of the partic. is not here past relatively to the verb e)/ktise, but is comcident with it. M. T. 150.
*megi/sth .. dunatwta/tous—cf. c. 64, 3; me/geqos of the size, du/namis of the influence of a state.
*(upo\ c. . piezo/menoi—c. 47, 4.
h(llhni/sqhsan— ‘adopted the Greek language, which they now speak.’
