th\n nu=n g.—cognate accus.
a)po\ tw=n *)a. cunoikhsa/ntwn—‘as the result of this joint settlement.’ Cf. c. 49, 4 and 2, 1. Ambracia was a colony of Corinth.
*)argei/ous— = oi( *)amfi/loxoi of 7.
xro/nw|— = xro/nw| u(/steron.
*formi/wna—some time before the Peloponnesian war.
*)amprakiw/tas—those in Argos.
ai(rou=si ... kai\ h)ndrapo/disan—contrast c. 67, 3. See 2 below.
*(h c.—c. 9, 4. It was very important to Athens.
*)/exqran ... e)poih/santo—act. of e)/xqra e)ge/neto in 2 above.
e)n tw=| pole/mw|—c. 65, 7.
*xao/nwn—see c. 80, 5.
th(n de\ po/lin—put before w(s for the sake of the antithesis.
*(ormw/menos—‘making Naupactus his head-quarters.’
e)pi\—‘to the coast.’
tau=ta—‘in these parts.’
a)rgurologw=si—‘collect arrears of tribute.’
mh( e)w=sin—‘prevent.’
*fashli/dos—a Dorian port of Lycia.
th=s e)kei=qen—for th=s e)kei=, by attraction to a)po/. Cf. c. 84, 5.

*)apoqnh/|skei .. die/fqeire—‘fell after losing.’ The aor. is antecedent in time to the hist. pres., but is placed after it, and joined by kai\ as the more important member. Cf. c. 67, 3 cullamba/nei .. e)ke/leusen.

*ai(/ te ... o(/ te ... kai\ a)/lla te ... kai/ tines—there are two members to this sentence, united by the first kai/: each of these two is bisected, the first by te ... te, the second by te ... kai/ tines. ou)de\n m. a)pani/stasan—‘did not force the Athenians to raise the siege,’ any more than the embassies sent by Sparta to Athens before the war demanding that the army should be withdrawn from Potidaea. Intr. p. lxviii. a)pani/sthmi is not found in any other Attic writer. Herod. III. 156.
e)pegege/nhto—cf. c. 4, 2.
a)nagkai/as—‘in their straits for food.’ ‘Non pas nécessaire à la vie, mais imposée par la nécessité.’ Cr. Livy, XXI. 14 pacem magis necessariam quam aequam.

a)llh/lwn e)ge/geunto—Josephus, VI. 3, 3 wrongly calls such cannibalism a horror unheard of among Greeks. With the austere brevity of Thuc.'s description contrast Macaulay's account of the sufferings in Londonderry, Hist. Eng. c. 12, but the propriety of the close of the picture, where the story of ‘the fat man’ is introduced, may be questioned.
ou(/tw dh\—c. 12, 4.
e)pi\ sfi/si t.— ‘against’; contrast c. 90, 2. Cf. III. 13 ai( d' e)f' h(mi=n teta/xatai. *xenofw=nti—c. 79.
*(orw=ntes me\n ... a)nhlwkui/as te—me\n is answered by te in I. 144, 2; III. 46, 2; IV. 32, 2. Cf. c. 65, 12.
e)n —belongs to th\n talaipwri/an; for the use cf. c. 3, 1.
e)s th\n p.—Intr. p. lxxvii.

*)epi\ toi=sde cune/bhsan, e)celqei=n—cf. IV. 16 nau=s para- dou=nai komi/santas *)aqhnai/ois ... ai( me\n spondai\ e)pi\ tou/tois e)ge/nonto. In VIII. 18 the imperative is used throughout the terms. ‘The men ... to go out.’ The inf. is not for e)pi\ tw=| e)celqei=n, but is the use noticed in c. 13, 1.
cu\n e(ni\—cum singulis vestimentis, Livy, XXI. 12.

gunai=kas de\—probably Thuc. is quoting the actual terms; so he is not responsible for what seems at first an odd correction of gunai=kas above, but is quite suited to the cumbrous diction of officials. ‘With one garment, except the women.’
*)/aneu au)tw=n—injussu suo or privato consilio.
cune/- bhsan—might have been cumbai=en, as in 21, 3. M. T. 713, 714.

h(=| e)bou/lonto—Recta, e)krath/samen a)
 h(=| e oulo/meqa, whereas h)=| bou/lointo would represent h(=| a)
 boulw/meqa. The sentence is equivalent to krath/santes a)
 e)xrhsa/meqa th=| po/lei h(=| e)boulo/meqa. Cf. c. 4, 7.
e)poi/kous—c. 27, 1. See on c. 101, 6.

*tau=ta me
 ... kai\—the break between me
 and tou= d', c. 71, is certainly not violent enough to warrant the supposition that kai\ deu/teron e)/tos k.t.l. is spurious. In a well-marked antithesis like tau=ta me
 ... xeimw=ni, tou= de\ ... qe/rous, an author could insert any parenthesis he chose between the me
 and de\
clauses. (So Andoc. 1, 29 peri\ me
 tw=n musthri/wn summarises what has preceded: then follows a parenthesis of five sections: then in 34 peri\ de\ tw=n a)naqhma/twn introduces what follows.)
*)es me\n ... e)stra/teusan d'—cf. c. 94, 4, 98, 2.
pe/myantes ... e)/legon—c. 6, 2.

*ou) di/kaia—cf. c. 5, 5, the Plataeans had told the Thebans o(/ti ou) ta\ pepoihme/na o(si/ws dra/seian. They now appeal both to to\ di/kaion and to\ kalo/n. pate/rwn w(=n e)ste— = tw=n pate/rwn. *pausani/as—this was done after the battle of Plataea, 479 B C., after burying the fallen in the territory of Plataea, which was declared autonomous and inviolable.
e)leuqerw/sas—this would remind the Spartans of their professed object in the present war. How could it be a)/cion e(autw=n to come e)pi\ doulei/a| th=| *plataiw=n? Cf. c. 8, 4.

e)leuqerw/sas . . qu/sas—the first partic. is prior in time to the second, and the second prior to the main verb. Cf. c. 52, 3 fqa/santes . . e)piqe/ntes ... u(fh=pton. cuna/rasqai to\n k.— cf. Demosth. 1, 24 s. ta\ pra/gmata, but the gen. is commoner.
*)eleuqeri/w|—Pausanias mentions an altar of Zeus Eleutherius and a festival called Eleutheria at Plataea.
a)pedi/dou—‘conceded’ the right, the imperf. representing the details of the act,
au)tono/mous—with e)/xontas. strateu=sai—the change of tense from oi)kei=n shows that the pres. denotes the continuous, the aor. the single act.
ei) de\ mh/— introduces the alternative, whether a positive or a negative precedes.
a)mu/nein—‘Pausanias can scarcely have offered these guarantees in the name of the confederacy without a resolution of the council of strategi to this effect.’ Busolt, G. Gesch. III. p. 212.
tw=n h(mi=n e)xqi/stwn—c. 1 tw=n e(kate/rois cumma/xwn.
*(orki/ous genome/nous—cf. Livy, XXI. 10 foederum arbitros ac testes.

tou\s u(mete/rous patrw/|ous kai\ h(: e)gxwri/ous —‘the gods of your race and of our country.’ patrw=oi are gods of a family. Cl. says the one art. shows that the same gods are meant by both expressions, but it may only show that the qeoi\ o(/rkioi are contrasted with the q. patrw=|oi and q. e)gxw/rioi. The q. o(/rkioi, Arn. says, would be affronted by the violation of the oath; the q. patrw=|oi of Sparta because the act of Pausanias was annulled; the q. e)gxw/rioi of Plataea because they would be driven into exile if the strangers seized their land.
e)dikai/wse—c. 41, 5.
*tosau=ta—c. 12, 1.
u(polabw\n—‘in answer’; as often in Plato.
di/kaia le/gete—i.e. the justice of your words depends on how far your own acts correspond to your statements.
au)tonomei=sqe—imper.

au)tw=n—the influence
of the rel. is lost. Cf. c. 4, 5.
tw=n a)/llwn—i.e. those who did not take part in the battle and ceremony of 479, and are now under the rule of Athens.
h(=s—cf. c. 43, 4 ou(\s nu=n u(mei=s. metasxo/ntes—share in the liberation of Greece as your confederates did then.
pro/teron—the occasion is unknown.
mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn—c. 67, 4.
de/xesqe—c. 7, 2.
*)adu/nata—the plur. points to the details of a com- plicated action.
par' e)kei/nois—cf. c. 21, 3.
ei(=en—the infin. is usual after ga\r on continuing Or. Obliqua, and this is the only instance of the opt. in Thuc. See also on c. 80, 1, M. T. 675.
ou)k e)pitre/pwsi—i.e. to remain neutral.
e)/norkoi—‘being included in the treaty in consequence of the stipulation that the Plataeans should admit both.’

peira/swsi—in the sense of peirw=mai. Cf. c. 19, 1, 77, 2. Several MSS. read peira/sousi, and the fut. indic. after a verb of fearing is occasionally found, as Aristoph. Eccles. 465, Plat. Rep. V. p. 451 A. But there is no case in Thuc.
*(umei=s de\—here de\ = a)lla\ in an answer.
gh=s o(/rous —art. omitted in a geographical expression. Cf. c. 13, 6.
e(/comen—sc. a)\ a)\n parala/bwmen. parakataqh/khn—pred. Cf. Plat. Rep. I. p. 332 a)podou=nai parakataqeme/nw|. e)rgazo/menoi —cf. xrh/mata e)/nerga.
*pei/qwsin—perhaps pei/swsin should be read.
h(me/- ras e)spei/sato—accus. of duration, e)n ai(=s replacing the numeral.
ei)ko\s h)=n—c. 11, 8.
komisqh=nai—‘return’ from Athens.
*)apagge/llontes—Intr. p. lxxviii.
*cu/mmaxoi—in B.C. 520.
perio/fesqai—sc. a)dikou- me/nous. e)piskh/ptousi—regular word for a solemn order; esp. used of a dying person's last requests.
pro\s—the only case of this use in Thuc.
*)ebouleu/santo ... o(rw=ntas ... pa/sxontas—the accus., where the nom. is expected, is due to ei) dei=, which interrupts the subject.
a)du/nata—c. 72, 2.
*)enteu=qen dh\—marking the decisive moment. Cf. c. 58, 2.
prw=ton me\n—answered by tosau=ta e)piqeia/sas c. 75, 1.
*cuni/stores—a solemn word. Aesch. Ag. 1055, Soph. Ant. 542, Eur. Supp. 1174.

ou)/te th\n a/rxh\n h)/lqomen —‘we did not at first attack.’ This is answered by ou)/te nu=n. de\—answers a)di/kws. to\ cunw/moton—the oath to aid in giving freedom to Greece. It would certainly be supposed that the oaths then taken were only binding in the war against Persia. Cf. c. 72, 1.
gh=n th/nde e)n h(=|—the art may be omitted with demonstratives when a relative clause follows.

au)th\n
—c. 4, 5.
e)nagwni/sasqai—c. 20, 4. Eur. Bacchae, 507 e)ndustuxh=sai ... e)pith/deios. h)/n ti poiw=men—litotes; cf. h)/n ti pa/sxh| ‘in case he die.’
kai\ ei)ko/ta—the emphatic member, as always when kai\ is inserted between polu\s and another adj.
a)diki/as—depends on kola/zesqai and u(pa/rxousi. toi=s u(.—these dats. depend on cuggnw/mones e)/ste = cugxwrh/sate.
periestau/rwsen—sc. o( basileu/s. tou= mhde/na—to fetch supplies.
xw=ma e)/xoun—this was not quite close to the wall; but nearly touched it. Cf. c. 77, 3 to\ metacu\ tou= tei/xous kai\ th=s prosxw/sews. au)tw=n—the Plataeans.
*kiqairw=nos—the town lay at the N. foot of Cithaeron.
e)kate/rwqen—sc. tou= xw/matos, on both sides the mound was strengthened by planks crossing one another at right angles.
a)nti\ toi/xwn—cf. c. 3, 3. The mound did not run all round the town, and its purpose was to support the siege engines.
u(lh\n—‘loose wood’) (cu/la, timber.
dih|rhme/noi—middle, sc. to\ xou=n. a)napau/las— ‘relief-parties.’
cenagoi\—the Lacedaemonian commanders of the allies, who were superior to the generals sent by the allies themselves.
cunefestw=tes—i.e. with the officers of the allies.

cu/linon tei=xos—a frame-work of timber, in which the bricks were secured. Buildings are sometimes constructed in this way in Germany. tei=xos is not really ‘a wall’ here, any more than in Pindar, Pyth. III. 38 tei/xei qe/san e)n culi/nw| su/ggonoi kou/ran, se/las d' a)mfe/dramen la/bron *(afai/stou, of which Thuc. was probably thinking.
cu/ndesmos—sc. tw=n pli/nqwn. purfo/rois—a common expedient in ancient sieges.
me/ga—pred. Cf. Demosth. 2, 8.

dielo/ntes—the wooden face of the Spartan xw=ma sloped towards the wall of Plataea, so as to touch it at the ground; hence prose/pipte. h)/|reto ... kai\ a)ntanh/|ei—parataxis, expressing well the simultaneous advance of wall and mound.

tarsoi=s—this word describes almost any series of parallel lines, as in basket-work; here reed wattles, (Used also of the ‘tarsal’ bones in the hand and foot; of a bird's wing, and of a bank of oars. The Atticists and their followers notice the word extensively.)
kala/mou—gen. of material.

e)ni/llontes—the primary sense is ‘to twist, roll.’ It is connected with i)llo/s, a squint, and Pausanias the Atticist gives e)ni/llein' to\ o)fqalmoi=s katamwka=sqai (to mock at anyone by winking). From this notion of twisting the word comes to mean ‘to squeeze.’ (This word is much noticed by the Atticists. L. and S. are unsatisfactory; Arn. has a good
note.)
to\ dih|rhme/non—‘the hole’ in the xw=ma. diaxeo/menon—sc. au)to/, what has just been described, viz. the xw=ma as repaired with the wattles. Cf. c. 75, 2.
*tou=to—accus. of respect. [

kai\ cuntekmhra/menoi]— as the xw=ma was close to the wall and touched it at the base, it is plain that the Plataeans would not need any tekmh/ria to discover how far to burrow. The edd. speak of calculating distance and direction, but the Peloponnesians had nothing to do but to dig straight ahead, until the xw=ma began to subside.
xou=n—the earth of the xw=ma, as it fell into the mine.

*)oli/goi pro\s polloi\s—a common antithesis; c. 100, 5; I. 110; III. 112; IV. 26; V. 80; VII. 87. e)/nqen kai\ e)/nqen—as the enemy gained on them, the Plataeans built a crescent-shaped wall, concave to the besiegers, starting from the extremities of that part of the wall opposite the xw=ma, so that in case the enemy should take the raised wall by storm, they might find another wall behind.
au)toi=—i.e. tou= mega/lou tei/xous) (tou= braxe/os = the part which had not been raised.
e)k tou= e)nto\s—‘inside,’ like a parte.

ma=llon— they had not been exposed to a cross-fire before. Thuc. means that the further in to the crescent the Peloponnesians got in building the xw=ma, the more exposed they would be to a fire from each side: proxwrou=ntas e)/sw belongs to gi/gnesqai also. (There is no need to explain this, as one scholar does, as for e)n a)m. gignome/nous ma=llon ponei=n,) Cf. Tac. Hist. v. 11, of the siege of Jerusalem, muri per artem obliqui aut introrsus sinuati, ut latera oppugnantium ad ictus patescerent.

tou= m. oi)kodomh/matos—after e)pi\ me/ga, which = me/ga me/ros and replaces the accus, after kate/seise, as in IV. 100 it replaces a nom., e)sesidh/rwto e)pi\ me/ga tou= a)/llou cu/lou. kata\ —‘by.’ Cf. c. 99, 1. Aeschin. 2, 124 ei)splei=n kata\ to\n potamo/n. kate/seise—‘shook.’
a)/llas—sc. prosh=gon. kai\ dokou\s—the rel. sentence is changed to a principal; this is due to the length of the second clause.

a)po\ th=s tomh=s e(. —‘at both ends,’ sc. tw=n dokw=n. This belongs to a)rth/santes, as also does a)po\ keraiw=n, stout poles, like a ship's yard-arm, made fast to the wall and projecting from it above the siege engines.
a)nelku/santes—on the double partic. with a)fi/esan, see c. 15, 2.
e)gkarsi/as—at an angle to the mhxanai/, xalarai=s—‘by letting the chains go.’
dia\ xeiro\s—c. 13, 2.
to\ proe/xon—‘the point.’
e)mbolh=s—‘head’ of the ram.

xw/mati—after a)ntitei/xisma. Cf. c. 61, 2 dh/lwsis a(/pasi. Thus mei=zon is not required before e)gi/gneto. Cf. v. 116 w(s au)toi=s ta\ diabath/ria i(era\ ou)k e)gi/gneto. a)ntitei/xisma —i.e. to\ mhnoeide\s tei=xos. deinw=n—‘means of coercing them.’
peira=sai—c. 19, 1; also for pa=san i)de/an.
fake/lous—an archaism, according to Marcellinus' life of Thuc. 52. It is found in Herod., Hippocrates, once in Eur., and in later authors.
pare/ballon—‘threw side by side.’
tou= tei/xous—the wall that had been raised, to\ me/ga oi)kodo/mhma. The object was to set fire to the wood-work of the superstructure. Cf. c. 75, 5.
th=s a)/llhs—after o(/son. po/lews—inside the wall, the space between it and the new mhnoeide\s tei=xos.

o)/resin—cf. Pindar, Pyth. III. 36 polla\n d' o)/rei pu=r e)c e(no\s spe/rmatos e)nqoro\n a)i)stwsen u(/lan, Hom. Il. 2, 455 pu=r e)pifle/gei a)/speton u(/lhn ou)/reos e)k korufh=s, Eur. Ino. fr. mikrou= ga\r e)k lampth=ros *)idai=on le/pas prh/seien a)/n tis. Thuc. naturally mentions the proverbial case of a forest on fire.
u(p' a)ne/mwn —a very common phrase. Cf. c. 85, 6. [
a)p' au)tou=]— explained as = a)po\ tou= trifqh=nai, or a)po\ tou= puro/s. In either case it is quite superfluous.
e)de/hse—subject tou=to. e)pege/neto au)th=|—i.e. th=| flogi/. e)pi/foron—sc. e)s th\n po/lin.
u(/dwr—this clause is in apposition to to)de, both ga\r and a finite verb being dispensed with.
me/ros]—Intr. p. xliii.
kata\ po/leis— ‘dividing the space among the different contingents.’
e)nto\s —i.e. between the circumvallation and the city wall) (e)/cwqen.

*)arktou/rou e)pitola/s—e)pitolh\ = the first appearance) (a)natolh\ = the daily rising. The date is Sept. 18th, the e(w/|a e)pitolh\ when A. rises just before sunrise) (e(speri/a e)pitolh/, which is in March. Cf. Soph. O. T. 1137 e)c h)=ros ei)s a)rktou=ron e(kmh/nous xro/nous. Verg. G. 1, 68.
plh=qos to\ a)/.—c. 2, 2.
a)/xrhston—c. 6, 4. Here oi( a)/xrhstoi, the general term is distinguished from oi( presbu/tatoi, the particular, and means those whose incapacity was due to other causes than age.
e)gkataleleimme/noi—c. 6, 4. Plat. Phaedo, p. 91 C w(/sper me)litta to\ ke/ntron e)gkatalipw/n. sitopoioi/—pred; so in Lat., Livy, XXI. 30, 8 advena cultor; ib. 36 exercitus tiro.
t. oi( cu/mpantes—cf. o( pa=s a)riqmo/s c. 7, 2.
toiau/th —pred., with kateskeua/sqh = toiau/th h)=n h( th=s poliorki/as kataskeuh/, these were the arrangements.

e)pistratei/a|—cf. e)pi/plous c. 17, 4. Thuc. would have written toi=s *plataieu=si were it not for the proximity of so many datives. Cf. e)piboh/qeia th=| nh/sw| III. 51; e)pidromh
 tw=| teixi/smati IV. 23; for the obj. = gen. cf. VII. 70 tw=n ue
 fulakh
 tw=n d' e(piboulh/n. *bottiai/ous—in the N.W. of
Chalcidice, which was called *bottikh/. a)kma/zontos—c. 19, 1.
tri/tos au)to/s—Intr. p. lxxvii. He had power superior to that of his colleagues for this expedition.
*spa/rtwlon—between Olynthus and Apollonia.
prosxwrh/sein u(po\—pass. of prosa/gesqai c. 30, 2.
e)/ndoqen —regarded from the Athenian point of view.
prasso/ntwn —c. 2, 3.
o(pli=tai te kai\ stratia\—‘hoplites and other troops,’ the general being again added to the particular. Cf. c. 78, 3.
e)s—‘as a.’
*xalkide/wn—those from Olynthus.
i(ppe/as—the Athenian cavalry were defeated in 431 twice during the invasion of Attica, c. 19, 22.
*ei)=xon—sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi. *krousi/dos—on the Ther- maic Gulf.
e)pibohqou=sin—sc. toi=s *xalkideu=si.
*prosgignome/nois—‘by the arrival of this reinforce- ment’
a)naxwrou=si—sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi.
*(=h| dokoi/h—cf. c. 100, 5, per occasionem adequitantes.
e)pi\ polu/—of space, as c. 75, 2.
*(upospo/ndous—see c. 92, 4.
tou\s au(tw=n—contrasted with those of the enemy; not implying that the Chalcidians and Bottiaeans separately took up their dead. Cf. IV. 97, 1.

*)amprakiw=tai—they had made an attack on Argos in concert with the Chaones and other tribes of barbarians in the autumn of 430 B.C. c. 68, 9. The Chaones were possibly a remnant of the Pelasgi. Hence they are sometimes treated as Greeks, though Thuc. always calls them barbarians. Grote, II. p. 234, Curtius, Hist. G. I. 104 ‘In later times they were regarded as barbarians ... but, according to their origin, they could claim perfect equality with the other branches of the Greek people.’ (Cf. Matthew Arnold, Lit. and Dogma, init.)
pa=san—this elaborate undertaking is in marked contrast, with the issue, c. 82; and it is quite in Thuc.'s manner to make the opening imposing under such circumstances. Cf. c. 7, 2.

*)aqhnai/wn— the Ambraciots were actuated by the tribe hatred existing in that quarter, and they had an old grudge against Phormio (c. 68). Now that Athens was in difficulties, they took the chance of revenge, and were at pains to demonstrate to Sparta that they were very important friends to her.

a)duna/twn— through being occupied with the fleet, and in protecting their coasts. tw=n a)po\ q. *)a.—a)po\ is for e)pi\ by attraction to cumbohqei=n, ‘the Acarnanians on the sea-coast would be unable to aid’ the inland tribes.
krath/sousi e)/soito—the indic. and opt. in the same sentence in Or. Obl. M. T 670.
o(moi/ws—‘would not find it so easy to.’

e)lpi/da ... labei=n—
e)lpi/s e)sti regularly has aor. infin., like ei)ko/s e)sti c. 11, 8.

*nau/pakton—this appealed equally to the Spartans, Corinthians, and Ambraciots; as the position of the conquered Messenians was a chronic insult to Sparta, Phormio interfered with the western trade of Corinth, and the Ambraciots too had their grudge against him.
*)/eti—c. 66, 2. Cnemus' year of office had not yet quite expired. For e)/ti of a period nearly complete, cf. c. 59, 3.

e)pi\ nausi\n—the dat. only here and IV. 10, 3. The gen. is regular, as c. 57, 1. So Demosth. 45, 30 says ta\ e)pi\ trape/zhs o)/nta, 27, 11 mna=s e)pi\ th=| trape/zh?; Aristoph. Eq. 754 e)pi\ tauthsi\ kaqh=tai th=s pe/tras, ib. 783 e)pi\ tai=si pe/trais kaqh/menon. There is no difference of sense, but the dat. is rare except with names of places. (Rutherford, Babrius, p. 7, wrongly denies the existence of this dat. in comedy.)
nautikw=|—abstract for concrete.
*leuka/da—an ally of Sparta, c. 9, 2, and a convenient point from which to attack Acarnania.
e)n paraskeuh=|—c. 17, 5.
e)k *leuka/dos ... a)fiko/menon e)n *leuka/di—a convement inaccuracy, as in c. 70, 3. For e)k *l., au)to/qen would have been more accurate.
*laqo/ntes—i.e. he passed the mouth of the Gulf of Corinth on his way to Leucas without being detected.
ei)/kosi—c. 69.

*)arxikou=—the presidency was in the hands of a particular family. The Chaones, then a powerful tribe, subsequently lost their importance, and were little more than a name in the time of Augustus. Verg. G. I. 8; II. 67. They, with the Molossi and Thesproti were the chief Epirot tribes.
*molossou\s—became under Pyrrhus the rulers of Epirus.
*)atinta=nas—bordered on the Parauaei near the river Aous.
*)oroi/dw|—both with cunestrateu/onto and e)pitre/yantos.
*kru/fa—he was supposed to be an ally of Athens, c. 29, 6.
u(/steron—c. 5, 3.
*)eporeu/eto—he started from Ambracia.

*limnai/an —between Argos and Anactorium, now Kravassara, and the natural point of departure from the Gulf of Ambracia to the Gulf of Corinth. The first object of the expedition was to obtain control of this route.
*stra/ton—on the Achelous, now Sourovigli. In 168 B.C. Livy says it was urbs validissima: now it is a poor village.
*ou)/te ... te—the two results, like the two causes, are introduced by parallel clauses.
e)/pempon keleu/ontes—c. 6, 2.
*oi( *p. kai\ oi( c.—the former=those sent with Cnemus, the latter the Ambraciots and barbarians. See c. 9, 2.
lo/gois ... e)/rgw|—the antithesis gives a good idea of their confidence that they would succeed.
*me/son—art. omitted, as with decio\n ke/ras. pros- h=|san—i.e. h(=|san pro\s thn po/lin.
*dia\ fulakh=s e)/.—cf. c. 13, 2, but here e)/xein is intrans., as in VII. 8, 3.
a)ciou/menoi—‘considered,’
ou)/t' e)pe/sxon —sc. to\n nou=n, ‘had no intention.’ This description is slightly sarcastic.
to\ strato/pedon—i.e. the camp which they had arranged to form, 2 above.

katalabei=n—‘occupy,’ establish themselves in, as III. 31 tw=n po/lewn katalabei=n tina. (According to Behrendt's conjecture, the sense would be ‘did not pause in their effort to occupy Stratus before the Greeks’; to\ belonging to the infin., cf. VII. 33, 3 e)pe/sxon to\ eu)qe/ws e)pixeirei=n.)
au)toboei\—noted by Marcellinus as a)rxaio/teron tw=n kat' au)to\n xro/nwn. Cf. c. 77, 3 fake/lous.
*)/eti prosio/ntas—i.e. that they had not halted, like the Greeks. Cf. e)/ti proselqei=n below and c. 21, 1.
o(moi/ws —‘as they had intended.’
o(mo/se xwrh/santes—c. 62, 3.
*katasta/ntwn—i.e. tw=n *xao/nwn kai\ tw=n a)/llwn. M. T. 848.
*oi)hqh=nai—sc. tou\s *(/ellhnas. For the change of sub- ject, cf. c. 3, 4.
katalhyome/nous—sc. tou\s barba/rous.
*)ene/keinto—kata\ kra/tos e)/feugon. Schol. The word, generally used of the pursuing party, well expresses the eagerness with which the barbarians rushed upon the lines of the Greeks.
a)nela/mbanon—as they arrived in scattered bodies.
a)/neu o(/. kinhqh=nai—without arms they could not stir, and even cu\n o(/plois it was dangerous for small foraging parties.
tou=to poiei=n—i.e. sfendona=n. Cf. c. 11, 8.

div2.p: *)/anapon—a tributary of the Achelous.

*oi)niadw=n— an important town on a hill in marshy ground near the S. W. coast of Acarnania, W. of the mouth of the Achelous. See c. 102. It had a considerable trade. In 450 B.C. the Messenians of Naupactus had tried to get possession of it, but failed, though Pericles himself laid siege to it with a large fleet. In 428 Asopius, son of Phormio, with the Acarnanians, started from Naupactus on another attempt to get hold of the place, but failed. In 424 the Acarnanians made it join Athens. It was captured and strengthened by Philip of Macedon in 219 (Polyb. IV. 65); and restored to the Acarnanians by Rome in 168, from whom it had been taken by the Aetolians in 213 (Polyb. XXII. 15, Livy, XXXVIII. 11). It was connected with Apulia by trade.

kata\ fili/an—c. 9, 4; with cum. which
probably means that the Oeniadae had been with Cnemus from the first, having joined him at Ambracia, though they are not mentioned, c. 80, 5.
cumboh/qeian—sc. tw=n *)akarna/nwn.

div3.p: *)apo\ qala/sshs a)/nw—‘that the Acarnanians on the coast might not aid those in the interior.’ For the attraction of a)po\ qala/sshs, cf. c. 80, 1. a)/nw adds nothing to the sense, and is in fact synonymous with a)po\ q.
h)nagka/sqhsan— plur. after nautiko\n as often. [
th=s k.t.l.]—o( au)to\s always takes the dat.
ei)/kosi—c. 69, 1.
*paraple/ontas—‘as they were sailing out of the gulf along the coast,’ i.e. e)/cw belongs to the partic.
e)n th=| eu)ruxwri/a|—‘in the open sea,’ so as to have space for manœuvring.
*stratiwtikw/teron—i.e. e)pi\ stratei/an ma=llon. Cf. c. 87, 2. They intended to make descents on the coast of Acarnania, cf. c. 80, 1.
komizome/nwn—belongs in sense to a)ntiparaple/ontas far more than to e(w/rwn au)tou\s which only makes a periphrasis for a)ntipare/pleon. Cf. ei)=xon e)mpei/rous c. 4, 2.
*patrw=n—now the largest town in Peloponnese, but its importance only dates from the 1st century A.D. Its greatest distinction is that here the patriots in 1821 first rose against the Turks.
diaba/llontes— = diabai/nontes. This intrans. use elsew here only in Herod. and poets.

*xalki/dos—on the coast of Aetolia, now Varassova, at the mouth of the Euenus, now Phidhari. It had belonged to Corinth, but had been taken by the Athenians 456 B.C. It lay at the foot of the mountain of the same name.
*eu)h/nou—Ovid, Met. 9, 104 fol. relates how Hercules slew Nessus here.

a)formisa/menoi—‘though they had slipped from their moorings in the night’; in order to elude the Athenians, the fleet tried to cross over to Acarnania before daybreak. The battle took place soon after dawn, c. 84, 2. e)/laqon precedes katei=don in time, and is plup. in sense.
porqmo/n—i.e. in the middle of the Gulf of Patrae, in the open, as Phormio had planned; and therefore between Patrae and Chalcis.
*pareskeua/zonto—cf. c. 7, 1. The imperf., as Cl. says, is due to the distributive nature of the act described.
*dido/ntes—belongs to w(s me)giston, the circle was as large as possible without leaving an opening. mh\ shows that the partic. implies preference or prohibition: ‘so as not to afford.’

die/kploun—this famous manœuvre consisted of ‘rowing through the intervals of the adversary's line, and thus getting in their rear, ... and before the ship of the adversary could change its position, of striking it either in the
stern, or in some weak part.’ Grote. to\ e)mba/llein kai\ diasxi/zein th\n tw=n e)nanti/wn ta/cin. Schol.
ta\s prw/|ras—sc. e)ta/canto. This chiasmus is pronounced by F. Stein to be ‘librarii additamentum prorsus supervacaneum.’ Anyhow it is detestable. (prw/|ra su\n tw=| i_, Herodian.)
dia\ braxe/os— with paragigno/menoi, masc. in spite of nau=s; ‘might be at hand to sail out.’
ei)/ ph|—they were uncertain at what point of the circle the Athenians would attack.
*kata\ mi/an—‘in a single line,’ one ship behind the other.
e)n xrw=|—i.e. as near as possible. Cf. ad vivum resecare.
do/khsin—c. 35, 2.
e)mbalei=n—fut. Cl. quotes IV. 55 do/khsi/s ti pra/cein. proei/rhto ... u(po\—the construction is due to au)toi=s.
*ei)w/qei—sc. au)to\ from o(/per, cf. c. 4, 5.
o(po/tan— cf. c. 11, 6.
to/te—i.e. when the wind threw them into confusion.
gi/gnesqai—might be e)/sesqai—‘quod enim fit non est, sed erit.’ Sta. Cf. IV. 24 h)/lpizon .. xeirw/sesqai, kai\ h)/dh sfw=n i)sxura\ ta\ pra/gmata gi/gnesqai.
*kath/|ei—c. 25, 4.
u(p' a)mfote/rwn—with proskei- me/nwn.

boh=| te—the te adds the third fact. For the disturbance, cf. Eur. Hec. 607 nautikh/ t' a)narxi/a | krei/sswn puro/s. a)nafe/rein—owing to the stiff breeze and heavy sea they could not clear the water.
a)lkh\n—‘resistance,’ robur. So Herod., common in poets and found frequently in Xen. as Ages. 10, 1; but not found in any other Attic prose.
*du/mhn—W. of Achaea; the exact site doubtful.
*molu/kreion—a small town near Antirrhium.

*po- seidw=ni—cf. Aristoph. Eq. 561 w)= *gerai/stie (Poseidon, from Geraestus, the site of a temple) pai= *kro/nou, *formi/wni/ te fi/ltat' e)k tw=n a)/llwn te qew=n *)aqhnai/ois, referring to Poseidon's victories, and to the success at Pylus.
*(ri/w|—cf. c. 86, 2; called also to\ *)anti/rrion, now Kastro Roumelias, 11/4 mile from the Rhium on the opposite coast. See L. and S. s.v. r(i/on.
*kullh/nhn—opposite Zacynthus, and a port of im- portance, of which there are no remains.
*leuka/dos— Cnemus was left at Oeniadae. Thence he had crossed to Leucas.
*tw=| *k.—belongs to cumbou/lous. The despatch of c. to aid the commander was not an uncommon occurrence, and shows with what jealousy the ephors controlled the officials.
belti/w—observe the truculence of this laconic message.
*prw=twn—i.e. in the Peloponnesian war.
peira- same/nois—see c. 5, 5.
di' o)li/gou—not post, but per breve, as in dia\ panto\s tou= xro/nou. a)pe/stellon—like e)/pempon, c. 6, 1.
*nau=s perih/ggellon—cf. c. 10, 1, and we expect nau=s paraskeua/zesqai or pe/myai. w(s e)pi\—cf. c. 83, 3.
*)aggelou=ntas ... kai\ keleu/wn—cf. c. 6, 2. It is clear from the answer to this urgent message that the government did not realise the situation.
*tw=| komi/zonti—it is strange that the commander is not named, and possible that he is a substitute appointed in place of Pericles, who was then dangerously ill.
*)aploi/as—i.e. rough weather. Had they been merely becalmed, they would have rowed. Only found in Herod. of prose writers.
e)ndie/triyen—c. 18, 2.
*pa/normon—just inside the straits, close to Rhium.
*pare/pleuse de\—cf. c. 7, 1 for the anaphora.
e)cw—Antirrhium and Rhium (Kastro Moreas) formed the entrance to the Gulf of Corinth. Phormio anchored W. of Antirrhium.
*(epta\—probably rather under the distance in those days. Thuc. judged by his eye. Strabo is still less exact; he calls the distance five stadia.
*(o pezo\s—for o( p. strato/s. The ellipse of a masc. non-personal noun is rare: this one is found only in Herod. and Thuc.
e)peidh\ kai\—cf. et ipse common in Livy.
ei)=don —sc. o(rmisame/nous. Cf. c. 11, 8.
meletw=ntes—absolute, only para- skeuazo/menoi governing naumaxi/an. gnw/mhn e)/xontes—with infin. like gno/ntes. For the double partic. see c. 15, 2.
oi( me\n—the subject subdivided; cf. c. 5, 3.
pro\s e)kei/nwn—‘to their interest’; cf. c. 83, 2.
*)/epeita—answers e)pi\ me\n in 5.
poih=sai—‘to bring on,’ the act. of the generals; contrast c. 83, 3, mid. of the men.
a)po\ tw=n *)a.—more formal than a)p' *)aqhnai/wn. e)/lecan—Intr. p. lviii.

*)/exei— = pare/xei: ‘does not support a conclusion which can justly cause you alarm.’ [to\] e)kfobh=sai— omitting to\ take e)kfobh=sai with dikai/an, as in IV. 17 di/kaioi/ ei)si kai\ a)pisto/tatoi ei)=nai. The conclusion they drew from the preceding battle was that they would be defeated in the coming battle: and this conclusion caused them fobei=sqai th\n me/llousan. But the battle, they are told, does not afford the tekmh/ria for such a conclusion. (to\ e)kfobh=sai cannot be accus. of respect, as in c. 53 to\ protalaipwrei=n, because such an accus. would here certainly contain a reference to the expected issue of the coming fight. The usual translation ‘ground for fear’ gives a wrong sense to every one of the three words.
If pefobh=sqai were read, the construction would be dikai/an pefobh=sqai, = ‘which it is right to fear,’ h( te/kmarsis dikai/a e)sti —pefobh=sqai being equivalent to di)kaio/n e)sti th\n te/kmarsin pefobh=sqai, infin. of purpose.)
*)epi\ stratei/an—c. 83, 3.
ta\ a)po\ th=s t—the wind and sea, c. 84, 3.
kai\ pou/ ti kai\—the expression barely does more than suggest the possibility of what was certain. The object is to blame tu/xh and excuse gnw/mh.
*kata\—‘owing to.’

prosege/neto—much like e)pi- gi/gnesqai, c. 4, 2, but the defeat is regarded as an unavoidable occurrence added to their other disad vantages (ta\ a)po\ th=s tu/xhs). Cf. Vergil's ‘nec Teucris addita Juno | usquam aberit, Aen. VI. 90.

th=s gnw/mhs to\ mh\ kata\ kra/tos nikhqe/n—=h( gnw/mh mh\ nikhqei=sa. Cf. c. 59 to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s gnw/mhs. Militibus fortuna victis invictus ipsorum animus opponitur. Hache. ‘It is not right that our minds, which we feel (mh/, not ou)) were not conquered by force but have still some answer to give, should be depressed by the result of mere accident.’

kata\ kra/tos— vi, as in kata\ k. ai(rei=n. a)ntilogi/an—sc. pro\s to\ kata\ kra/tos nikhqh=nai, viz. the answer that the disaster was due to a)peiri/a, tu/xh, want of paraskeuh/. A familiar word in Plato.
cumfora=s—opposed to gnw/mhs above.
nomi/sai—sc. di/kaion. a)ndrei/ous o)rqw=s—‘really brave,’ o)rqw=s as in Aristoph. Eq. 1085.
a)peiri/an ... proballome/nous—‘make in experience an excuse.’
tou= a)ndrei/ou p.—‘while courage remains.’
e)/n tini—neut.
*(umw=n de\—topic to\ dunato/n. Index, s.v. to/poi. lei/petai—sc. th=s e)kei/nwn e)mpeiri/as. mnh/mhn—‘presence of mind.’
a)/neu eu)yuxi/as—the insinuation that the Athenians lacked courage is wholly unsupported by argument.
a)/neu a)lkh=s—‘without boldness,’ as in c. 84, 3 robur; it is the result of eu)yuxi/a.
*)apara/skeuoi tuxei=n—for the omission of o)/ntes, cf. c. 39, 4.
*plh=qos—c. 11, 3.
ta\ de\ polla\—adverbial accus. For the gnw/mh, cf. c. 13, 2.
*prosgeno/mena—here of additional advantages; con- trast 3 above.
didaskali/an—cf. Aesch. Ag. 185 *zh=na to\n pa/qh ma/qos | qe/nta kuri/ws e)/xein. Arn.
*to\ kaq' e(auto\n—cf. c. 11, 3.
tis prostaxqh=|—the change from the plur. to the indef. sing. is due to the intervention of e(/kastos. On the juxtaposition of 2nd and 3rd pers., e(auto\n . . e(/pesqe etc. see c. 11, 1, 44, 1.
*pro/teron—Cnemus, Machaon, Isocrates and Aga- tharchidas.
ou) xei=ron—meiosis, not to offend the others.
e)ndw/somen—as in c. 49, 4.
h)\n de/ tis—this vague threat shows that the officers suspected there had been cowardice in the former battle. Cf. c. 85, 2.
*)orrwdi/an—the noun is used by no other prose writer but Herod.
ai)sqome/nous o(/ti—a substantive clause after ai)sqa/nomai is not very common, cf. I. 50, VII. 49, 1. o(/ti and opt. is found, e.g. in IV. 122; V. 2; VIII. 100, but the partic. is far commoner.
cunista/menoi—cf. c. 21, 3.

parai/nesin poih/sasqai—=parakeleu/sasqai, the harangues of generals being called paraine/seis or parakeleu/seis or lo/goi protreptikoi/ (cf. p. 48); of the three ei)/dh or ge/nh of speeches, viz. lo/goi dikanikoi/ (forensic), l. e)pideiktikoi/ (of which e)pita/fioi are a branch), and l. sumbouleutikoi/, paraine/seis belong to the last.

*kai\ propareskeu/aze—does not influence the construction, w(s really depending on e)/lege. Cf. c. 2, 4. So Livy, XXI. 18 nostra haec quaestio (atque animadversio) in civem nostrum est, nostro an suo fecerit arbitrio.
o)/xlon ... u(poxwrei=n—a poetic construction. Cf. Eur. Hec. 812 poi= m' u(peca/geis po/da;
tou= qarsei=n—cf. IV. 17, 3 u(po/mnhsin tou= kalw=s bouleu/sasqai h(ghsa/menoi: ‘council them to take heart.’
ou)k a)ciw=n—for the double partic. o(rw=n ... a)ciw=n, cf. c. 59, 3.
e)n o)rrwdi/a| e)/xein—c. 59, 2.

*ou)k a)po\ tou= i)/sou—the neg. of to\ plh=qos, as in c. 13, 1 parali/ph| kai\ mh\ dhw/sh|. w(=|—i.e. tou=to w(=|, the tou=to belonging to qarsou=sin, lit. ‘as to that in which they feel confidence,’ viz. w(s prosh=|kon sfi/sin a). ei)=nai, the courage which they have shown so often. For the construction, cf. Livy, XXI. 10 id de quo ambigebatur, eventus belli, unde jus stabat, ei victoriam dedit.
katorqou=ntes—antithesis to ou/ di' a)/llo ti. Cf. c. 65, 8. dia\ ... e)mpeiri/an depends on katorqou=ntes. ta\ plei/w— because they had so seldom fought at sea.

kai\ oi)/ontai— ‘and so they think.’ For the change from partic. to indic., cf. V. 61, 4 boulo/menoi a)/llws te ... kai\ o(/mhroi h)=san. So Eur. Bacchae, 225 pro/fasin me
 w(s dh\ maina/das quosko/ous (sc. ou)/sas), th
 d' *)afrodi/thn pro/sq' a)/gein tou= *bakxi/ou. poih/sein—subject th
 e)mpeiri/an.
*to\ d'—i.e. to\ katorqou=n. e)k tou= dikai/ou—cf. c. 44, 3, = dikai/ws. perie/stai—‘will be found on our side.’
e)n e)kei/nw|—i.e. e)n tw=| pezw=|. eu)yuxi/a|—answers the statement made in c. 87, 5.
profe/rousi— = proe/xein, only used by Herod., Thuc. and poets.
tw=| de\—‘owing to our superiority in experience, we are more confident.’
*te—adds the third fact to prw=ton me\n. e)/peita above, and so gives another reason for the conclusion mh\ dei/shte dia\ th\n—‘for the sake of,’ with h(gou/menoi. The statement is general.
ou)k a)\n—the prot., ‘if they had had their own way’ is implied in a)/kontas. e)pexei/rhsan—emphatic.
para\ polu\—‘decisively’; cf. c. 8, 4

*kata\ ... kai\ o(/ti—cf. c. 65, 7 for kata/. tou= para- lo/gou—cf. tw=| ou)k ei)ko/ti below; explained in oi( d' e)k pollou= ... a)ntitolmw=sin: ‘worthy of our astonishing action,’ in offering battle with such inferior numbers. (tou= para\ polu\ is explained to mean tou= para\ polu\ pronenikhke/nai, but (1) this is not clear, (2) the previous victory has just been referred to and the probability of another sufficiently implied in kata\ to\ pronenikhke/nai: a new reason is now wanted, (3) the next section, introduced by ga\r, is meaningless.)
*)anti/paloi—‘most men, when they are a match for the enemy.’
pi/sunoi—found also V. 14, 3; VI. 2, 6; otherwise only in Herod. and poets. Cf. Ruth. New Phryn. p. 21. The ordinary word is pisteu/wn, as in 2 above.
e)k pollw=| u(podeeste/rwn—sc. e)pio/ntes: cf. a)p' e)lasso/nwn o(rmw/menos c 65, 2, ‘whose means are far inferior.’
th=s dianoi/as to\ b.—‘strength of will.’
tw=| ou)k ei)ko/ti—‘because of what they never expected than on account of our expected preparations.’ (Ste. gives up this passage, and other edd. put a sense upon it which the words will not bear.)
kata\ lo/gon—the Peloponnesians were expecting the immediate arrival of reinforcements from Athens; cf. c. 86, 6.
*(hmei=s—he hints that the enemy are both a)/peiroi and a)/tolmoi.
*to\n a)gw=na—topic to\ cumfe/ron; cf. c. 11, 3.
ei)=nai —infin. of limitation, in this phrase almost confined to neg. sentences.
e)mbolh\n—charge broadside, with the e)/mbolon) (prosbolh/, charge prow to prow.
e)k pollou=—e longinquo.
a)nastrofai/—turning back after any manœuvre to regain the original position of the ship.
e)n tou/tw|—‘in these circumstances’; cf. e)n w(=| c. 1.

*tou/twn—in the analysis the peroration is made to begin here. There was in antiquity some doubt about the place where the pi/stis ends. The schol. on 10 o( de\ a)gw\n remarks tine\s a)po\ tou= de\ tou\s e)pilo/gous, and the same writer puts oi( e)pi/logoi to 11. Cf. the opening of the peroration in c. 11, 9, 87, 8.

para\ tai=s nausi\—Intr. p. xliii. para\ is rarely used thus with things, cf. c. 43, 2; but the frequent personification of po/lis, nau=s, etc. renders the phrase possible. The Athenians, up to the beginning of the action, were on shore, c. 90, 3.
di' o)li/gou—local; cf. c. 29, 3.
kai\ sigh\n—cf. c. 11, 9.

e)/s te ta\ polla\ ... naumaxi/a|—for e)s, with cumfe/rei, cf. IV. 26, 5. The only other passage in which an impersonal noun is in dat. with cumfe/rei is VI. 83 lo/gou me\n h(donh=? to\ paranti/ka terpome/nous, th=? d' e)gxeirh/sei u(/steron ta\ cumfe/ronta pra/ssontas.
*)agw\n ... katalu=sai—generally peri/, u(pe/r, or e(/neka, as c. 63, 1, but here the infin. are epexegetic.
e)lpi/da tou= nautikou=—cf. peni/as e)lpi/di, c. 42, 4.
*au)=—‘again.’
e)qe/lousin— = ei)w/qasi, filou=si, as in Herod. and Xen.
*)epi\ tessa/rwn—‘four deep,’ in four lines.

e)pi\ th\n e(autw=n gh=n—with taca/menoi, ‘drawing up their ships with the coast of Peloponnesus at their backs’; the four lines extended back towards the coast. (This is obscure enough, but it is the only possible sense. e)pi\ cannot mean para\ ‘along.’)
e)/sw [e)pi\]—these are not possible together; but? w(s e)pi\ tou= k. The Peloponnesians were moving N.E. from Rhium, and therefore in the direction of Naupactus.
deciw=| ke/ra|—when they began to move up the gulf, the four lines of ships turned to the right, so that there were now four abreast, the right wing leading.

*ei)/kosi—the Peloponnesians had 77 ships (c. 86, 4); as the right wing consists of 20 ships 4 abreast, the rest of the lines were probably so arranged that every fifth line consisted of only 3 ships abreast instead of 4, which would give 3 groups each consisting of 19 ships.
tau/th|—‘in this direction,’ towards Naupactus.
diafu/goien—into the open part of the gulf, eastwards.
ple/onta to\n e)pi/ploun—‘the attacking line when it bore down on them.’ Cf. 4 below e)pistre/yantes ta\s nau=s metwphdo\n e)/pleon.

*)erh/mw|—i.e. deprived of its protection, Phormio being at Antirrhium. For the sense, not implying that there were no people in Naupactus, cf. c. 25, 1 a)nqrw/pwn ou)k e)no/ntwn. kata\ spoudh\n—cf. c. 94, 2.
e)mbiba/sas—imponere; the object omitted as constantly in naval and military phrases. For the double partic. see c. 4, 4.
*messhni/wn—from Naupactus.
*)epi\ ke/rws—‘in single file.’
a)po\ s.—cf. c. 92, 1. metwphdo\n—ta\ me/twpa, o(/ e)sti ta\ pro/swpa tw=n new=n, parei=xon toi=s e)nanti/ois. Schol. i.e. they turned to the left, into four lines, as they had been at first.
ta/xous—depends on w(s ei)=xen e(/kastos. Xen. Hel. 4, 5, 15.
*tw=n de\—i.e. tou/twn de\ = pasw=n tw=n new=n. to\ ke/ras —i.e. the right wing, ta\s ei)/kosi nau=s of 2 above.

th
 e)pistrofh
—cf. to
 e)pi/ploun in 2 above; ‘the sudden turn.’
e)ce/wsan—technical, ‘to force an enemy to run his ship aground.’
o(/soi mh\— = ei) mh/ tines.
*)anadou/menoi—the imperf. partic. in this phrase expresses the lashing of each of the vessels. The aor. is used in VII. 74. ei(=lon h)/dh—‘had already taken.’
cu\n toi=s o(/plois—c. 2, 1.
*)ekra/toun ... die/fqeiran—‘were successful and had disabled.’
fqa/nousin ... prokatafugou=sai—aor. partic. here coincident in time with the historic pres. Cf. c. 2, 3 e)/laqon e)selqo/ntes. au)tou\s— = tou\s e)n tai=s nausi/. i)/sxousai— ‘riding at anchor.’
kata\—shows the point of the coast. i)/sxw also takes e)s or dat. pareskeua/zonto a)munou/menoi—w(s omitted, as in c. 18, 1. al.
*(/usteron—)(fqa/nousin. Cf. c. 5, 3, 80. e)paia/- nizon—it was in honour of Apollo, a curious coincidence.
a)/ma ple/ontes—together.
*mete/wros—in the middle of the gulf.

peri\ h(\n ... fqa/sasa . . diwkou/sh|—‘several MSS. omit kai\ peripleu/sasa. But fqa/nein peri/ ti does not appear sanctioned by usage.’ Linwood. Probably Thuc. meant peri\ h(\n to be governed by diwkou/sh|, and the ship was struck broadside when in the act of pursuing the enemy round the anchored vessel.

*diw/kontes .. ai( me/n—cf. 1 above. In diw/kontes ... kaqei=sai ... e)pe/sthsan ... drw=ntes ... boulo/menoi, the first partic. is causal to kaqei=sai, which is temporal to e)pe/sthsan: drw=ntes defines e)pe/sthsan as in c. 90, 1 a)nago/menoi e)pleon: boulo/menoi is causal to e)pe/sthsan. e)pe/sthsan tou= plou=—lit. stopped in their course. Cf. IV. 47 e)peta/xunon th=s o)dou=. pro\s th\n e)c o). a)nteco/rmhsin—refers to the 11 ships mentioned in 1 above, which i)/sxousai a)nti/prw|roi pareskeua/zonto, ‘as the enemy were near and could charge them.’ Both e)c o)li/gou and di' o)li/gou mean ‘suddenly’ or ‘at a short distance.’ Cf. c. 11, 4, 85, 2, 89, 9.
bra/xea—brevia, Verg. Aen. I. 111; found only in Herod. except here.
o)li/gon me\n .. e)/peita—para- taxis.
*pa/normon—see c. 86, 4.
a)nhga/gonto— equivalent to a plup., as often in rel. clauses. M. T. 58.
*(\ec—sc. ou)/sas. a)/ndras te—te adds the third fact connected with the pursuit.

diafqei/rantes to\ prw=ton—c. 90, 5. The whole Peloponnesian fleet, not only the 20 ships on the right wing, fled to Panormus, as the main body of 57 ships had gone to aid the others, and so abandoned their prizes.
*peri\—‘near.’
e)ce/pesen—‘his body was washed up.’

*(/oqen— = e)ntau=qa o(/qen. Cf. Demosth. 45, 81 a)na/gein o(/qen ei)/lhfas, Andoc. 1, 64 qerapai/nas e)/labon o(/qen o(rmw/menoi tau=t' e)poi/oun. a)nagago/menoi—viz. kata\ to\ *)apollw/nion c. 91, 1.
e)/sthsan e)/sthsan de\ kai\—cf. c. 7, 1, 86, 1 and 2.
u(po/sponda—thus the Peloponnesians acknowledged themselves defeated.
*tropai=on th=s troph=s—the same gen. VI. 98, 4; VII. 54. h(/nper—c. 90, 6.
a)ne/qesan e)pi\—the same use of e)pi\ as in c. 52, 4 e)pitiqe/nai nekrou\s e)pi\ pura/s, 76, 2 i)za/nein e)pi/. *(ri/on—in honour of Poseidon, c. 84, 4.
*)aqhnai/wn—see on c. 86, 6.
kai\ *ko/rinqon—i e. Lechaeum, the port of Corinth.
*ai(=s—‘with which.’ Cf. c. 85.

*)afu/laktos—yet in c. 24 Thuc. said fulaka\s kate- sth/santo kata\ qa/lassan; from which Pp concludes that the vessels there mentioned were not armed. Thuc. however seems to imply that the guard-ships had been withdrawn, or at least were not always on the spot. Probably Pericles would have disapproved of this.
a)/klh|stos—see c. 94, 4. Probably Brasidas planned this attack.
ei)ko/tws—cf. c. 8, 1.
e)pikratei=n—sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. polu\—e)pikratei=n takes the place of the usual comparative.
*tropwth=ra—from tropo/s, leather, and so a thong which attached the oar to the skalmo/s, thole-pin. The ancients did not use rowlocks like ours.
a)fikome/nous ... kaqelku/santas—see c. 15, 2.
*)=hn ... profula/sson—cf. c. 67, 1.

prosdoki/a ... mh\ a)/n—after the analogy of fo/bos, cf. c. 13, 1. If the time were pres., the sentence would be prosdoki/a e)sti mh\ a)\n e)pipleu/seian. There are very few cases of this construction, and no others in Thuc.
e)capinai/ws—see c. 3, 1.

a)po\ tou= profanou=s—a regular formula: cf. a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os III. 43, 5; but a)po\ in such phrases is less common than e)k. a)po\ tou= i)/sou however is often found in Thuc. This use of a)po\ is not found iu the orators.

tolmh=sai a)/n—depends on the idea of thinking implied in prosdoki/a h)=n. Sc. e)pipleu=sai. kaq' h(suxi/an —sc. e)pipleu=sai, ‘to make an attack without meeting with opposition.’ Intr. p. xliv. Cf. Arist. Eccles. 288 kata\ sko/ton = clam.
mh\ ou)k—cf. I. 141 to\ ou) be)baion e)/xontes mh\ ou) proanalw/sein. M. T. 817.
*kai\ e)xw/roun—kai\ marks the carrying out of the plan they had formed. In this idiom the rel. sense of w(s, ‘as,’ is hardly distinguished from the temporal. Cf. c. 2, 4.
ou)ke/ti—again there is irony in the narrative. Cf. c. 80, 1.
*salami=nos—first for emphasis. Cf. c. 7, 2, 11, 2.

o(rw=n—
cf. c. 55, 1.

new=n t. fulakh/—cf. c. 69, 1. e)p' au)tou= has a slightly different meaning with fulakh/, as though it were peri\ au)to/. With frou/rion e)pi\ tou= a)krwthri/ou contrast tropai=on e)pi\ th=| a)/kra| VIII. 106. See c. 80, 2.
*fruktoi\ pole/mioi—lampa/des polemi/ous dhlou=sai. Schol.

to
 po/lemon—see c. 1. a)
 ... a)
—caused by the breaking of the sentence.
*kaqei=lkon—imperf. throughout, describing the action going on.
tw=| pezw=| de\—notice the variation in the order.
*(ws h)/|sqonto—c. 3, 1.
e)/sti ga\r o(/ ti kai\—cf. kai/ tis kai\ c. 93, 3, kai/ ti kai\ c. 87, 2. e)/stin o(/ ti is part of the object of e)fo/boun, as fobw= se tou=to = I make you fear this.
*ou)ke/ti katalabo/ntes—cf. c. 56, 6.

kai\ ... a(/ma— this adds a new fact of importance, like kai\ dh\ kai/. klh/|sei —‘the walls, being carried down to either side of the harbour's mouth, were prolonged from thence across the mouth upon shoals, or artificial moles, until a passage only was left in the middle for two or three triremes abreast between two towers, the opening of which might be further protected by a chain.’ Col. Leake, Top. of Athens, p. 311. klh|stoi\ lime/nes were common. ‘It was not until Athens was in danger of being surprised by the enemy's fleet that the Athenians saw the necessity of fortifying the Peiraeus in the manner customary among the Greeks.’ ib. l.c.
*)aleca/ndrou—had sided with the Greeks in the Persian war.

e)pi\ *xalkide/as—cf. c. 79. Athens suffered more annoyance from the north than from any other quarter outside the Peloponnese. Probably the generals who granted terms to Potidaea (c. 70) were brought to trial at the instigation of Cleon. Now at last the government hoped to pacify the Chalcidian towns, which had revolted with Potidaea, by means of Sitalces.

du/o u(posxe/seis th
 me
 ... th
 de\—the object subdivided. Somewhat similar is c. 44, 1.
*(/o te ... toi=s te *)a—the double te as in c. 22, 1 and 84 marking parallelism.
u(posxo/menos—‘made promises.’ What these were is unknown. Intr. p. lxxix.

tw=| pole/mw| —Cl. proposes tou= pole/mou, but probably Thuc. means kat' a)rxa\s tou= pole/mou piezo/menon au)tw=|; for in 432 B.C. Athens had made alliance with Philip and was at war with him till August 431 B.C., c. 29, 6.
*fi/lippon—formerly king of upper Macedonia, c. 100, 3; expelled by Perdiccas. He had recently died.
e)pi\ basilei/a|—purpose, as e)p' w)feli/a| c. 29, 3.
katalu/sein—c. 29, 5.
*(hgemo/na—i.e. as his chief adviser.

*(/agnwna—
c. 58.
e)/dei ... paragene/sqai—cf. c. 5, 1, ‘were to aid him,’ according to an arrangement.
*)ani/sthsin—c. 68, 1.
e)nto\s—citra.
*ai(/mou— the Balkan.
*(rodo/phs—Despoto.
u(perba/nti—cf. c. 49, 5; here = ultra. The Getae lived then between Mt. Haemus and the Danube, in Bulgaria.

me/rh = e)/qnh. katw/|khto— this use of the mid. of persous is found ouly in Herod. and Thuc., and is confined to perf. forms. Dion. Hal. fiuds fault with Thuc. for using the mid. where Attic writers use the active.
*)oreinw=n—)(o(/soi pedi/a ei)=xon c. 101, 3.
au)tono/mwn —)(o(/swn h)=rxe 1 above.
a)/lla o(/sa—cf. 3 below.
maxairofo/rwn—a well-known mark of some of the Thracian tribes.
*)agria=nas—at the source of the Strymon (Struma) and round Mt. Rhodope
*sko/mbrou—another mountain iu the Balkan chain, south of Sophia. The Laeaei were north of the Agrianes.
ta\ pro\s *pai/onas—‘on the side of the P., who from that point were indepeudent.’
*triballou\s—in Servia.
*)oski/ou—a tributary of the Danube (the Isker).
e)k tou= o)/rous—part of Rhodope.
*ne/stos—the Kara-su. The Romans in B.C. 167 made it the northern boundary of Macedonia.
*(/ebros—the Maritza.
*)ege/neto—Thuc. probably knew more of Thrace than any other Greek owing to his property, infleuce, and sojourn there.
me/geqos—accus. of respect.

e)pi\ me\n q. kaqh/kousa— ‘extended along the coast line,’ cf. c. 27, 2) (e)s h)/peiron. The construction is e)ge/neto kaqh/kousa, like h)=n kaqh/kousa, cf. c. 80, 2, 93, 2; lit. extended down to the sea.

me/xri *)/istrou potamou=—cf. Isocr. VII. 80 e)nto\s *(/aluos potamou=, the only case in Attic outside Thuc. where the art. is omitted with the name when potamo\s is inserted. The omission is common in Herod.: there are six cases in Thuc.
peri/plous—with tessa/rwn h(merw=n. Cf. VI. 1 *sikeli/as (-a Kr., Hw.) peri/plous e)stin .. o)ktw\ h(merw=n. ta\ cuntomw/tata—adverbial.
i(sth=tai —stet, of anything which does not shift its position.
nhi\ s.— = o(lka/di.
*dia\ plei/stou .. e)gi/gneto—‘for in this direction it extended furthest into the interior.’
a(nu/sai—epexegetic to h)=n h( a)rxh/.
*)=hrcan—ingressive, as a)rxqw=si c. 8, 4.
*seu/qou— nephew of Sitalces.
basileu/sas—ingressive, as c. 15, 2. Coutrast c. 80, 6.
du/namis—sc. h)=n, ‘amounted in all to about.’
dw=ra—not voluntary, but like Edward IV.'s benevoleuces.

o(/sa—see c. 13, 4. Cf. I. 16. lei=a—‘plain,’ unembroidered. kataskeuh/—u(fanta/ etc. are reckoned
among these ‘effects.’
au)tw=|—emphatic.
paradunasteu/ousi—‘princes.’
*persw=n—probably refers to the practice of giving bounties as rewards for public services.
lamba/nein—hinting that these presents were really exactions.
kata\ to\ du/nasqai —‘owing to their power’ (to exact money).
e)pi\ ple/on — = ma=llon. au)tw=|—i.e. tw=| no/mw|. e)xrh/santo—sc. oi( *)odrusai/.
*)epi\ me/ga i)sxu/os—cf. c. 17, 4.
tw=n ga\r—sc. basileiw=n. o(/sai—cf. 3 above.

eu)daimoni/a|—of wealth, as beatus. Cf. Eur. Bacchae, 16 *)arabi/an eu)dai/mona. polu\ deute/ra meta\—‘far inferior to.’ (Arn. trauslates ‘easily second,’ quoting Soph. O. C. 1228 mh\ fu=nai to\n a)/panta nika=| lo/gon: to\ de\ ... bh=nai kei=qen o(/qenper h(/kei polu\ deu/teron w(s ta/xista, but there too the deu/teros plou=s is ‘far inferior’ to the prw=tos plou=s.)

*(/en pro\s e(
—cf. Herod. IV. 50 e(
 pro\s e(
 sumba/llein. ou)k e)/stin o(/ ti— = ou)de/n, otherwise ou)k would not be inserted here after ou)de/. ou) mh
 ou)de\—‘not that they are on a level with other nations in general prudence and intelligence in the employment of the ordinary resources of life.’
cu/nesin— meaning that the Scythians, with their natural advantages (ta\ paro/nta e)s to\n bi/on), might have been a great nation if they had been blessed with the sense to pursue a definite policy.
*(etoi=ma—c. 3, 4.
*kerki/nhs—between the Axius (the Vardar) and Strymon.
*sintw=n—on the right bank of the Strymon.
temw\n—by felling the mountain-trees.
*maidou/s—also on the right bank of the Strymon.

*do/bhron—‘in one of the first high valleys on the Paeonian (western) side (of Cercine), from which the way to lower Macedonia would be a continued descent, first down the valley of one of the tributary streams of the Axius, and then by the valley of the Axius itself.’ Arn.

*)apegi/gneto ... prosegi/gneto—a paratactic parono- masi/a. After he had left his own kingdom, it might have been expected that his forces would dwindle down, owing to their miscellaneous character, and the slightness of the ties by which they were connected.
to\ pa=n—c. 7, 2.
gene/sqai —c. 13, 3.
*kataba/ntes—attributive, as in c. 30, 1. This order is only possible when the noun, here au)to/nomoi, has other attributes beside the partic.
cu/mmeiktos—with h)kolou/qei; they were not separated into contingents, but were what histories call ‘a horde.’
plh/qei f.—‘chiefly formidable on account of their numbers.’
*)en—would be e)s had not the muster at Doberus already been referred to.
kata\ korufh\n— = a)/nwqen, kata\ via like kata\ kra/tos, expressing the manner; cf. c. 76, 4. th\n ka/tw *m.—to\ para/lion. Schol.
*tw=n ga\r—‘for, besides the lower Macedonians, there are also Macedonians in the upper country, amongst whom are iucluded the L. and E.’ Note in Jowett.
*ligkhstai\— the district called Lyncestis.
*)elimiw=tai—divided from Thessaly by the Cambunian mountains.
basilei/as—‘have kings of their own.’ J.
*th\n de\ peri\—not para/, because the regions en umerated below are not merely those actually on the coast, but comprise h( ka/tw gh= generally.
*thmeni/dai—hence Philip and Alexander claimed to be Greeks, and their claim was generally admitted.
e)basi/leusan—ingressive.
*pieri/as—between Mt. Olympus and the Thermaic Gulf, the origiual home of the muses and birth-place of Orpheus.
u(po\ to\ *pa/ggaion—after this both the Pieres and Orpheus were connected with Thrace.
ko/lpos —see L. and S.
oi)kou=sin—their new home was Bottice. They originally dwelt near Pella.

*stenh/n—the Paeonians had possessed ‘a narrow strip on the bank of the Axius, down to Pella and the sea.’ Grote points out that this would leave hardly any room for the Bottiaeans, who dwelt north of the Pierians, between the mouth of the Haliacmon (the Indjeh Kara-su) and that of the Axius. Probably Thuc. is mistaken in saying me/xri qala/sshs, and the Paeonians did not extend so far east.

*mugdoni/an— Herod. VII. 123 says the Axius divided Bottia on the south from Mygdonia on the north. Iu this region lived also the Edonians, Crestonians, and Bisaltae (6 below), but the Mygdonians must have been the most important.
*)eordi/as—east of Lyncestis. N.W. of the Elimiots.
*fu/skan—somewhere between the Strymon and Axius.
katw/|khtai—c. 96, 1.
*)almwpi/as—some where near Eordia and Pieria.

*ou(=toi—=oi( ka/tw; the tribes who were led by the Temenidae and conquered all lower Macedonia, the part which has been described from 3 above. Contrast *makedo/nes au)toi\ below, = the original Macedonians before the conquests, oi( a)/nw, who remained partially independent, c. 99, 2.
au)tw=n— those just mentioned were not of Macedonian stock.
*oi( *m. ou(=toi—oi( u(po\ *perdi/kkou basileuo/menoi. kar- tera\—secure places in the hills.

*)arxe/laos—reigned 413-399 B.C. Eur. wrote a play named after him, and the ‘Bacchae’ was written at his
court. It is strange that Thuc. should go out of his way to make this remark about his reign: he must have considered these improvements very important.
o(dou\s eu)qei/as—cf. c. 98, 1. Andoc. 2, 11 says that Archelaus gave him the right to cut down and export as much timber as he chose.
ta)=lla accus. of respect, ta\ k. to\n po/lemon being object of dieko/smhse. o)ktw\—cf. the position of e(/c in c. 92, 2.
*th\n *fili/ppou—the upper part of the Axius.
o(mologi/a|—with prosxwrou=nta) (kata\ kra/tos.
*)aristera=|—i.e. ‘east of Pella, as Sitalces was marching southwards.’ Arn.
e)/sw—i.e. further south.
*(/oph| dokoi/h—with e)se/ballon, which is used here of a cavalry charge. They charged wherever they chose, as the Thracians were not disciplined. Cf. c. 79, 6.

*(upo\ de\ p. periklh|o/menoi— = o(po/te u(po\ p. peri- klh/|ointo, corresponding to h(=? me\n prospe/soien: hence pres. partic. ‘Whenever (after charging) they were hemmed in by superior numbers, they placed themselves in danger, as they were far outnumbered by the enemy.’
plh=qos—as in c. 11, 3.
pollaplasi/w|—dat. of cause.
*lo/gous e)poiei=to—‘had a conference.’ Livy would have reported this conversation at length.

ou) parh=san— c. 95, 3. The incompetence displayed by Athens against Perdiccas is so strange that the ambassadors sent to Sitalces may have been bribed: for they might easily have sent word when Sitalces really did start. The muddle which followed the death of Pericles is as great as the confusion in the English government during the Bute ministry after the fall of Pitt in 1761. Perhaps it is partly due to the same cause.
a)pistou=ntes—Sitalces had become an ally two years before, and his promise had been unfulfilled till now. Cf. c. 29. e)/pemyan—‘had sent.’
*)en p. h)=san—c. 80, 3. The Thessalians and the other Greeks rightly regarded Sitalces now as a mere plunderer.
*qra=|kes—the tribes living in the plains on the lower Strymon, near Amphipolis.
*pare/sxe lo/gon—on the analogy of fo/bon pare/xein, as mh\ below shows: ‘even as far as the ... he caused questionings.’
e)pi\—denotes distance, as in e)f' o(/son, c. 62, 2.
u(p' au)tw=n a)go/menoi—‘induced by the Athenians.’
kata\ to\ c.—c. 22, 2.

xwrh/swsin—The change to the plur., suggesting *qra=kes, adds a notion of vague terror to the narrative. This small artifice shows how perpetually Thuc. produces pathos
by saying the least that cau possibly be said. Cf. Eur. Hec. 277 mh/ mou to\ te)knon e)k xerw=n a)pospa/sh?s | mhde\ kta/nhte.
*(/ama e)pe/xwn—‘as he overran them.’
ei)=xen au)tw| —cf. c. 102, 2.
u(po\ xeimw=nos—one would have supposed that Sitalces would have foreseen this.
a)napei/qetai—c. 14, 1.
*seu/qou—he succeeded Sitalces. Spardacus was brother of Sitalces.
e)p' au)th=|—‘along with.’ Cf. Isaeus, 2, 5 e)pi\ th=| a)delfh=? proi=ka. prospoiei=tai—sibi conciliat.
*ta\s pa/sas—‘in all.’
kata\ ta/xos—again Thuc. contrasts the slightness of the result with the vastness of the plan. Cf. c. 7, 2.
u(pe/sxeto—contrast c. 95, 2.
*)astakou=—the Corinthians had restored the tyrant Euarchus who had been expelled by the Athenians, c. 31, 33. Cl. thinks the place must have since joined Athens.
*stra/tou—c. 80, 8: Coronta is unknown.
*oi)nia/das—c. 82. As Oeniadae had helped Cnemus effectually, it would have been advantageous to puuish it and prevent it from doing more harm to Athens.
a)/nwqen me\n— sc. r(e)wn, ‘flowing past Stratus high up the stream.’
e)ciei\s —of water discharging itself into the sea, only in Thuc. and Herod. The meaning reappears in Polybius.
perilimna/zwn —this applies to the winter only.
*)exina/dwn—the object of this digression is probably to show that it was as difficult to attack Oeniadae by sea as by land.
prosxoi=—‘forms deposits.’
h)pei/rwntai— = h)/peiros gege/nhntai. ou)k e)n pollw=|—c. 17, 2.
tou=to paqei=n —pass. of tou=to dra=n, as c. 11, 8, 49, 5. This has not happened, as the sea carries away the deposits. Cf. Herod. II. 10.
*to/ te ... ai(/ te—the double cause, as c. 95, 2.
me/ga kai\ polu\—cf. c. 5, 2.
a)llh/lais—‘help one another to bind the deposits together.’
e)/xousai— = pare/xousai, as c. 61, 2.

*(/ote dh\ a)la=sqai—cf. c. 13, 5, the infin. by assimi- lation to xrh=sai. M. T. 755. In temporal sentences in Or. Obl. Thuc. generally retaius the mood of the Recta, except III. 95 e)/ws katabai/h, representing e(/ws a)
 katabw=, IV. 117 pri
 paraskeua/sainto, representiug pri
 a)
 paraskeuasw/meqa, VII. 48 o(po/te bou/lointo, representing o(/tan boulw/meqa, and III. 22, 8.
mhtro/s—Eriphyle, c. 68, 3.
xrh=sai—this meaning occurs in Herod., Thuc., and tragedy only. The Attic is a)nairei=n. oi)kei=n—pres. (or aor.) infin. after words meaning to give an oracle. M. T. 98.
u(peipo/nta—‘saying besides,’ as in I. 90, 4.

lu/sin tw=n deima/ton—technical words of the oracle. Cf. Pausan. 2, 29. 6 e)s *delfou\s a)pe)steilan ... ai)th/sontas lu/sin tou=
kakou=. Soph. El. 635 a)/nakti tw=|d' o(/pws luthri/ous | eu)xa\s a)na/sxw deima/twn a(\ nu=n e)/xw. eu(rw\n—sc. tau/thn th\n gh=n. h(/tis mh/pw—hypothetical rel., ‘such as was not.’ The vague form is well suited to the oracle.
au)tw=|—agent.
*(ikanh\ a)\n kexw=sqai—i.e. kexwsme/nh a)\n ei)/h, ‘it would be by this time.’
di/aita—‘to make a habitation,’ pred. with xw=sqai. e)duna/steuse—ingressive, as e)basi/leusan c. 99. 3.
e)pwnumi/an—it was called *kourh=tis before.
*)eleuqe/rous—the slaves had been sold.
*tw=| pole/mw|—c. 47, 1.

e)teleu/ta—the anaphora is probably unintentional, this being a formula, which, though to us it may become tedious, is quite in accordance with the Greek method of ending quietly. Cf. the closing lines of any Greek play, and the finish of any Greek speech except the de Corona. (I cannot in the least agree with what Dr. Rutherford says on this formula.)

div2.p: Ch. 1 Preface to the Ten Years' War.

Ch. 2-6 The ban attempt on Plataea, April 431 B.C. The Thebans surprised the town while the Peloponnesians were preparing to invade Attica. They offered to accept Plataea as an ally; which offer the Plataeans in their terror were about to accept. But, on noticing that the Thebans were few in number, they decided to attack them; and of the Thebans some were killed and the rest were captured while searching in vain for the gates of the town. Hereupon a large force arrived from Thebes, and the Plataeans expostulated with them, promising on their part—so the Thebans said—that they would release the prisoners if their land were left unharmed. But, when the Thebans departed, the prisoners were put to death. Then the Athenians sent troops and supplies to Plataea, and the women, children, and old men were removed from the town to Athens.

Ch. 7-9 The preparations and the feelings of both sides. The Peloponnesians formed a prodigious scheme for a huge navy, but nothing came of it all. (*le/wn e)ge/lasen e)ntau=qa.) The Athenians made a special point of securing the friendship of the N.W. islands. The usual prophecies were whispered: the usual portents were reported. Sparta's catch-word was Freedom: Athens cried Empire. Therefore all to whom the choice of sides lay open chose Sparta. But the islands and coast-towns of Asia and of the North-West were bound to support Athens; and Plataea, Naupactus, and the Acarnanians, except those of Astacus and Oeniadae, were indebted to her for benefits received.

Ch. 10-12 The Lacedaemonians muster at the Isthmus preparatory to invading Attica. There Archidamus the Spartan king harangued them in a speech which exemplifies the
habitual caution and hesitancy of the Spartans in their undertakings outside the Peloponnese. The despatch of a Spartan to ascertain the temper of the Athenians produced nothing more than an aphorism from the messenger.
Ch. 13 Notes of speeches made by Pericles in the assembly when the first invasion was imminent. He stated the grounds of his confidence that Athens was a match for Sparta.

Ch. 14-16 The Athenians, following the advice of Pericles, conveyed their goods from the country into the city. But the move was irksome to all those who had been brought up in the country. (Antiquarian digression on early Attica.)

Ch. 18-22 Opening of the campaign of 431 B.C. The first invasion of Attica was desultory and ill-planned. Archidamus delayed at Oenoe in the hope that Athens would be terrified into submission by the great numbers of his army. But the Athenians were more discontented with Pericles than afraid of Archidamus. The king, being repulsed in an attempt ou Oenoe, made his way to Acharnae, where he again tarried, hoping to entice the enemy ont to battle. And the enemy would have been enticed to battle had not Pericles persistently withstood their clamour. He only sent out a squadron or two of horse to protect the country in the immediate neighbourhood of the city.

Ch. 23-26 But, in the meanwhile, Carcinas and Proteas and Socrates sailed from Piraeus with a fleet of one hundred sail, and made descents on the coasts of the Peloponnese. An attack on Methone was repulsed by Brasidas. Simultaneously Cleopompos, in command of a fleet of thirty ships, made a successful expedition to the coast of the Opuntian Locrians. When Archidamus had left Attica, the Athenians formed a reserve fund of one thousand talents and a reserve fleet of one hundred vessels.
Ch. 27 In the same summer the Athenians appropriated Aegina.
Ch. 28 On the 3rd of August there was an eclipse of the sun, which was considered remarkable by those who did not know Anaxagoras.
Ch. 29 Formation of an alliance between Athens and Sitalces of Thrace, and reconciliation of Athens and Perdiccas of Macedon. Sitalces promised to aid the Athenians in the reduction of Chalcidice.

Ch. 30-31 After their failure at Methone, Carcinus and his colleagues made a highly successful expedition to Acarnania and Cephallenia. They expelled Euarchus, tyrant of Astacus, and gained Cephallenia for Athens. On the homeward voyage,
they learnt that Pericles had invaded the Megarid with the whole of the Athenian forces. Similar expeditions were undertaken annually (sometimes twice a year, in the spring and autumn, IV. 66) until 424 B. C., when Nisaea was captured.
Ch. 32 In the late autumn, the Athenians fortified Atalanta to protect Euboea from Locrian pirates.
Ch. 33 When the Athenian fleet had left Acarnania, Euarchus recovered Astacus with help from Corinth.

Ch. 34 At the close of the campaign the Athenians buried the bones of their dead with much ceremony in the Ceramicus. And every year this ceremony was repeated: for this was a custom of the Athenians. The funeral oration was delivered this year by Pericles himself.

Ch. 35-46 The historian's report of the speech delivered by Pericles. The general introduction is followed by a special introduction to the first and most important part of the body of the speech; that is to say, to that part which contains a description of the ideal Athens and of the ideal Athenian, Athens and the Athenians as Pericles desire them to be, and as, in his view, they might be—nay, as they almost were. ‘Athens is a liberal education to Greece,’ and even her enemies admit her greatness. (c. 41.)
The Athenian is versatile and patriotic, able to live in any land, yet loving his own above all others. It is this ideal. this true Athens that the citizens must keep before their minds. They must love their city, (e)rastai\ gigno/menoi au)th=s) as Plato saysSee Rep. 501 D, 487 D, 493 A, 486 D, for the importance of the words e)rastai/, a)/xrhstos, pai/deusis, eu)/xaris. philosophers are lovers of the ideal and the true (e)rastai\ tou= o)/ntos te kai\ a)lhqei/as): must be her true philosopher-citizens, learning their lesson of self-devotion from the pattern of Greece. Then they would prove to the world that Athenian versatility (eu)trapeli/a) meant something more than the mere cunning which the Thebans associated with that quality, that the Athenian character was as far above the Spartan as the Athenian ideal of e)leuqeri/a was above the Spartan ideal of eu)nomi/a. Next the orator praised the fallen, exhorted his hearers to be like them, and bade the relatives not to weep for those who had brought them to such great honour by one glorious act never to be forgotten.
The oration closed with a short peroration remarkable for its calm dignity and unaffected simplicity.

Ch. 47 Opening of the campaign of 430 B.C. The second invasion of Attica had but begun when a mysterious epidemic
broke out in Athens. No medicine, no prayers, no voices of oracles availed, so that men at last gave them up as useless.
Ch. 48-54 History of the origin of the epidemic; of its symptoms and effects; of its influence on morality.

It seems that it broke out in Ethiopia, and passed thence to the Persian Empire. Anyhow, it appeared quite suddenly in Piraeus, and thence made its way to the crowded city. The historian promises to relate what he had himself suffered and had observed in others.

There were three stages in the disease, which followed one another with such rapidity that the crisis came generally in a week or nine days. Many who survived the crisis died subsequently from exhaustion. Others were disabled for a time or permanently. Even birds of prey and beasts shrank from the tainted flesh of the dead: no eagles gathered there. The doctors could discover no satisfactory treatment, and no natural strength made any man proof against the infection. But worse than all the bodily suffering was the mental depression that accompanied the disease Relatives neglected to tend their sick and to mourn their dead. But so much the more readily, when natural ties were forgotten, did good friends sacrifice themselves; and many generous men thus lost their lives. While the epidemic raged there was very little other sickness in the city: and those who once recovered were not liable to another attack; at any rate, a second attack was never serious. In the general panic, the ceremonies of religion and the decencies of burial were disregarded.

While the love of many grew cold, wickedness increased. For hope and fear were fled, and men gave themselves up to the pleasures of the moment, feeling that there was no future. The old people called to mind an oracular saying heard in their youth; but, though it seemed to apply to the present, they could not agree about one of the words.

Ch. 55-57 While Archidamus was ravaging Attica, Pericles left Athens with a fleet of one hundred ships to ravage the coasts of the Peloponnese. An attack on Epidaurus failed. The enemy retired from Attica where they had been for forty days. This proved to be the longest of all the invasions of Attica, though it was said that it would have lasted still longer had not the Peloponnesians feared the epidemic, which had scarcely been felt in the Peloponnese.

Ch. 58-59 When Pericles returned, the fleet was sent to Potidaea under Hagnon. The only result was that the army already before the town caught the epidemic from the newlyarrived troops, so that Hagnon returned after losing many men
owing to the disease. At Athens the discontent caused by the invasion and the plague together was so serious that Pericles called a special assembly and delivered an oration in defence of himself and his policy.

Ch. 60-64 Version by Thucydides of the speech then de- livered. Pericles upbraided his hearers for falling so very far short of the ideal he had set before them. Instead of being ready to sacrifice themselves for their city they had made overtures for peace to Sparta. And what was the use of blaming him for misfortunes sent by Providence?

Ch. 65 Great as was the effect produced by the speech, the Athenians nevertheless did not rest satisfied until they had fined Pericles. Then follows a notice of the statesman's death, and an account of his character and policy.

Ch. 66-67 Two Lacedaemonian failures narrated. An expedi- tion against Zacynthus produced no result, and ambassadors from the Peloponnese to the Great King fell into the hands of the Athenians. having been arrested by Sadocus, son of Sitalces, while passing through Thrace. Among them was the notorious Corinthian Aristeus. They were put to death at Athens without a trial.
Ch. 68 In the autumn the Ambraciots, enemies of Athens, attacked the Amphilocian Argos, but were unable to take it. The historian narrates the origin and earlier history of this Argos.

Ch. 69-70 During the winter, Phormio was sent from Athens with twenty ships to Naupactus to command the entrance of the Gulf of Corinth. About the same time Melesandrus, an Athenian general, was defeated and killed in Lycia. Potidaea surrendered on terms which the Athenians at home considered unnecessarily favourable.

Ch. 71-78 Opening of the campaign of 429 B.C. Instead of invading Attica, Archidamus attacked Plataea. After unsuccessful negotiations with the Plataeans and a solemn appeal to heaven, the king attempted to carry a mound to the top of the walls, but the Plataeans first built on to their wall opposite the mound, and then successfully undermined the enemy's work. Then they built a new wall in towards the city, concave to the old wall where they had raised its height, their object being to take the enemy between a cross-fire in case they gained the raised wall. Then the enemy used batteringrams, but the Plataeans broke them by letting down huge beams upon them. Next Archidamus tried to burn the town. As the attempt failed he was forced to blockade Plataea, which contained four hundred and eighty men and one hundred
and ten women. The rest of the inhabitants had been sent to Athens, which had promised to send aid to Plataca and had encouraged it to hold out.
Ch. 79 An Athenian expeditionary force sent to subdue Chalcidice is defeated, and three generals killed, near Spartolus.

Ch. 80-82 Mean while a combined expedition of Lacedae- monians, Ambraciots, and barbarians was planned against Acarnania. The main body of the fleet was still preparing, when Cnemus, the Spartan admiral, started from Leucadia for Stratus. Near that city the barbarians were completely defeated, and Cnemus retreated to Oeniadae.

Ch. 83-84 At almost the same time the main body of the fleet, consisting of forty-seven vessels, was intercepted by Phormio while on its way to Acarnania. In an engagement fought soon after day-break, the Peloponnesians were utterly defeated, and pursued to Patrae.

Ch. 85-86 When the news of the defeat reached Sparta, the ephors sent out three commissioners, one of whom was Brasidas, to advise Cnemus; for they were indignant at the result of this the first great naval battle of the war. The commissioners had orders to bring on a new battle, and a ‘better’ one. On their arrival both sides then sent for reinforcements. Twenty ships were sent from Athens, but were ordered to go first to Crete, where they were delayed by bad weather. The Peloponnesians, having seventy-seven ships, were anxious to bring on a battle before any reinforcements reached Phormio.

Ch. 87-89 The commanders of both sides harangued their troops before the engagement. The Peloponnesians excused the former defeat, and pointed out that their side was superior both in courage and in numbers. On the other hand, Phormio declared that it was fear which made the enemy bring a fleet of seventy-seven to fight a fleet of twenty ships; and the boldness of the Athenians in accepting battle with so small a force filled the enemy, they might be sure, with astonishment and apprehension.

Ch. 90-92 A detailed and admirably perspicuous account of the battle in the Gulf. The Peloponnesians were defeated by superior seamanship. One of the Spartan commissioners committed suicide when his ship was disabled at the crisis of the battle. Phormio returned to Naupactus where he was joined by the twenty ships from Crete. The main body of the Peloponnesians, under Cnemus and Brasidas, returned to Corinth.

Ch. 93-94 There, on the suggestion of the Megarians, they planned a night attack on the Piraeus. But their courage failed them at the last minute, so they plundered Salamis instead. The Athenians were at first greatly alarmed, but a fleet was sent out at dawn, and the Peloponnesians retired in haste to Nisaea. Then the Piraeus was made a ‘closed harbour’ as a precaution against surprises.

Ch. 95-101 Expedition of Sitalces against Perdiccas of Mace- don and the Chalcidians. Perdiccas had deceived him, and he had made a promise to Athens that he would help to restore order in Chalcidice. The Athenians had promised to send a large force to help him; but, feeling doubts about his sincerity, only sent commissioners bearing presents. However, Sitalces crossed the Balkans with a vast, but very miscellaneous force. Thucydides gives an account of the kingdom. revenues, and empire of the Odrysae, and of the rise of the Macedonian monarchy. The forces of Perdiccas were quite insufficient to withstand Sitalces, at whose approach even the Greeks trembled as far south as Thermopylae, and made ready their arms. But the Athenian force did not come, and provisions ran short: so, after ravaging Chalcidice, Bottice, and Macedonia, he acceded to his nephew's suggestion that he should depart. His nephew Seuthes obtained the sister of Perdiccas in marriage as a return for his mediation.
